City of Borger
Code of Ordinances
Including Supplement No. 13
This Code of Ordinances contains all ordinances deemed advisable to be included as enacted through Ordinance
O-009-18 adopted 11/6/18.
HOME RULE CHARTER
SECTION 1. NAME, BOUNDARIES AND POWERS OF CITY.
The City of Borger, Hutchinson County, Texas, as the boundaries of said City are herein established, or may
hereafter be established, shall be a body politic, incorporated under and known by the name and style of the
“City of Borger”, with such powers, rights and duties herein provided. The boundary and limits of said
corporation shall be as follows:
“BEGINNING at a point at the Southwest corner of Section Eighteen, Block “Y”, M. & C. Survey,
Hutchinson County, Texas, thence North along the West lines of Sections Eighteen, Nineteen and
Twenty said block and survey to the Northwest corner of the southwest one quarter (1/4) of Section
Twenty said block and survey;
THENCE east through the center of Section Twenty of said block and survey crossing the East line of
said Section Twenty and continuing to the center of Section Thirteen said block and survey;
THENCE south to the southeast corner of the southwest quarter (SW 1/4) of same section Thirteen in
said block and survey;
THENCE west to the common corner of sections fourteen, nineteen, twenty, and thirteen in said
block and survey;
THENCE south along the east line of sections nineteen and eighteen said block and survey to the
southeast corner of said section eighteen;
THENCE west to the southwest corner of said section eighteen, in said block and survey to the point
of beginning all being situated in the County of Hutchinson, State of Texas.”
The City of Borger as such shall have perpetual succession; right of local self government; may use a corporate
seal; may sue and be sued; may acquire property in fee simple or lesser interest or estate by purchase, gift,
devise, appropriation, lease or lease with the privilege to purchase for any municipal purpose; may sell, lease,
hold, manage and control such real, personal and mixed property, and make any and all rules and regulations by
ordinance or resolution which may be required to carry out fully all the provisions of any conveyance, deed, or
will, in relation to any gift or bequest, or the provisions of any lease by which it may acquire property; may
acquire, construct, own, lease and operate and regulate public utilities, and impound, manufacture and otherwise
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 2/430
acquire all such commodities and things as may be necessary or desirable for use or distribution in the operation
of public utilities, may assess, levy and collect taxes for general and special purposes on all the subjects or
objects which the city may lawfully tax, including the right to assess the franchise of any public corporation
using and occupying its streets or grounds separate from its tangible property; may borrow money on the faith
and credit of the city by the issue or sale of bonds or notes of the city in the manner and of the amount permitted
by the Constitution of the State; may appropriate the money of the city for all lawful purposes; may create,
provide for, construct, regulate and maintain all things of the nature of public works and improvements; may
levy and collect assessments for local improvements and create and cause to be created improvement district as
now or shall be hereafter authorized by the laws of Texas, and may exercise all powers and shall have all rights
in reference thereto that now or may hereafter be authorized and permitted by law; may license and regulate
persons, corporations and associations engaged in any business, occupation, profession or trade, as well as all
things and matters pertaining to sanitation or health; may define, prohibit, abate, suppress and prevent all things
detrimental to the health, morals, comforts, safety, convenience and welfare of the inhabitants of the city, and all
nuisances and causes thereof; may levy and collect from those who keep or permit to be kept or maintained
within the city anything whatever which may be or become productive of filth, disagreeable to the senses, or
dangerous to health, such taxes as may be deemed reasonably necessary to prevent or correct the evils caused
thereby; may establish a municipal court and prescribe its jurisdiction; may regulate the construction, height, and
the material used in all buildings, and the maintenance and occupancy thereof; may regulate and control the
platting and laying out and the use, for whatever purposes, of the streets and other public places; may create,
establish, abolish and organize offices and fix salaries and compensations of all officers and employees, may
make and enforce local police, sanitary and other regulations; and may pass such ordinances as may be
expedient for maintaining and promoting the peace, good government, health and welfare of the city, and for the
government of the functions thereof.
State law references–Powers of home-rule municipality, V.T.C.S. art. 1175; general powers of home-rule municipality, V.T.C.A.,
Local Government Code, sec. 51.071 et seq.
SECTION 2. OTHER POWERS.
The enumeration of particular powers by this charter shall not be held or deemed to be exclusive, but in addition
to the powers enumerated herein, implied thereby or appropriate to the exercise thereof, the city shall have and
may exercise all other powers which are now or which may hereafter be conferred on municipalities by the
Constitution and laws of Texas. And it is hereby expressly provided that it shall have all the powers that are
granted to cities of more than five thousand inhabitants by Chapter 13 Vernon's Annotated Civil Statutes of The
State of Texas, Revision of 1925 and all Amendments thereto.
SECTION 3. EXTENSION OF BOUNDARIES.
The extension of city boundaries shall be made in the manner as prescribed by law. (Amended 1/23/45;
Ordinance of 2/18/92, ratified 5/2/92)
State law references–Municipal boundaries and annexation, V.T.C.A, Local Government Code, ch. 41 et seq.; municipal annexation,
V.T.C.A., Local Government Code, ch. 43; authority of home-rule municipality to annex area, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code, sec.
43.021.
SECTION 4. [EXEMPTION FROM] EXECUTION [AND] GARNISHMENT.
No public or other property of any character held or owned by the City shall be subject to seizure or sale under
execution of any kind or nature, nor shall the City be subject to garnishment in any cause, nor shall it ever be
required to answer any garnishment proceedings; and any judgment taken against it in such proceeding shall be
void.
State law reference–Authority to provide that municipal funds not subject to garnishment, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code, sec.
101.023.

SECTION 5. NOTICE [OF] CLAIM BEFORE SUIT.
The City shall not be liable on account of any claim for damages to any person or property, unless the person
asserting such claim, or some one for such person, shall give to the City written notice of such claim and of the
facts upon which it is based, within thirty days from the time it is claimed that such damages were inflicted, and
no suit shall be instituted or maintained on any such claim, until the expiration of ninety days from the time such
notice shall have been given.
State law references–Texas Tort Claims Act, V.T.C.A., Civil Practice and Remedies Code, ch. 101; notice procedures, V.T.C.A., Civil
Practice and Remedies Code, sec. 101.101; liability for damages, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code, sec. 51.077.
SECTION 6. COUNCIL-MANAGER PLAN.
The form of government provided in this Charter shall be known as the “Council-Manager Plan” and shall
consist of a Council of five persons who shall be elected at large in the manner hereinafter provided, one of
whom shall by a majority vote of the Council be designated as Mayor, and of a City Manager who shall be
employed by the Council and said Council and City Manager shall have and exercise the powers and discharge
the duties hereinafter specified. (Ordinance 1969-2, art. II, 2/18/69, ratified 4/1/69)
Editor's note–Ordinance 1969-2, ratified April 1, 1969, changed the form of government from the Commission-Manager Plan to the
Council-Manager Plan.
State law reference–Form of government, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code, sec. 26.021.
SECTION 7. ELECTION LAWS.
All elections held under the provisions of this Charter shall be in conformity with the then existing state election
laws; however, ballots used for the election of Councilmembers shall be without party designation. (Ordinance
1969-2, art. III, 2/18/69, ratified 4/1/69)
State law reference–Provisions regarding elections generally, V.T.C.A., Election Code.
SECTION 8. VACANCIES.
Vacancies in the Office of Mayor and in the Council shall be filled by the Council for the remainder of the
unexpired term except as herein otherwise provided but any vacancies resulting from a recall election shall be
filled in the manner provided in such cases.
In the event as many as three members of the City Council shall resign within the time contained in three
consecutive days, a municipal election shall be called by the remaining Councilmembers and shall be held
within thirty days thereafter in the manner provided by this Charter for the holding of municipal elections for the
purpose of filling the vacancies caused by such resignation.
State law reference–Special election to fill vacancy generally, V.T.C.A., Election Code, sec. 201.051 et seq.
SECTION 9. QUALIFICATIONS.
Each Councilmember shall be a resident citizen of the City of Borger, and have the qualifications of electors
therein, and shall have resided in the City of Borger at least one year preceding their election. The
Councilmembers and other officers and employees shall not hold any other public office of emolument and shall
not be interested in the profits or emoluments of any contract, job, work or service for the municipality or
interested in the sale to the city of any supplies, equipment, material or articles purchased; nor shall either of
them be the owner of stock in any public utility or public service corporation within the city, nor in the employ
of any owner of stock in any public utility or public service corporation. Any officer or employee of the city who
shall cease to possess any of the qualifications herein required shall forfeit their office or position and any
contract in which any officer or employee shall or may become interested, may be declared void by the Council.
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 4/430
No officer or employee of the city shall accept any frank, free tickets, passes or service, or anything of value,
directly or indirectly, from any person, firm or corporation, upon terms more favorable than are granted to the
public, and any violation of this section shall be a misdemeanor, and on conviction thereof, such office or
employment shall be forfeited. (Election of 4/7/84)
State law references–Eligibility for public office, V.T.C.A., Election Code, sec. 141.001 et seq.; age and residence requirements for
home-rule city office, V.T.C.A., Election Code, sec. 141.003; candidates for city office, V.T.C.A., Election Code, ch. 143.
SECTION 10. ELECTIVE OFFICERS.
The elective officers of the city shall consist of five Councilmembers, each of whom shall be qualified electors
and each shall have resided in the City of Borger for one year next preceding their election and in all elections
held hereunder whether from the election of five or a less number of Councilmembers, the candidate or
candidates receiving the greatest number of votes of the qualified voters of the city at large voting at said
election shall be declared elected.
State law references–Eligibility for public office, V.T.C.A., Election Code, sec. 141.001 et seq.; age and residence requirements for
home-rule city office, V.T.C.A., Election Code, sec. 141.003; candidates for city office, V.T.C.A., Election Code, ch. 143.
SECTION 11. ELECTION RESULTS.
The Council shall, on the first Monday after each regular and special election, or, if for any cause the same
cannot be done on the first Monday, then as soon thereafter as practicable, canvass the returns, and declare the
result of such elections.
State law reference–Canvassing elections, V.T.C.A., Election Code, ch. 67.
SECTION 12. TERM OF ELECTIVE OFFICERS.
(1) An election shall be held annually on the first Saturday in May for the election of City Councilmembers.
At the election for Councilmembers to be held on April 1, 1969, the two (2) candidates receiving the greatest
number of votes of qualified voters of said election shall be elected for a term of three (3) years; the two (2)
candidates who receive the next greatest number of votes of the qualified voters shall be elected for a term of
two (2) years. The candidate receiving the next greatest number of votes of the qualified voter shall be elected
for a one year term.
(2) Following such initial election, each Councilmember thereafter elected shall be elected for a three-year
term, however, any appointment of a Councilmember as authorized by the Charter shall be only until the next
annual election. If a Councilmember is to be elected for an unexpired term, the Candidate seeking such position
shall so designate in their application.
(3) If an election should be necessary under Section 8 hereof, the candidates in their application shall state the
term remaining unexpired they desire to seek.
(Ordinance 1969-2, art. III, 2/18/69, ratified 4/1/69; election of 5/7/88)
State constitution reference–Term of office exceeding two years but not to exceed four years, vacancies, Texas Constitution, art. 11,
sec. 11.
State law references–Date for election of officers, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code, sec. 26.042; election dates, V.T.C.A., Election
Code, ch. 41; election by plurality, V.T.C.A., Election Code, sec. 2.001 et seq.
SECTIONS 13–18. RESERVED.
Editor's note–Sections 13 through 18 were repealed April 1, 1969, at an election held pursuant to Ordinance 1969-2, art. III, adopted
February 18, 1969. The subject matter of the repealed sections is as follows: sec. 13, nomination of candidates; sec. 14, nominating

petition; sec. 15, form of nominating petition; sec. 16, filing with clerk; sec. 17, form of ballot; sec. 18, rotation of names on ballot.
SECTION 19. RECALL ELECTIONS.
The Mayor and any and all of the Councilmembers may be removed from office by the electors. The procedure
to effect such removal shall be as follows:
A petition demanding that the question of removing any such officer be submitted to the electors
shall be filed with the City Secretary.
Each such petition shall outline in detail specific allegations of official misconduct, incompetency,
willful violation of any municipal ordinance, conviction of a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude
or felony while in office, or other reasons relating to the performance of official duties regarding the
one (1) officer whose removal is sought.
Such petition for the recall of any or all of the Councilmembers or the Mayor shall be signed by a
number of registered voters residing within the City equal to thirty (30) percent of the votes cast at
the last regular municipal election; but in no event shall fewer than five hundred (500) signatures be
required.
The signatures to such petitions need not be appended to any one paper.
(Election of 5/7/88)
SECTION 20. PETITION FOR RECALL.
Petition papers shall be procured from the City Secretary, who shall keep a sufficient number of such blank
petitions on file for distribution as herein provided. Prior to the insurance [issuance] of such petition papers an
affidavit shall be made by one or more qualified electors and filed with the City Secretary, stating the name and
office of the officer or officers sought to be removed. The City Secretary upon issuing any such petition papers
to an elector, shall enter in a record, to be kept in such office, the name of the elector to whom issued, the date of
such issuance and the number of papers issued, and shall certify on such papers the name of the elector to whom
issued and the date issued. No petition papers so issued shall be accepted as part of the petition unless it bears
such certificate of the City Secretary and unless it be filed as provided herein.
SECTION 21. RECALL PETITION SIGNATURES.
Each signer of a recall petition shall sign their name in ink or indelible pencil and shall place thereon after their
name, their place of residence by street and number, voter registration number, date of signing and their printed
name. The provisions of Charter [Chapter] 141, Subchapter C, Texas Election Code, as amended, shall apply to
any recall petition and to the signatures obtained in support thereof. (Election of 5/7/88)
SECTION 22. TIME [FOR] FILING WITH CITY SECRETARY.
All papers comprising a recall petition shall be assembled and filed with the City Secretary as one instrument
within twenty (20) days after the filing with the City Secretary of the affidavit stating the name and office of the
officer sought to be removed.
At the time of filing such recall petition, an individual or any group of individuals seeking the recall of any
officer shall file with the City Secretary a cash or surety bond in an amount to be determined by the City
Secretary sufficient to pay the expenses of such recall election. The costs of an unsuccessful recall election shall
be paid from the bond.
(Election of 5/7/88)
SECTION 23. ELECTION ON RECALL.
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 6/430
The City Secretary shall inspect each petition presented seeking the recall of a City officer, in order to determine
whether it contains the required number of valid signatures and complies with the other requirements of this
charter and state law, within fifteen (15) business days after the filing of each such petition and bond. Upon
verification that the petition presented contains the required number of valid signatures and conforms to the
requirements of this charter and state law, the City Secretary shall at once notify the officer sought to be recalled,
and shall submit the recall petition to the Council within thirty (30) days after its filing. If the official whose
removal is sought does not resign within five (5) days after such notice, the Council shall thereupon order and
fix a day for holding a recall election. Any such election shall be held not less than forty-five (45) days nor more
than seventy-five (75) days after the petition has been presented to the Council at the same time if any general
election is held within such period; but is [if] no such election be held within such period, the Council shall call
a special recall election to be held within the time aforesaid.
Before any such recall election for the removal of Mayor or Councilmembers shall be set, there shall be
nominated candidates to fill the vacancy or vacancies. Such nominations shall be made by petition; petitions for
each such candidate shall be signed by at least five (5) percent of the number of voters of the City of Borger
voting at the last regular municipal election, and shall be filed with the City Secretary of the City of Borger not
less than fifteen (15) days after the filing of the recall petition. The form and requirements for said petition and
acceptance by candidates shall be the same as provided in this charter in the case of election of Mayor and
Councilmembers.
(Election of 5/7/88)
SECTION 24. RECALL BALLOT.
The ballots at such recall elections shall conform to the following requirements:
With respect to each person whose removal is sought the question shall be submitted, “Shall (name of
person) be removed from the office of (name of office) by recall?”
Immediately following each such question there shall be printed on the ballots the two propositions,
in the order set forth:
For the removal of (name of person).
Against the removal of (name of person).
In voting said ballot the voters shall indicate their vote by placing an X in the square beside the
statement indicating the way they wish to vote.
Under said questions shall be placed the names of candidates to fill the vacancy or vacancies. The
name of the officer or officers whose removal is sought shall not appear on the ballot as a candidate
or candidates to succeed themselves.
(Election of 5/7/88)
SECTION 25. RESULTS [OF] RECALL ELECTION.
Should a majority of the votes cast at a recall election be against the recall of the officer named on the ballot,
such officer shall continue in office for the remainder of such officer's unexpired term, subject to recall as
before. If a majority of the votes cast at a recall election shall be for the recall of the officer named on the ballot,
the officer shall be deemed removed from office, and the replacement candidate receiving the highest number of
votes shall replace the officer so removed for the remainder of his or her unexpired therm [term]. (Election of
5/7/88)
SECTION 26. TIME [OF] SECOND RECALL.
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 7/430
No recall petition shall be filed against the Mayor, or City Council Members within two (2) months after each
takes their office, nor in case of an officer re-elected in a recall election, until two (2) months after that election.
SECTION 27. INITIATIVE[,] REFERENDUM AND RECALL.
Any proposed ordinance may be submitted to the Council by petition signed by at least thirty (30) percent of the
number of voters of the City of Borger voting at the last regular municipal election. All petition papers circulated
with respect to any proposed ordinance, shall be uniform in character and shall contain the proposed ordinance
in full, and have printed or written thereon the names and addresses of at least five electors who shall be
officially regarded as filing the petition and shall constitute a committee of the petitioners for the purpose
hereinafter named. (Election of 4/7/84)
SECTION 28. INITIATIVE [OR] REFERENDUM PETITION.
Each signer of a petition shall sign their name in ink or indelible pencil and shall place on the petition paper after
their name, their place of residence by street and number. The signature to any such petition paper need not all
be appended to one paper but to each such paper there shall be attached an affidavit by the circulator thereof,
stating the number of signers to such part of the petition and that each signature appended to the paper is the
genuine signature of the person whose name it purports to be, and was made in the presence of affiant.
SECTION 29. FILING WITH CITY SECRETARY.
All papers comprising a petition shall be assembled and filed with the City Secretary as one instrument, and
when so filed, the City Secretary shall submit the proposed ordinance to the Council within thirty (30) days from
the date of its filing. (Election of 4/7/84)
SECTION 30. SUBMIT TO COUNCIL.
The Council shall at once proceed to consider it and shall take final action thereon within thirty (30) days from
the date of submission. If the Council rejects the proposed ordinance, or passes it in a form different from that
set forth in the petition, the committee may then require that it be submitted to a vote of the electors in its
original form, or that it be submitted to a vote of the electors with any proposed change, addition, or amendment.
(Election of 4/7/84)
SECTION 31. [WHEN CERTIFIED].
When an ordinance proposed by petition is to be submitted to a vote of the electors, the committee of the
petitioners shall certify that fact and the proposed ordinance to the City Secretary within ten (10) days after the
final action on such proposed ordinance by the Council.
SECTION 32. TIME [FOR] CALLING ELECTION.
Upon receipt of the certificate and certified copy of the proposed ordinance, the Secretary shall certify the fact to
the Council at its next regular meeting. The proposed ordinance shall be submitted to vote of the electors at the
next uniform election date as provided in Vernon's Ann. Civ. St., Art. 2.01(b) Election Code, however, if such
uniform election date is less than forty-five (45) days subsequent to the receipt of the Secretary's certificate by
the Council, then the election shall be held on the next uniform election date after the end of the forty-five (45)
day period. (Election of 4/7/84)
State law references–Date for election of officers, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code, sec. 26.042; election dates, V.T.C.A., Election
Code, ch. 41.
SECTION 33. FORM OF BALLOT.
The ballots used when voting upon any such proposed ordinance shall state the title of the ordinance to be voted
on, and below it the two propositions, “For the Ordinance”, and “Against the Ordinance”, and in voting said
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 8/430
ballot, the voters shall indicate their vote by placing an X in the square beside the statement indicating the way
they wish to vote. If a majority of the electors voting on any such proposed ordinance shall vote in favor thereof,
it shall thereupon become an ordinance of the city. (Election of 4/7/84)
SECTION 34. VOTE TO REPEAL ORDINANCE.
Proposed ordinances for repealing any existing ordinance or ordinances, in whole or in part, may be submitted to
the Council as provided in the preceding sections for initiating ordinances, and if rejected by the Council, then to
a vote of the electors, as provided in Section 30. Initiated ordinances adopted by the electors shall be published
and may be amended or repealed as in the case of other ordinances, providing that no ordinance initiated by the
electors shall be amended or repealed sooner than three months after its enactment; nor shall any ordinance
repealed by the electors be re-enacted sooner than three months after such repeal.
SECTION 35. WHEN TO FILE OBJECTIONS.
No ordinance passed or franchise granted by the Council shall go into effect sooner than ten (10) days after its
final passage by the Council. If, at any time before becoming effective, thirty (30) percent of the number of
voters of the City of Borger voting at the last regular municipal election shall file with the City Secretary
objections to said ordinance or franchise, and a petition requesting that said ordinance or franchise be submitted
to a vote of the electors for their approval or rejection, it shall not become operative until voted thereon.
(Election of 4/7/84)
SECTION 36. [WHEN SUBMITTED TO VOTE.]
The City Secretary shall deliver such petition to the Council which shall proceed to reconsider the ordinance, or
franchise, as the case may be. If, upon such reconsideration, the ordinance or franchise be not entirely repealed,
the Council shall provide for submitting it to a vote of the electors, and in so doing the Council shall be
governed by the provisions of Section 31, 32, and 33, hereof, respecting the time of submission and the manner
of voting on ordinances proposed to the Council by petition. If, when submitted to a vote of the electors, any
such ordinance be not approved by a majority of those voting thereon, it shall be deemed repealed.
SECTION 37. REFERENDUM VOTE.
Referendum petitions need not contain the text of the ordinances, the repeal of which is sought, hut [but] shall be
subject in all other respects to the requirements for petitions submitting proposed ordinances to the Council.
Ballots used in referendum elections shall conform in all respects to those provided for in Section 33 of this
Charter.
SECTION 38. CONFLICTING ORDINANCES.
If the provisions of two or more ordinances adopted or approved at the same election conflict, the ordinance
receiving the highest affirmative vote shall prevail.
SECTION 39. EMERGENCY MEASURE.
Ordinances passed as emergency measures shall be subject to referendum in like manner as other ordinances,
except that they shall go into effect at the time indicated in such ordinances. If, when submitted to a vote of the
electors, an emergency measure be not approved by a majority of those voting thereon, it shall be considered
repealed as regards any further action thereunder; but such measure so repealed shall be deemed sufficient
authority for payment in accordance with the ordinance, or any expense incurred previous to the time of filing
petitions for a referendum vote thereon.
SECTION 40. RESERVED.
Editor's note–Section 40, pertaining to the officers of elections, was repealed April 1, 1969, at an election held pursuant to Ordinance
1969-2, art. III, adopted February 18, 1969.
