SECTION 41. ELECTION OF MAYOR.
The Council shall, at its first meeting after their election and qualification, or as soon thereafter as possible, by
ballot elect from their own membership one person, having in view their special qualifications for such position,
who shall be Mayor, and who shall have the power and discharge the duties specified and required by this
Charter. A majority vote of the entire Council shall be necessary to elect said Mayor. The Mayor shall hold his
office at the will of the Council, a majority vote of the Council being necessary to remove, and be subject to
recall by the electors as herein provided.
The Mayor shall be ex officio chairperson of the Council, and shall preside at their meetings. The Mayor shall be
recognized as the Official head of the City for ceremonial purposes, and by the Courts for the purpose of serving
civil process, and by the Governor for military purposes. During the absence or disability of the Mayor, the
Mayor's duties shall be performed by another member appointed by the Council.
SECTION 42. CITY MANAGER.
The Council shall employ a City Manager who shall be the administrative head of the municipal government and
shall be responsible for the efficient administration of all Departments. The City Manager shall be appointed
with the sole view of fitness for the position and without regard to political or religious affiliations. The City
Manager may or [may] not be a resident of the City of Borger, when appointed and the City Manager shall hold
the office at the will of the Council; provided the Council may at any time discontinue the City Manager's
employment.
SECTION 43. DUTIES OF CITY MANAGER.
The powers and duties of the City Manager shall be:
(a) To see that the law and ordinances are enforced.
(b) To appoint all appointive officers or employees of the City subject to the approval of the Board
of Councilmembers, and, except as herein provided remove all or any appointed officers and
employees in the service of the City; all appointments to be upon merit and fitness alone, all
removals to be for good cause only to be judged by the City Manager subject to the right of appeal to
the Council whose decisions shall be final. The members of the Board of Equalization excepted; such
appointments to be made by the Council. (Election of 4/7/84)
(c) To exercise control over all Departments and Divisions created herein or that may be hereafter
created by the Council.
(d) To attend all meetings of the Council with the right to take part in the discussion but having no
vote.
(e) To recommend to the Council for adoption such measures as the City Manager may deem
necessary or expedient.
(f) To keep the Council fully advised as to the financial conditions and needs of the City.
(g) To prepare and submit the annual budget on the basis of estimate made by the Officers of the
various Departments.
(h) To require a monthly report on blanks to be prepared and furnished by the City Manager for
that purpose from the officers of all departments reporting activities of the department for the
preceding month. (Ordinance 1969-2, art. IV, 2/18/69, ratified 4/1/69)
(i) To perform such other duties as may be prescribed by this Charter or be required of the City
Manager by ordinance or by the Council.
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 10/430
SECTION 44. CITY MANAGER-ADMINISTRATIVE–INDEPENDENCE OF.
It shall be unlawful for the City Council or any of its members to attempt to dictate the appointment of any
person to office or employment by the City Manager, the Council having only the right to approve or disapprove
the appointment made by the City Manager, and when disapproved by the Council the Manager shall make
another appointment immediately, and submit the same to the Council for their approval or disapproval and shall
submit appointments to the Council until some person is approved by the Council. Except for the purpose of
inquiry, the Council and its members shall deal with the administrative service solely through the City Manager,
and neither the Council nor any member thereof, shall give orders to any of the subordinates of the City
Manager, either publicly or privately.
SECTION 45. INVESTIGATIONS BY THE CITY MANAGER.
The City Manager may, without notice, cause the affairs of any department or the conduct of any officer or
employee to be examined. Any person or persons appointed by the City Manager to examine the affairs of any
Department or the conduct of any officer or employee shall have the power to require the attendance of
witnesses and the production of books and papers and other evidence.
SECTION 46. BOND [OF] CITY MANAGER.
The City Manager shall give an official bond in the sum of twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) or a
greater amount to be determined by the Council. Such bond shall be payable to the City of Borger and shall be
conditioned for the faithful discharge of the duties of such City Manager, and for the faithful accounting for all
monies, credits and things of value coming into the hands of such City Manager. Such bond shall be procured
from some regularly accredited Surety Company, authorized to do business under the Laws of the State of Texas,
and the Premium to such Surety Company shall be paid by the City of Borger. The City Manager shall have the
right to require official bonds from other appointive offices of the City in such amounts and conditions as the
Board of Councilmen may deem best for the efficiency of the public service.
All official bonds shall be approved by the Council and filed and recorded with the person exercising the duty of
the City Secretary.
(Election of 4/7/84)
State law reference–Official bonds, V.T.C.A., Government Code, ch. 604.
SECTION 47. OATH OF OFFICE.
Every officer of the City, before entering upon the duties of their office, shall take and subscribe to the oath
prescribed by the Constitution of the State of Texas for County Officials.
State constitution reference–Oath of office, Texas Constitution, art. 16, sec. 1.
SECTION 48. PAYING OUT MONEY.
No money shall be paid, nor warrant or voucher issued for any sum whatsoever, until after the City Council shall
have approved a claim therefor, and ordered the payment thereof, and before any warrant or voucher shall be
paid the same shall be signed by the City Secretary, attested with the seal of the City, and countersigned by the
City Manager.
SECTION 49. CONTRACTS BY CITY MANAGER.
Contracts for all expenditures, purchases or contracts for supplies, materials, equipment, public printing, public
improvements or public works shall be let on written, sealed, competitive bids in the manner prescribed by law.
The City Council shall by ordinance establish procedures for the prompt payment of vouchers and expenditures
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 11/430
made for such purposes. (Ordinance 1969-2, art. IV, 2/18/69, ratified 4/1/69; election of 4/7/84; Ordinance of
2/18/92, ratified 5/2/92)
State law reference–Purchasing and contracting authority of municipality, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code, chs. 252, 271.
SECTION 50. DUTIES OF COUNCIL.
The Council shall levy all taxes, apportion all funds of the City among the various departments[,] establish
special funds for special purposes, order election, canvass the returns and declare the result, enact all ordinances
of both civil and criminal nature, provide penalties for their violation, grant all franchises which they deem
proper, and have general power over the City finances, subject to the conditions and limitations imposed by this
Charter.
SECTION 51. WHAT CONSTITUTES QUORUM.
A majority of the members of the Council shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of any business except as
in this Charter otherwise provided.
SECTION 52. MEETINGS [OF] COUNCIL.
All meetings of the Council shall be open to the public and its proceedings shall be recorded in the journal which
shall be open to the inspection of all the citizens of the City. All votes on ordinances, franchises, resolutions and
awarding contracts for any purpose shall be taken by “Yea” and “Nay” and entered upon the journal. At the
request of any member, all votes upon any other question shall be likewise recorded.
State law reference–Open meetings, V.T.C.A., Government Code, ch. 551.
SECTION 53. [TIME OF] MEETINGS OF COUNCIL.
The regular meetings of the Council shall be held on the first and third Tuesday afternoons of each month, and
special meetings shall be held when requested by the City Manager and two Councilmembers, or when
requested by three Councilmembers. (Ordinance 1969-2, art. V, 2/18/69, ratified 4/1/69)
SECTION 54. REPORTS BY CITY MANAGER.
The City Manager shall monthly submit reports to the Council at a regular meeting of the work done in the
various departments for the preceding month, which report shall briefly and concisely show the work done, the
cost thereof, and the state of the various funds of the City. (Ordinance 1969-2, art. IV, 2/18/69, ratified 4/1/69)
SECTION 55. APPOINTMENT OF AUDITOR.
The Council shall as often as it deems advisable, and not less often than once each fiscal year, cause an audit to
be made of the books of accounts of the city. The audit is to be performed by a Certified Public Accountant,
licensed in the State of Texas. Such auditor shall furnish to the Council financial statements and reports as
recommended by the Municipal Finance Officers Association and as requested by the Council. A condensed
statement of such report of audit shall be published at least once each year. (Election of 4/7/84)
State law reference–Audit of municipal finances, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code, ch. 103.
SECTION 56. ORDINANCE ENACTMENT.
Each proposed ordinance or resolution shall be introduced in written or printed form, and shall not contain more
than one subject, which shall be clearly stated in the title; but general appropriation ordinances may contain the
various subjects and accounts for which monies are to be appropriated. The enacting clause of all ordinances
passed by the Council shall be: “Be it ordained by the City Council of the City of Borger.” The enacting clause
of all ordinances submitted by the initiative shall be: “Be it ordained by the people of the City of Borger.”
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 12/430
No ordinance, unless it be declared an emergency measure, shall be passed on the day on which it shall have
been introduced.
When any proposed ordinance, resolution or other thing duly presented for the action of the City Council shall
be finally acted upon and disposed of by the body before which it shall be pending, such action shall be binding
as the final action of the city thereupon, until the same shall be amended or repealed in some legal manner
authorized and provided by this Charter.
(Election of 4/7/84)
SECTION 57. EMERGENCY MEASURE.
All ordinances and resolutions shall be in effect from and after ten (10) days from the date of their passage by
the Council except as otherwise provided in this Charter. The Council may, by an affirmative vote of all
members present, pass emergency measures to take effect at the time indicated therein. An emergency measure
shall consist only of ordinances or resolutions for the immediate preservation of the public peace, property,
health, or safety, or providing for the usual daily operation of a municipal department, in which the emergency is
set forth and defined in a preamble thereto. Ordinances appropriating money may be passed as emergency
measures, but no measure making a grant, renewal, or extension of a franchise or other special privilege, or
regulating rate to be charged for its services by any public utility, shall ever be passed as an emergency measure.
(Ordinance 1969-2, art. VI, 2/18/69, ratified 4/1/69)
SECTION 58. INVESTIGATION BY COUNCIL.
The Council may investigate the financial transactions of any office or department of the City Government and
the official acts and conduct of any city official, and by similar investigations may secure information upon any
matter. In conducting such investigations the Council, or any committee thereof may compel the attendance of
witnesses and the production of books, papers and other evidence, and for that purpose may issue subpoenas or
attachments which shall be signed by the Chairman of the Council, which may be served and executed by any
officer authorized by law to serve subpoenas and other process. If any witnesses shall refuse to testify to any
facts within their knowledge or to produce any papers or books in their possession, or under their control,
relating to the matter under inquiry, before the Council, the Council shall have power to cause the witness to be
punished as for contempt. No witness shall be excused from testifying to their knowledge of the matter under
investigation in any such inquiry, but such testimony shall not be used against them in any criminal prosecution
except for perjury committed upon such inquiry. The Chairman of the Council shall have power to administer all
oaths to witnesses called to testify in such investigations.
SECTION 59. CHANGING DEPARTMENTS AND SUBDIVISIONS THEREOF.
The Council shall create and consolidate such appointive offices and may divide the administration of the City's
affairs into such departments, as they may deem advisable, and may discontinue any such appointive office or
department except the office of City Manager.
SECTION 60. PUBLICATION OF ORDINANCES.
A descriptive caption of all ordinances carrying a penalty shall be published once a week for two consecutive
weeks in some newspaper published in the City of Borger, and no such ordinance shall become effective until
ten days after the date of its last publication, provided that emergency measures shall take effect according to
their terms. (Ordinance 1969-2, art. VI, 2/18/69, ratified 4/1/69)
State law reference–Publication of ordinances, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code, sec. 52.013
SECTION 61. RECORDING OF ORDINANCES.
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 13/430
Every ordinance, or resolution, upon its becoming effective shall be recorded in a permanently bound book kept
for that purpose and shall be authenticated by the signature of the Mayor and the person exercising the duties of
City Secretary.
SECTION 62. NEPOTISM.
No person related within the second degree by affinity or within the third degree by consanguinity, to the Mayor,
or to either of the Councilmembers, or to the City Manager, shall be appointed to any office, position, clerkship
or service of the City.
State law reference–Nepotism, V.T.C.A., Government Code, ch. 573.
SECTION 63. SALARIES - ATTENDANCE - NECESSARY EXPENSES.
The compensation of the Mayor and each Councilman shall be $25.00 per meeting attended, but not to exceed
$50.00 per month; provided, further that the Mayor and Councilmen may be allowed their actual and necessary
expenses incurred while on business out of the city on matters pertaining to the city affairs and then only upon
the filing of an itemized account of the same with the Treasurer properly verified and allowed by the Council.
(Ordinance 1969-2, art. V, 2/18/69, ratified 4/1/69)
State law reference–Compensation of officers in home-rule municipality, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code, sec. 141.004.
SECTION 64. MUNICIPAL COURT.
There is hereby created, established and adopted in said City, a court to be known as the Municipal Court in said
City, which court shall have the jurisdiction and organization hereinafter prescribed.
Said court shall have jurisdiction within the territorial limits of said City in all criminal cases arising under the
ordinances of said City now in force or hereafter to be passed and shall have jurisdiction concurrently with any
Justice of the Peace, Hutchinson County, Texas, in all criminal cases arising under the laws of the State of Texas
in which the punishment is by fine only, and arising within the territorial limits of said City. Fines shall be
assessed in accordance with the Borger City Code and the laws of the State of Texas, but shall not exceed the
maximum allowed by state law.
(Election of 5/7/88)
State law references–Municipal courts generally, V.T.C.A., Government Code, sec. 29.001 et seq.; jurisdiction of municipal courts,
V.T.C.A., Government Code, sec. 29.003.
SECTION 65. SELECTION OF JUDGE OR RECORDER [MUNICIPAL COURT JUDGE].
Such court shall be presided over by a judge in such City who shall be selected in the manner and under the
respective provisions of this Charter concerning the selection of officers other than the elective officers, and all
such provisions are hereby made applicable to the Judge herein provided for. Such Judge shall hold office for the
same length of time and under the same terms and provisions as other appointed officers of the City and shall be
subject to removal in the same manner and by the same procedure provided by this Charter for other appointive
officers. Such Judge shall receive such compensation as shall be prescribed by the proper officers of the City
under the provisions of this Charter relative to the compensation of appointive officers.
The Council is authorized to appoint one or more Acting Judges who shall have the same authority as granted to
the regular Judge by this Charter and the laws of the State of Texas.
(Ordinance 1969-2, art. VII, 2/18/69, ratified 4/1/69)
State law references–Municipal court judges, V.T.C.A., Government Code, sec. 29.004; reference in state law to “recorder” means
“judge of the municipal court, V.T.C.A., Government Code, sec. 29.004(d); term of municipal court judge, V.T.C.A., Government
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 14/430
Code, sec. 29.005.
SECTION 66. CLERK OF MUNICIPAL COURT.
The City Secretary of said City shall be ex officio clerk of said court and may be authorized to appoint a deputy,
who shall have the same powers as the City Secretary when acting as the Clerk of said court. It shall be the duty
of said Clerk to keep a record of the proceedings of said court; to issue all process and generally to do and
perform all the duties of a clerk of a court as prescribed by the laws of the State of Texas for the Clerk of the
County Court insofar as such provisions may be applicable.
State law reference–Municipal court clerk, generally, V.T.C.A., Government Code, sec. 29.010.
SECTION 67. TRIAL BY JURY.
Every person charged with a misdemeanor in said court shall be entitled, if they shall demand, to be tried by a
jury of six (6) legal residents of said City, who shall be summoned, empaneled and qualified as jurors in Justice
Courts under the laws of the State of Texas. For all jurors summoned, the City shall pay the sum of $10.00, and
for all jurors who serve the City shall pay the sum of $15.00 in each case. (Ordinance 1969-2, art. VIII, 2/18/69,
ratified 4/1/69; election of 4/7/84)
State law references–Right to trial by jury inviolate, Tex. Code Crim. Proc. art. 1.12; trial before the jury, Tex. Code Crim. Proc. ch.
36; jury pay and expenses for jurors, Tex. Code Crim. Proc. art. 104.001.
SECTION 68. PLEADING, PRACTICE AND PROCEDURE.
All rules of pleading, practice and procedure now established for the County Court by the laws of the State of
Texas shall apply in said Municipal Court insofar as the same are applicable except that the proceedings in such
court shall be commended [commenced] by complaint in the manner and under the regulations now provided by
law in criminal cases prosecuted before the Justice of the Peace of the State of Texas and except that the
Recorder [Municipal Court Judge] need not charge the jury except upon charges requested in writing by the
defendant or the defendant's attorney, which such charges the Recorder [Municipal Court Judge] shall have the
power to give or refuse under the same rules and regulations now applicable to the granting or refusing of such
charges by the County Judge in criminal cases under the Statutes of said State. Complaints before such court
hereby created and established may be sworn to before the Recorder [Municipal Court Judge], Clerk of said
court or the clerk's deputy, or the City Attorney or the City Attorney's assistant, each and all of which officers for
that purpose shall have power to administer oaths; or it may be sworn to before any other officer authorized by
law to administer oaths.
State law reference–Procedures for processing cases within criminal jurisdiction of municipal court, Tex. Code Crim. Proc. ch. 45.
SECTION 69. SEAL OF MUNICIPAL COURT.
The said Municipal Court shall have a seal having engraved thereon a star of five points in the center and the
words “Municipal Court of Borger, Texas” the impress of which shall be attached to all proceedings except
subpoenas issued out of said court and shall be used to authenticate the official acts of the Clerk and of the
Recorder [Municipal Court Judge] where they are authorized or required to use the seal of office.
SECTION 70. COMMENCEMENT AND TRIAL OF CAUSES.
In all prosecution in said court where under an ordinance or under the provisions of the Penal Code of the State
of Texas, the complaint shall commence “In the name and by the authority of the State of Texas” and shall
conclude “against the peace and dignity of the State”; and where an offense is covered by an ordinance the
complaint may also conclude “contrary to said ordinance;” and all prosecution in said court shall be conducted
by the City Attorney of said City or by the City Attorney's assistant; but the County Attorney of Hutchinson
County, Texas, if such person so desires, may also represent the State of Texas in such prosecution.
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 15/430
State law references–Requisites of complaint, Tex. Code Crim. Proc. art. 1.23; municipal prosecutions by city attorney or deputy city
attorney, Tex. Code Crim. Proc. art. 45.201.
SECTION 71. RULES FOR COLLECTING FEES AND COSTS - PRACTICE.
The City shall have power by means of ordinances to be ordained and established in the manner provided by this
Charter for ordaining and establishing other ordinances from time to time to prescribe such rules not inconsistent
with the provisions of this Charter or the laws of the State of Texas as may be deemed proper to enforce by
execution against the property of the defendant or by imprisonment of the defendant the collection of all costs
and fees imposed by such court and shall also have the power to adopt such rules and regulations concerning the
practice and procedure in such court as may be deemed proper by the legislative body of said city not
inconsistent with the provisions of this Charter nor the laws of the State of Texas. Until the passage of such
ordinance all rules and regulations of said City now in force concerning the Municipal Court therein and the
enforcement of collection of fees and costs imposed by said Court shall be applicable to the court hereby created
and established.
State law reference–Municipal court fines, costs and special expenses, Tex. Code Crim. Proc. art. 45.203.
SECTION 72. PAYMENT OF FEES AND COSTS.
All costs and fees imposed by said Court in any prosecution therein shall be paid into the City Treasury of said
City for the use and benefit of the City.
State law reference–Municipal court fines, costs and special expenses, Tex. Code Crim. Proc. art. 45.203.
SECTION 73. [MAXIMUM COSTS.]
There shall be taxed against and collected from each defendant in case of the defendant's conviction before said
court such costs as may be provided by the ordinances of the City; but in no case shall there be prescribed the
collection of greater costs than are prescribed by the law of the State of Texas to be collected from defendants
convicted before Justices of the Peace.
State law references–Municipal court fines, costs and special expenses, Tex. Code Crim. Proc. art. 45.203; costs paid by defendants,
Tex. Code Crim. Proc. ch. 102.
SECTION 74. WITNESS FEES: ATTENDANCE OF WITNESSES.
The provisions of the Code of Criminal Procedure of the State of Texas regulating the amount and collection of
witness fees and for enforcing the attendance of witnesses in criminal cases tried before the Justices of the Peace
of the State shall as far as applicable govern and be applicable to the trial of cases before said court.
State law reference–Witness fees paid by defendant, Tex. Code Crim. Proc. art. 102.002.
SECTION 75. PUNISHMENT FOR CONTEMPT; BAIL.
The Judge of said Municipal Court shall have the power to punish for contempt to the same extent and under the
same circumstances as County Judges under the laws of the State of Texas may punish for contempt of the
County Court. The Judge shall have the power to take recognizances, admit to bail and forfeit recognizances and
bail bond under the same rules and regulations as now govern the taking and forfeiture of the same in the County
Court under the laws of Texas.
State law reference–Contempt of court, V.T.C.A., Government Code, sec. 21.002.
SECTION 76. PROCESS: HOW SERVED.
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 16/430
All process issued out of said Municipal Court shall be served by the Chief of Police or any police officer of the
City under the same rules and regulations as are provided by the laws of Texas for the service by sheriffs and
constables of process issued out of the County Court so far as the same are applicable.
State law reference–Service of process, Tex. Code Crim. Proc. sec. 45.202.
SECTION 77. WRITS MAY BE EXECUTED ANYWHERE IN COUNTY.
Writs issued out of said court or by the Clerk thereof for offenses against the law may be executed and the
accused person arrested by the Chief of Police or any police officer of the City anywhere within the territorial
limits of Hutchinson County.
State law reference–Service of process, Tex. Code Crim. Proc. sec. 45.202.
SECTION 78. PEACE BOND: PROCEDURE CONCERNING.
Whenever any person has been required by the Recorder [Municipal Court Judge] to give a peace bond or a
bond for good behavior or any similar bond which may be legally required and has complied with said order to
give such bond and has been guilty of the violation or infraction of said bond and the same is proved or
established to the satisfaction of the court in any trial or complaint, such party so offending may be fined in the
sum of two hundred dollars ($200.00) and the City in its corporate name may sue in any court having
jurisdiction for the recovery of the penalty of such bond.
SECTION 79. MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS.
In all cases the fines imposed on appeal together with the costs imposed in the Municipal Court and the Court to
which the appeal is taken shall be collected from the defendant and the defendant's bondsmen and such fines and
the costs of the Municipal Court shall, when collected, be paid into the treasury of the City. When the defendant
in such cases is committed to custody, the defendant shall be committed to the custody of the Chief of Police of
the City to be held by the Chief of Police in accordance with ordinances of the City providing for the custody of
prisoners convicted before said court; and said City shall be liable to the officers of the court to which the appeal
is taken for the costs due them when such defendant has fully discharged such fines and costs. Said Municipal
Court shall hold no terms and shall be at all times open for the transaction of business.
SECTION 80. APPEALS: APPELLATE PROCEDURE.
Appeals from judgments rendered by said Municipal Court shall be heard by the County Court of Hutchinson
County, and in all such appeals to said County Court the trial shall be de novo, the same as if the prosecution had
been originally commenced in that court. Said appeals shall be governed by the rules and practice for appeals
from the Justices' Courts to the County Court of the State, as far as the same may be applicable.
State law reference–Appeal procedures, bond, etc., Tex. Code Crim. Proc. art. 45.042 et seq.
SECTION 81. PRESENT MUNICIPAL COURT VALIDATED UNTIL ORGANIZATION
HEREUNDER.
Until the due and legal organization of the said court as herein provided for, the Municipal Court in said City as
now established shall continue to exercise its powers and jurisdiction.
SECTION 82. CITY ATTORNEY: QUALIFICATIONS, SALARY, POWERS AND DUTY.
The City Attorney shall be a regularly licensed and practicing attorney-at-law. The City Attorney shall receive
for services rendered such compensation as may be fixed by the Council, and shall hold the office until a
successor is appointed and qualified. The City Attorney shall represent the City in all litigation and
controversies, and it shall be the City Attorney's duty to approve in writing all proposed ordinances of the City
before they are adopted, or to file with the City Council in writing legal objections thereto. It shall be the City
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 17/430
Attorney's duty to draft or pass upon all proposed ordinances granting franchises of any kind, and in the event of
the City Attorney's disapproval of any such ordinance it shall be the duty of the City Attorney to file with the
City Council written legal objections thereto. It shall be the duty of the City Attorney to inspect and pass upon
all papers, documents, contracts and other instruments in which the City may be interested. The City Attorney
shall be the legal adviser of the Mayor, City Manager, of the superintendents of the different departments, and of
the City Council, or any committee thereof, and of all city officers and employees, with respect to any legal
question involving any official duty or any other matter pertaining to the affairs of the City of Borger. The City
Attorney shall perform such other duties as the City Council shall direct. Whenever it shall be brought to the
City Attorney's knowledge through the affidavit of ten credible persons or otherwise, that any person, firm or
corporation, exercising and enjoying any franchise or privilege from the City of Borger, has been guilty of a
breach of any condition of such franchise or privilege [or] has failed to comply in any material manner with the
terms and stipulations thereof, it shall be the duty of the City Attorney to report the same to the City Council,
together with all facts bearing upon the same which may be brought to his attention. If the City Council shall
determine that said complaints are well founded, it shall be its duty to take such action as may be necessary, and
to cause the City Attorney to carry out its instructions thereon; and in the event the offending corporation, person
or firm, shall fail or refuse to conform to the orders of the Council with respect thereto, it shall be the duty of the
Council to direct the City Attorney to institute suit in the Court having jurisdiction thereof against such
corporation, firm or person, for a judgment or forfeiture of such franchise or privilege, or any other judgment
proper under the premises. It shall be the duty of the City Attorney to see that all penal ordinances of the city are
impartially enforced. (Amended 1/23/45)
SECTION 83. ASSISTANT CITY ATTORNEY: HOW APPOINTED, QUALIFICATIONS, SALARY,
POWERS AND DUTIES.
The City Manager may appoint an Assistant City Attorney, if in the City Manager's judgment it is necessary to
the proper administration of the office of City Attorney; and the City Attorney and the Assistant City Attorney
shall have authority to administer oaths and affidavits. The qualifications of the Assistant City Attorney shall be
the same as those prescribed for City Attorney, and the Assistant City Attorney shall receive such compensations
as may be prescribed by the City Council. The Assistant City Attorney's duties shall be such as may be
prescribed by the City Council.
SECTION 84. CITY SECRETARY: QUALIFICATIONS, SALARY, POWERS AND DUTIES.
The City Secretary shall receive for services rendered such compensation as may be fixed by the Council. It
shall be the duty of the City Secretary to attend all meetings of the City Council and to keep accurate books
provided for that purpose; to preserve and keep in order all books, papers, documents, records and files of the
Council; to countersign all documents, papers and licenses authorized by the Council; to keep a record of all
such, and to countersign all warrants drawn by the Treasurer or other proper officer of the City. The City
Secretary shall perform such other and further duties as may be required either by law or by the City Council or
by ordinance or otherwise. The City Secretary shall have custody of all ordinances of the city and of all papers
and records of the City Council, and of the seal of the corporation, and shall affix the same to only such
documents and obligations of the city as the City Secretary may be legally authorized so to do. (Amended
1/23/45; Ordinance 1969-2, art. IX, 2/18/69, ratified 4/1/69)
SECTION 85. TAX ASSESSOR AND COLLECTOR; SALARY, BOND, POWER AND DUTIES.
The City Assessor and Collector shall receive for services rendered, such compensation as may be fixed by the
City Council. The City Assessor and Collector shall give bond in such amount as may be prescribed by the City
Council, with good and sufficient sureties, said bond to be payable to the Mayor and the Mayor's successors in
office. The Council may require a new bond of him at any time, if in its opinion the existing bond is insufficient,
and whenever such new bond is required, the City Assessor and Collector shall perform no official act until such
new bond shall be given and approved. The City Assessor and Collector shall assess or cause to be assessed all
taxable property in such manner and within such time as the Council may prescribe. The City Assessor and
Collector shall make duplicate assessment rolls, and on their completion and approval the City Assessor and
Collector shall deliver one copy to the City Manager and retain one for use in making collections. The City
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 18/430
Assessor and Collector shall cause property holders to render their property for taxation in the manner
prescribed by law and ordinance, and for this purpose the City Assessor and Collector is empowered to
administer oaths and affirmations. The City Assessor and Collector shall collect all taxes due the city, whether
the same be general, special, occupation, license or otherwise, and shall pay the same over to the City Treasurer
within six days of their collections, taking duplicate receipts therefor, one of which the City Assessor and
Collector shall retain, and the other the City Assessor and Collector shall turn over to the City Manager;
provided, however, the City Assessor and Collector shall not be entitled to keep on hand a sum exceeding
$1,000.00. The City Assessor and Collector shall monthly or oftener if required make a detailed report to the
City Council of all collections made by the City Assessor and Collector. The City Assessor and Collector shall
be vigilant and see that no business is carried on, unless the license or occupation tax due thereon shall have first
been paid. The City Assessor and Collector shall have such deputies as may be given by the Council. The Tax-
Assessor Collector and Board of Equalization shall comply with all state laws regulating tax assessing and
collecting. (Election of 4/7/84)
SECTION 86. RESERVED.
Editor's note–Section 86, pertaining to penalties for default of duty of the Tax Assessor and Collector, was repealed in the election of
April 7, 1984.
SECTION 87. DEPOSITORY.
The City Council shall designate a bank or banks in the City of Borger as the City Depository or depositories
which shall be selected for a period of two years, and the bank or banks in the City of Borger which shall offer,
in a bid, services of the greatest net value to the city shall be selected. The Council shall have the right to reject
any and all bids offered as City Depository. (Ordinance 1969-2, art. X, 2/18/69, ratified 4/1/69; election of
4/7/84)
State law reference–Depositories for municipal funds, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code, ch. 105.
SECTION 88. CHIEF OF POLICE; QUALIFICATIONS, SALARY, POWERS AND DUTIES, BOND.
The Chief of Police shall be the chief police officer of the City. The Chief of Police shall receive for services
such compensation as may be fixed by the Council. The Chief of Police shall either in person or by deputy
attend Municipal Court while in session, and upon request of the City Manager or the City Council, attend City
Council meetings while in session, and shall promptly and faithfully execute all writs and process issued to the
Chief of Police. The Chief of Police shall have like power with the Sheriff of the County to execute the writ of
search warrant. The Chief of Police shall be active in quieting riots, disorders and disturbances of the peace
within the limits of the City, and shall take into custody all persons so offending against the peace of the City,
and shall have the authority to take suitable and sufficient bail for the appearance before the Municipal Court of
any person charged with an offense against the ordinances or laws of the City or the State of Texas. It shall be
the duty of the Chief of Police to arrest without warrant all violations of the public peace, and all who obstruct or
interfere with the Chief of Police in the execution of the duties of that office, or who shall be guilty of any
disorderly conduct or disturbances whatever in the presence of the Chief of Police or upon complaint of any
citizen. To prevent a breach of the peace or preserve quiet and good order, the Chief of Police shall have the
authority to close any theater, drinking house or any other place or building of public resort; and in the
prosecution and suppression of crime and arrest of offenders the Chief of Police shall have, possess and exercise
like power, authority and jurisdiction as the Sheriff of the County, under the laws of the State. The Chief of
Police shall give a bond payable to the City of Borger in the sum of not less than $2,500.00 or such other greater
sum as the City Council may require by ordinance. The Chief of Police shall perform such other duties, and
possess such other powers, rights and authority as the Council may by ordinance require or confer. (Election of
4/7/84)
SECTION 89. RIGHT OF EMINENT DOMAIN.
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 19/430
Said city shall have the right of eminent domain and the power to appropriate private property for public
purposes whenever the governing authority deems it necessary; and to take any private property, within or
without the city limits, for any of the following purposes, to wit: City Halls, Fire Stations, Police Stations, Jails,
Calaboose, Fire Alarm Systems, Libraries, Hospitals, Sanitariums, Auditoriums, Market Houses, Reformatories,
Abattoirs, Streets, Avenues, Alleys, Parks, Highways, Playgrounds, Sewer Systems, Storm Sewers, Sewage
Disposal Plants, Filtering Beds and Emptying Grounds for Sewer Systems, Drainage, Water Supply Sources,
Wells, Water and Electric Light and Power Systems, Street Car Systems, Telephone and Telegraph Systems, Gas
Plants or Gas Systems, Cemeteries, Prison Farms, Pest Houses, and for any other municipal purpose that may be
deemed advisable. The power herein granted for the purpose of acquiring private property shall include the
power of improvement and enlargement of water works, including water supply, riparian rights, standpipes,
watersheds and the construction of supply reservoirs. In all cases wherein the city exercises the power of
eminent domain, it shall be controlled as nearly as practicable, by the laws governing the condemnation of
property by railroad corporation in the State; the City taking the position of the railroad corporation in such case.
The power of eminent domain hereby conferred shall include the right of the governing authority when so
expressed, to take the fee in the land so condemned, and such power and authority shall include the right to
condemn public property for such purposes.
State law references–Eminent domain, V.T.C.A., Property Code, ch. 21; municipal right of eminent domain, V.T.C.A., Local
Government Code, ch. 251.
SECTION 90. OWNERSHIP OF PUBLIC UTILITIES.
Said City shall have the power to buy, own or construct, and to maintain and operate within or without the city
limits, complete water system or systems, gas or electric lighting power plant or plants, telephone or telegraph
systems, street railways, sewer systems, sewage plants, fertilizing plants, abattoirs, municipal railway terminals,
or any other public service utility, and to demand and receive compensation for services furnished by the city for
private purposes or otherwise, and to have the power to regulate, by ordinance, the collection of compensation
for such services. Said city shall have the power to acquire by lease, purchase or condemnation, the property of
any person, firm or corporation now or hereafter conducting any such business, for the purpose of operating such
public utility or utilities and for the purpose of distributing such service within or without the city, or any portion
thereof.
State law references–Municipal home-rule powers to regulate public utilities and franchises using streets, etc., V.A.C.S., art. 1175;
municipal utilities, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code, sec. 402.001 et seq.; authority for municipal public services and utility systems
in home-rule municipalities, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code, sec. 402.002; municipal jurisdiction over electric utility, V.T.C.A.,
Utilities Code, ch. 33; municipal jurisdiction over water and sewer utility rates, operations and services, V.T.C.A., Water Code, sec.
13.042; municipal jurisdiction over rates, operations and services of gas utility, V.T.C.A., Utilities Code, ch. 103; Public Utility
Regulatory Act, V.T.C.A., Utilities Code, ch. 11 et seq.; miscellaneous powers and duties of utilities, V.T.C.A., Utilities Code, ch. 181.
SECTION 91. FUNDS FOR ACQUISITION OF ANY PUBLIC UTILITY: SECURITY FOR SAME,
ETC.
Should the City determine to acquire any public utility by purchase, condemnation or otherwise, as herein
provided, said city shall have the power to obtain funds for the purpose of acquiring said public utility and
paying the compensation therefor, by issuing bonds or notes, or other evidence of indebtedness and may secure
the same by fixing a lien upon the property constituting the public utility so acquired, and said security shall
apply alone to said property so acquired.
State law reference–Municipal home-rule powers to regulate public utilities and franchises using streets, etc., V.A.C.S., art. 1175.
SECTION 92. MANUFACTURE OR PURCHASE OF PUBLIC UTILITY PRODUCTS.
Said city shall have the authority to manufacture its own electricity, gas or anything else that may be needed or
used by it or the public; to make contract with any person, firm or corporation for the purchase of gas, water,
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 20/430
electricity or any other commodity or article used by it or the public, and to sell the same to the public as may be
determined by the governing authority.
State law reference–Authority for municipal public services and utility systems in home-rule municipalities, V.T.C.A., Local
Government Code, sec. 402.002.
SECTION 93. RESERVED.
Editor's note–Section 93, which pertained to the right to operate and maintain public utilities which had been acquired by the city and
to the exclusivity of the right to operate and maintain said utilities, was repealed June 1, 1935.
SECTION 94. RIGHT TO REGULATE CHARGES, ETC., OF HOLDER OF FRANCHISE OR
PRIVILEGE.
Said city shall have the power to determine, fix, and regulate charges, fares and rates of any person, firm or
corporation now exercising, or that may hereafter exercise, any right of franchise or public privilege in said city,
and to prescribe the kind of service to be furnished and the equipment to be used, and the manner in which the
service shall be rendered, and to change such regulations from time to time. In order to ascertain all of the facts
necessary for a proper understanding of what is or should be reasonable rate or regulation, the governing
authority shall have full power to inspect the books and other records of such persons, firms or corporations and
compel the attendance of witnesses for such purpose; providing that in adopting such regulations and in fixing or
changing such compensations, no stocks or bonds authorized or issued by any person, firm or corporation
exercising such franchise or privilege shall be considered, unless proof be made, that the same have been
actually issued by such person, firm or corporation for money, or its equivalent, paid and used for the purchase
and development of the property under investigation.
State law references–Franchise to use streets in municipality, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code, sec. 311.071 et seq.; authority to grant
franchise to use or occupy public grounds, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code, sec. 282.003; municipal home-rule powers to regulate
public utilities and franchises using streets, etc., V.A.C.S., art. 1175.
SECTION 95. STREET POWERS.
The powers, terms and provisions of an act passed by the First Called Session of the Fortieth Legislature of the
State of Texas and entitled:
“An Act to authorize incorporated cities, towns and villages incorporated under either general or
special law, including those operating under a special charter or amendments of charter adopted
pursuant to the Home Rule provisions of the constitution to cause to be improved streets, avenues,
alleys, highways, boulevards, drives, public places, squares, or any portion or portions thereof, and to
assess part of the cost thereof against abutting property and owners thereof, and against railroads,
street railroads or interurbans and owners thereof occupying, using or crossing streets, avenues,
alleys, highways, boulevards, drives, public places or squares improved, and to provide for the
enforcement and collection of such assessments and providing the powers, terms and provisions of
this Act shall not repeal any charter provision or law, general or special, but shall exist as alternative
powers, terms and provisions, and providing that any city which shall adopt or amend its own charter
under the Home Rule provisions of the Constitution may provide therein for any of the powers, terms
and provisions thereof, as part of, in lieu of, or as alternative to any charter provision, and providing
the necessary matters and things incidental to and necessary for the carrying out of the purposes of
this Act, and providing this Act shall not apply in any city, town or village not having more than one
thousand inhabitants, and declaring an emergency”,
are hereby embraced in and made a part of this charter, and the City of Borger and its governing body shall have,
possess and may exercise all of the terms, powers and provisions herein contained.
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 21/430
State law reference–Street improvements and assessments in cities having more than 1,000 inhabitants, V.T.C.A., Transportation
Code, ch. 313.
SECTION 96. CONSTRUCTION OF SIDEWALKS AND CURBS.
Said city shall have the power to provide for the construction and building of sidewalks and curbs and to charge
the entire cost of the construction of said sidewalks, including the curb, against the owner of the abutting
property and make a special charge against the owner for such cost, and to provide by special assessment, a lien
against such property for such cost.
State law reference–Assessment for construction of sidewalks and curbs, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code, sec. 311.093.
SECTION 97. IMPROVEMENT OF SIDEWALKS AND CURBS.
Said city shall have the power to provide for the construction, improvement or repair of any sidewalk or curb by
penal ordinance, and to declare defective sidewalks or curbs public nuisances.
State law reference–Authority over sidewalks, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code, sec. 311.004.
SECTION 98. FRANCHISES FOR USE OF STREETS.
Said city shall have the power and authority to grant franchises for the use and occupancy of streets, avenues,
alleys and any and all public grounds belonging to or under the control of the city. No telegraph, telephone,
electric light or power, street railway, interurban railway, steam railway, gas company, waterworks water
systems, or any other character of public utility, shall be granted any franchise or permitted the use of any street,
avenue, alley, highway, or grounds of the city without first making application to, and obtaining the consent of,
the governing authority thereto, expressed by ordinance and upon paying such compensation as may be
prescribed and upon such condition as may be provided for by such ordinance, and before such ordinance
proposing to make any grant or franchise or privilege to any applicant to use or occupy any street, avenue, alley,
or any other public ground belonging to or under the control of the city, shall become effective, publication of
said ordinance, as finally proposed to be passed, shall be made in a newspaper published in the City of Borger,
once a week for three (3) consecutive weeks; which publication shall be made at the expense of the applicant
desiring said grant and said proposed ordinance shall not be thereafter changed unless republished as in the first
instance, nor shall any such ordinance take effect or become a law or contract or vest any rights in the applicant
therefor, until after the expiration of thirty days from the last publication of said ordinance as aforesaid.
Pending the time such ordinance may become effective it is hereby made the duty of the governing authority of
the city to order an election if requested so to do by written petition, signed by at least ten (10) percent of the
legally qualified voters, as determined by the number of votes cast in the last regular municipal election, at
which election the qualified voters of said city shall vote for or against the proposed grant, as set forth in detail
by the ordinance conferring the right and privileges upon the applicant therefor. Such election shall be ordered
not less than thirty (30) days nor more than ninety (90) days from the date of filing said petition, and if at said
election the majority of the votes cast shall be for the granting of such franchise or privilege, said ordinance and
the making of said proposed grant shall thereupon become effective, but if a majority of the votes cast at said
election shall be against granting of such franchise or privilege such ordinance shall be ineffective and the
making of such proposed grant be null and void.
No franchise shall ever be granted by the City Council other than an indeterminate franchise or a franchise for a
period of years not exceeding twenty, except in cases where an election is held, as above provided, to determine
whether or not a franchise shall be granted, and no franchise granted as the result of any election shall ever be
for a period of time exceeding forty years.
State law references–Franchise to use streets in municipality, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code, sec. 311.071 et seq.; authority to grant
franchise to use or occupy public grounds, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code, sec. 282.003; municipal home-rule powers to regulate
public utilities and franchises using streets, etc., V.A.C.S., art. 1175.
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 22/430
SECTION 99. PUBLIC WORKS IMPROVEMENTS.
Said city shall have the power to open, extend, straighten or widen any public street, avenue or alley and for
such purpose to acquire the necessary land by purchase or condemnation, and to provide that the cost of
improving any such street, avenue or alley by opening, extending, straightening or widening the same shall be
paid for by the owner of the property lying in the territory of such improvement and which is specially benefited
thereby and to provide that the cost shall be charged by special assessment against such owner and made a lien
against the owner's said property for the amount due by the owner. Three (3) Special Commissioners shall be
appointed by the County Judge of Hutchinson County, Texas, for the purpose of condemning said land and
apportioning said cost, and such apportionment shall be specially assessed by the governing authority of said
city against the owners and their property lying in the territory so found by said Special Commissioners to be
specially benefited in enhanced value, and said city may issue assignable certificates for the payment of any
such cost against such property owner and the owner's property and may provide for the payment thereof in
deferred payments, which deferred payments shall bear interest at the rate not exceeding eight (8) percent per
annum. Said city shall pay such proportion of such cost as may be determined by said Special Commissioners to
be due by it; provided the cost to be paid by the city shall never exceed one-third (1/3) of the cost of such
improvements. (Election of 4/7/84)
State law references–Street improvements and assessments in cities having more than 1,000 inhabitants, V.T.C.A., Transportation
Code, ch. 313; authority of municipality over and under public highways, streets and alleys, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code, sec.
311.001; assessment for street improvements, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code, sec. 311.091; assessment of costs of improvements on
abutting properties, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code, sec. 313.041 et seq.
SECTION 100. ALTERING STREETS, OBSTRUCTIONS, ENCROACHMENTS, ETC.
Said city shall have the power to control, regulate and remove all obstructions, encroachments and
encumbrances on any public street, avenue, or alley and to narrow, alter, widen, straighten, vacate, abandon, and
close same, to provide for sprinkling and cleaning same, and to regulate and control the moving of buildings,
and structures of every kind and character upon and along same.
State law references–Municipal regulation of obstructions on streets, etc., V.T.C.A., Transportation Code, ch. 311; authority of homerule
municipality to regulate movement of building on streets, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code, sec. 311.005; closing of street or alley,
V.T.C.A., Transportation Code, sec. 311.007.
SECTION 101. PARKS, PLAYGROUNDS, ETC.
Said city shall have exclusive control over all city parks and municipal playgrounds and the right to control,
regulate and remove all obstructions and prevent all encroachments thereupon; and to provide for raising,
grading, filling, terracing, landscape gardening, erecting buildings, providing amusements therein, for
establishing walks and paving driveways around, in and through said parks, playgrounds and other public
grounds.
SECTION 102. CITIES, TOWNS AND VILLAGES: ASSESSMENTS FOR STREET WIDENING
AND OPENING PAYABLE [IN] INSTALLMENTS.
The powers, terms and provisions of an act passed by the Regular Session of the Fortieth Legislature of the State
of Texas and entitled:
“An Act to amend Chapter 17, Title 28; cities, towns and villages, Article 1213 of the Revised Civil
Statutes of Texas of 1925, so that the assessments for street widening and street opening may be
made payable in not exceeding sixteen annual payments, and declaring an emergency”,
are hereby embraced and made a part of this charter and the City of Borger and its governing body shall have,
possess and may exercise all of the terms, powers, and provisions therein contained.
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 23/430
State law reference–Assessment for highway improvements, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code, secs. 314.046 and 314.049.
SECTION 102-A. CITY ZONING LAW: AUTHORIZING CITIES AND INCORPORATED
VILLAGES TO PASS ZONING REGULATIONS.
The powers, terms and provisions of an Act passed by the Regular Session of the Fortieth Legislature of the
State of Texas entitled:
“An Act enabling cities and incorporated villages to pass zoning regulations, granting full power to
said cities and incorporated villages, providing for the creation of districts, declaring purposes in
view, providing for the method of procedure, providing for certain changes, providing for a
commission, providing for a board of adjustment, providing for its powers and duties, providing
certain methods of enforcement and remedies, providing certain exemptions, providing the method to
be followed in case of conflict with other laws, providing for the validity for all parts of the law not
declared unconstitutional, and declaring an emergency”,
are hereby embraced in and made a part of this charter and the City of Borger and its governing body shall have,
possess and may exercise all of the terms, powers and provisions therein contained.
State law reference–Municipal zoning authority, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code, ch. 211.
SECTION 103. TAXATION.
The City shall have the power and is hereby authorized annually, to levy and collect taxes at a rate of not to
exceed Two Dollars and Fifty Cents ($2.50) on the One Hundred Dollars ($100.00) of the assessed valuation of
all real and personal property within the City Limits, not exempt from taxation by the Constitution and laws of
the State. (Election of 4/7/84)
State law references–Texas Property Tax Code supersedes municipal charter, V.T.C.A., Tax Code, sec. 1.02; tax liens and personal
liability, V.T.C.A., Tax Code, ch. 32; property taxes authorized, V.T.C.A., Tax Code, sec. 302.001; tax collection powers, V.T.C.A, Tax
Code, sec. 302.102.
SECTION 104. LICENSE TAX.
The City shall authorize the granting and issuing of licenses and shall direct the manner of issuing and
registering the same and fix the fees thereof but no license shall be issued for a longer period than one (1) year,
and shall not be assignable except by permission of the governing authorities of the city.
State law reference–Occupation taxes, V.T.C.A., Tax Code, sec. 302.101.
SECTION 105. FRANCHISE TAX.
The City shall have the power, annually, to levy and collect a franchise tax against any person, firm or
corporation using and occupying the public streets, alleys or grounds of the City separately from the tangible
property of such person, firm or corporation, and to levy and collect same annually upon the property of all such
persons, firms or corporations as the same are now and may be assessed under the State Laws, and thereunder
and shall have full power to enforce the collection of such taxes.
SECTION 106. REGULATE ASSESSMENTS.
The City shall have the power to regulate the manner and mode of making out tax lists, inventories and
appraisement of property therein, and to prescribe the oath that shall be administered to each person rendering
property for taxation and to prescribe how, when, where property shall be rendered and to prescribe the number
of, and forms of assessment, rolls and to adopt such measures as may be deemed advisable to secure the
assessment of all properties within the City Limits and to collect taxes thereon and may provide a fine and
penalty upon all persons failing, neglecting or refusing to render their property for taxation, and to do all things
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 24/430
necessary or proper to render effectual the collection of money by taxation, and provide methods of enforcing
same by attachment, sequestration or otherwise.
SECTION 107. UNRENDERED PROPERTY.
The City shall have power to provide for the rendition and assessment of unrendered property for taxation and
levy and assess taxes thereon, annually and to provide for the rendition, levy, and assessment of taxes for
previous years on property omitted from taxation, and to provide interest at the rate of six (6) percent per annum
for such unrendered or omitted property and to change and provide correction and assessment of property
erroneously assessed.
SECTION 108. TIME [OF] TAX LEVY.
All real, personal or mixed property held, owned or situated in the City of Borger shall be liable for all municipal
taxes, due by the owner thereof, including taxes on real estate, franchises, personal and mixed property. Such
municipal taxes are hereby declared to be a lien, charge and incumbrance upon the property so taxed and shall be
a prior lien to all other claims, sales assignments, transfers, gifts and judicial writs. Said lien, shall exist on the
first day of January of each year until all such taxes have been paid and against any real estate which, for any
cause has failed to be assessed for one or more years, and such lien shall be good and effective for every year for
which assessments have failed. Personal property of all persons, firms or corporations owing any taxes to the
City of Borger, is hereby made liable for all of such taxes, whether the same be upon personal or real property or
upon both. The governing authority of the City, at its first meeting in June of each year or as soon thereafter as
practicable shall levy the annual tax for each year, but special taxes or assessments allowed by this Charter may
be levied, assessed and collected at such time as the governing authorities may provide; provided that should the
governing authorities fail or neglect to levy the annual tax herein provided for any one year the annual tax levy
for the preceding year last made by said governing authority shall and will be considered in force and effective
as the tax levy for the year for which no annual tax levy was made.
SECTION 109. COLLECTION [OF] TAX.
The said City shall have full power to provide for the collection, by suit or otherwise, [of] taxes assessed, levied
and imposed, and is hereby authorized, and to that end shall have full power and authority to sell, or cause to be
sold all kinds of property, real and personal as provided herein, or by the revised Statutes of this State, and shall
make such rules and regulations and enact all such ordinances as are deemed necessary for the collection of any
taxes provided in this Charter.
It shall not be necessary in any action, suit or proceeding in which the City shall be a party, for any bond,
undertaking or security to be executed in the behalf of the City.
The City shall have the power to control and manage the finances of the City; to provide its fiscal year and fiscal
arrangements.
State law reference–Imposition of penalty for collection of delinquent taxes, V.T.C.A., Tax Code, secs. 33.01, 33.07, 33.08.
SECTION 110. DIFFERENT FUNDS.
All money arising from the collection of taxes by the City shall be divided into funds and designated as “General
Fund”, “Interest and Sinking Fund”, and “Hotel/Motel Room Occupancy Tax Fund”, and such other funds as
may be authorized by ordinance of the City Council.
No irregularities in the time and manner of making or returning the City Assessment Rolls or the approval of
such Rolls shall invalidate any assessment.
(Election of 4/7/84)
