ARTICLE 3.08 MOVING AND DEMOLITION OF BUILDINGS*
Sec. 3.08.001 Permits required for moving buildings
(a) It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to move any building into, within, or out of the city
limits without first filing with the city a bond as required herein and making application for and obtaining a
moving permit and a foundation permit for each separate building and any other permits that may be required to
ensure compliance with the code.
(b) A foundation permit shall not be required when a building is to be moved out of the city limits.
Sec. 3.08.002 Insurance requirements for persons moving buildings
(a) Any person, firm or corporation engaged in the business of moving buildings, structures or houses into or
within the corporate limits of the city shall execute and deliver to the planning and zoning department proof of
general liability insurance in the amount of $300,000.00 for the use and benefit of the city, the property owner or
any person injured or damaged by any act or neglect of the principal or his agents or employees, or by reasons of
failure to repair any damages, defective work, device or installation, or for failure to remedy any defects,
damages or faulty workmanship or material within the time prescribed by a city inspector for the completion of
such remedial work without additional cost to the individual for whom the work or moving was done and
guaranteeing compliance with the requirements of this code, of all work done by the principal, his agents or
employees. Suspension or revocation of a permit of the principal shall not affect the liability of the principal or
the insurance underwriter. Said insurance shall further save, indemnify and keep harmless the city against all
judgments, costs and expenses which may in any way accrue against the city in consequence of the granting of a
permit.
(b) No permit for the moving or relocation of any building shall be issued until the certificate of insurance has
been filed with the city as required herein.
Sec. 3.08.003 General requirements for moving buildings; issuance of moving permit
(a) Buildings or structures moved into or within the city shall comply with the provisions of this code.
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 112/430
(b) Any person, firm or corporation desiring to move a building into or within the city limits shall make
application for a moving permit on the forms provided to the planning and zoning department. A moving permit
may be issued when the following have been complied with:
(1) That an inspection of the building to be moved within or into the city has been made by the
building inspector to determine if the building complies with the building, plumbing, electrical and
other applicable codes of the city and that the inspector's report is on file with the city and a copy has
been received by the owner. The inspector's report shall specify the repairs and/or changes if any
which must be accomplished in order for the building to be in compliance with city codes. Any
permits required for such repairs and/or changes shall be obtained prior to the issuance of a moving
permit and such repairs shall be completed within 180 days of the date of issuance of the moving
permit. An inspection of the building shall not be required for buildings being moved out of the city.
(A) Any building, structure or portion thereof if determined to be substandard as defined in
this code shall not be moved within or into the city.
(B) A moving permit may be issued for an existing building or structure to be moved within
or into the city provided such building or structure was constructed in conformance with the
city building code in effect at the time of construction and the electrical wiring, plumbing and
mechanical equipment was installed in conformance with all applicable ordinances or codes in
effect at the time of installation and the structure, electrical wiring, plumbing, and mechanical
equipment have been maintained in good condition and are being used in a safe manner.
(2) That the lot is described by a plat of record as required by this code, that a site plan has been
filed with the city, showing the proposed location of the building on the lot, property lines, streets,
alleys, setbacks, and the location of any existing buildings on the lot, and that the building and
proposed occupancy comply with the zoning regulations of the district in which the building is to be
located.
(3) That a foundation permit has been issued and such foundation has been inspected and is
complete and ready for the building to be moved within or into the city.
(Ordinance O-003-14 adopted 4/1/14)
(4) A cash bond as listed in article 5.000 is required to insure lot cleanup and the removal of the
foundation off of the lot from which the building is to be moved. The cash bond will be refunded
when the lot has been cleared, all excavations and low areas have been filled with approved material,
the sewer line has been plugged, and the other utilities disconnected to the satisfaction of the building
inspector. A cash bond will not be required for buildings being moved into the city limits. (Ordinance
O-008-18 adopted 9/18/18)
(5) That the proper permits have been obtained from the state department of transportation and that
the proposed route for moving the building has been approved by the appropriate city official. No
building or portion thereof shall be moved from one site to another or through the city along any
public way within the city if such moving requires the removal or moving of a traffic signal mast
arm.
(6) That any person, firm or corporation desiring to move into the city limits a building or structure
of new construction containing more than 120 square feet shall comply with subsection (b)(1) of this
section prior to the issuance of a moving permit. in lieu of an inspection as required in subsection (b)
(1), a letter from the building inspector of the city where the building was constructed certifying that
the building was constructed in compliance with that city's building ordinances, or a letter from a
registered professional architect or engineer certifying that the building complies with the provisions
of a recognized building code, plumbing and mechanical code, and electrical code, will be accepted.
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 113/430
(Ordinance O-003-14 adopted 4/1/14)
Sec. 3.08.004 Permit and inspection fees for moving buildings
Before any permit shall be issued under the provisions of this article, the applicant therefor shall pay all associated fees as
listed in article 5.000. (Ordinance O-008-18 adopted 9/18/18)
Sec. 3.08.005 Demolition of buildings
(a) Permit required; standards for work. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to demolish
any building or structure or cause the same to be demolished within the city without first making application for
and obtaining a demolition permit from the planning and zoning department and complying with the following:
(1) Provide protection for adjoining property and pedestrians in compliance with the provisions of
the International Building Code and request approval of the protection provided from the building
inspector prior to beginning any demolition work. The building inspector may require additional or
lesser protection depending upon the circumstances or the degree of hazard to adjoining properties or
pedestrians.
(2) All utilities shall be disconnected by the utility companies prior to the issuance of the
demolition permit with the exception of the sewer lateral which shall be plugged as directed by the
building inspector after the building has been demolished.
(Ordinance O-003-14 adopted 4/1/14)
(3) A cash bond as listed in article 5.000 is required to insure lot cleanup and the removal of the
foundation off of the lot. The cash bond will be refunded when the lot has been cleared, all
excavations and low areas have been filled with approved material and the lot will drain properly.
(Ordinance O-008-18 adopted 9/18/18)
(b) Permit fee; expiration of permit. No fee shall be required for a demolition permit; however, each permit
shall expire within 90 days from the date of issuance and all demolition and lot cleanup shall be completed by
the expiration date. The building inspector may grant an extension of not more than 30 days when weather
conditions or other circumstances in the opinion of the inspector justify the granting of an extension.
(c) Forfeiture of bond. Failure to comply with the provisions of this section within ten days of a written notice
to the permittee by the building inspector shall result in the cash bond being forfeited and used to complete the
demolition and lot cleanup.

ARTICLE 3.11 SUBSTANDARD BUILDINGS*
Sec. 3.11.001 Definitions
As used in this article, the following terms shall have the meanings given below:
Building. Any structure, either temporary or permanent, having a roof or other covering, that is designed or used
for the shelter or enclosure of any person, animal, or property of any kind, including tents, awnings, or vehicles
situated on private property and used for purposes of a building.
Building inspector. The building official and the building inspector designated to inspect buildings or
construction or designated to enforce the provisions of this article.
Dangerous building, unsafe building or unfit dwelling. Any structure or building located within the incorporated
limits of the city that is:
(1) In such a state or condition of repair or disrepair that all or any of the following conditions
exist:
(A) Walls or other vertical structural members list, lean, or buckle;
(B) Damage or deterioration exists to the extent that the building is unsafe;
(C) Loads on floors or roofs are improperly distributed or the floors or roofs are of
insufficient strength to be reasonably safe for the purposes used;
(D) Damage by fire, wind, or other cause has rendered the building or structure dangerous to
life, safety, morals or the general health and welfare of the occupants or the people of the city;
(E) The building or structure is so dilapidated, substandard, decayed, unsafe, unsanitary or
otherwise lacking in the amenities essential to decent living or use that the same is unfit for
human habitation or occupancy or is likely to cause sickness, disease or injury or otherwise to
constitute a detriment to the health, morals, safety or general welfare of those persons
assembled, working, or living therein or is a hazard to the public health, safety and welfare;
(F) Light, air, and sanitation facilities are inadequate to protect the health, morals, safety, or
general welfare of persons who assemble, work, or live therein;
(G) Stairways, fire escapes, and other facilities of egress in case of fire or panic are
inadequate;
(H) Parts or appendages of the building or structure are so attached that they are likely to fall
and injure persons or property;
(2) Dilapidated, substandard, or unfit for human habitation and a hazard to the public health,
safety, and welfare of the city's residents;
(3) Regardless of its structural condition, unoccupied by its owners, lessees, or other invitees and is
unsecured from unauthorized entry to the extent that it could be entered or used by vagrants or other
uninvited persons as a place of harborage or could be entered or used by children; or
(4) Boarded up, fenced or otherwise secured in any manner if:
(A) The building constitutes a danger to the public even though secured from entry; or
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 124/430
(B) The means used to secure the building are inadequate to prevent unauthorized entry or
use of the building to the extent it could be entered or used by vagrants or other uninvited
persons as a place of harborage or could be entered or used by children.
Demolish. To tear down the building or structure and remove all building materials and debris from the property
leaving the property in a clean and sanitary condition so as to receive the approval of the building official.
Dwelling. The entirety or any portion of any building that is not an apartment house or lodging house, and that
contains one or more dwelling units or guest rooms that are used, intended, or designed to be built, used, rented,
leased, let, or hired out to be occupied, or which are occupied, for living purposes.
Dwelling unit. A single unit providing complete, independent living facilities for one or more persons including
permanent provisions for living, sleeping, eating, cooking, and sanitation.
Occupant. Any person who rents, leases or appears to reside in, rent or lease a building, structure or property
through custody of the premises or who has the legal right to possession of such premises.
Owner. Any person who holds any interest in the legal title of a building, structure or property or who has the
legal right of possession thereof.
Person. An individual human, partnership, copartnership, firm, company, limited liability partnership or other
partnership or other such company, joint venture, joint stock company, trust, estate, governmental entity,
association or corporation or any other legal entity, or their legal representatives, agents or assigns.
Repair. The reconstruction, renovation, or renewal of any part of an existing building for the purpose of its
maintenance. This term shall not apply to any change or construction, alteration, or additions to a building other
than for the purpose of reconstruction, renovation, or renewal.
Responsible party. The owner or occupant, including the person in custody of the building, property or structure
and any mortgagee or lienholder.
(Ordinance adopting Code)
Sec. 3.11.002 Violations; penalty
(a) The responsible parties for any unsafe building, unfit dwelling or dangerous building who shall fail to
comply with any notice or order to repair, vacate or demolish said building or structure, such notice or order
given by the authority of the board of appeals or the city council, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor.
(b) Any responsible party in possession of any unsafe building, unfit dwelling or dangerous building who fails
to comply with any notice or order to vacate such building and fails to repair such building in accordance with
an order given by the board of appeals or the city council shall be guilty of a misdemeanor.
(c) Any person removing a posted notice of any unsafe building, unfit dwelling or dangerous building from
any building that is posted pursuant to posting notice requirements of this article shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor.
(d) The violation of any provision of this article shall be unlawful and a misdemeanor offense punishable by a
fine as provided in section 1.01.009 of this code. Each day a violation of this article continues shall constitute a
separate offense.
(Ordinance adopting Code)
Sec. 3.11.003 Prima facie evidence of responsibility for violation
