(Ordinance O-010-03, sec. 154.20, adopted 6/3/03)
Sec. 3.13.062 Standards for placement and appearance of manufactured homes
(a) Purpose. The purpose of this section is to set forth standards for the placement and architectural
appearance of manufactured housing within the city. The intent of this section is to insure that manufactured
housing is compatible with other dwellings in residential neighborhoods and meets minimum placement and
architectural standards while providing an alternative means of affordable house ownership for the residents of
the city.
(b) Site requirements. Each manufactured home placed on an individual lot shall meet the following
requirements:
(1) For specific use permit approval, a manufactured home shall have a minimum width of
fourteen (14) feet measured at any point perpendicular to the length of the manufactured home
located on a twenty-five-foot lot.
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 150/430
(2) A manufactured home is allowed in a manufactured home zoned district and a specific use
permit is required for the installation of a manufactured home in the estate/agricultural, singlefamily-
1, single-family-2, general residential and commercial zoned districts of the city. A
manufactured home shall not be located in the central business, retail, neighborhood service, planned
development, light industrial, or heavy industrial zoned districts of the city.
(3) A manufactured home square footage shall be comparable to that of existing housing units in
the immediate residential neighborhood or subdivision.
(4) The main roof of the manufactured home shall not be less than 3:12 pitch, with eaves
projecting not less than six (6) inches, and be of asphalt shingle or metal.
(5) A manufactured home shall be permanently attached or affixed to a permanent foundation
system. The permanent foundation system shall be as follows:
(A) A continuous concrete slab with a minimum thickness of four (4) inches.
(B) A below-grade continuous concrete beam shall be an integral part of the slab placed
under the perimeter of the unit, and under those portions of the chassis that bear the structural
load of the housing unit, and under those portions of the chassis that bear the structural load of
the unit. The minimum beam dimensions shall be 10" wide and 12" high or as designed and
sealed by a registered professional engineer. Concrete support piers from the slab foundation to
the chassis shall be installed according to the installation manual for the unit or as required by
the state.
(C) State-approved tie-down anchors shall be installed in the continuous concrete beam.
(D) The distance between finished grade and the bottom of the exterior walls shall not exceed
thirty (30) inches.
(6) A manufactured home shall have all towing equipment, i.e., tongue, axle, wheels, lighting or
other such conditions which are not an integral part of the structure, removed before the housing is
permanently attached or affixed.
(7) The housing unit shall have a covered entry or dormer on any entry visible from a public street
or right-of-way.
(8) Proof of HUD-code inspected manufactured home shall be submitted prior to installation or
issuance of a specific use permit.
(9) A manufactured home shall have a habitability inspection performed and certificate of
occupancy issued prior to the connection of permanent utilities.
Note: Development standards such as setbacks, lot size, and off-street parking requirements set forth by the city
subdivision ordinance shall be enforced. Nonconforming mobile homes or manufactured homes removed from a
site may only be replaced with a manufactured home that complies with this article.
(Ordinance O-010-03, sec. 154.19, adopted 6/3/03)
Sec. 3.13.063 Location and licensing
(a) Permitted locations. Manufactured home parks and recreational vehicle parks may be located in any zoned
district of the city permitted by the zoning ordinance schedule of uses located elsewhere in this code.
(b) Licensing and fee requirements. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any manufactured home
park or recreational vehicle park within the city limits unless the person possesses a valid license issued the
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 151/430
current year by the building official. All applications for a license shall be made in writing on forms provided by
the building official, who shall issue a license when compliance with this article has been achieved.
(1) Application for original license. Application for an original license shall be in writing, signed
by the applicant as to the truth of the application and by deposit of the license fee, and shall contain:
(A) Name and address of applicant;
(B) Location and legal description of the park;
(C) Plot plan of the park showing all spaces of manufactured homes or recreational vehicles,
structures, roads, walkways and other service and utility facilities.
Before an original license is issued, the building official shall inspect the park for compliance
with the provisions of this article.
(2) Application for renewal. Application for renewal of a license shall be made in writing by the
licensee on forms provided by the building official, on or before October 1 of each year. The
application will contain any change in the information submitted on the original license.
(Ordinance O-010-03, sec. 154.21, adopted 6/3/03)
(3) License fee. All original license applications or renewals shall be accompanied by a fee as
listed in article 5.000 for each manufactured home or recreational vehicle space in the park.
(Ordinance O-008-18 adopted 9/18/18)
(4) Licenses not transferable. Licenses issued under the provisions of this section shall not be
transferred. A new license will be issued to any new owner upon compliance with the provisions of
this article.
(5) Notice of violation; suspension of license. Whenever, upon inspection of any manufactured
home park or recreational vehicle park, the building official finds that conditions or practices exist
which are in violation of applicable provisions of this article, he shall give notice to the licensee.
Such notice shall (1) be in writing; (2) include a statement of the reason for such notice; (3) allow a
reasonable time for the performance of the act it requires; (4) be served on the licensee or his agent
either by personal service or mail to the last known address, or when notified by any method
authorized or required by state law; and (5) contain an outline of remedial action which, if taken, will
effect compliance with the provisions of this article. Unless such conditions or practices are corrected
within a reasonable period of time, the building official shall immediately suspend the license, and
give notice in writing of such suspension. The licensee shall cease operation of such park, except as
provided in subsection (6).
(6) Appeals. Any person affected by any notice issued in connection with the enforcement of any
provision of this section by the building official may request and be granted a hearing before the
building standards commission, provided such person affected by the decision of the building official
files a written request within fifteen (15) days after the notice was served to the secretary of the
building standards commission requesting such hearing and setting forth a brief statement of the
grounds therefor. Upon receipt of the request, the secretary of the building standards commission
shall set a time and place for such hearing and give the petitioner written notice thereof. The filing of
the request for a public hearing shall act as a stay of notice and of suspension. Should the petitioner
be aggrieved by the decision of the building standards commission, then a request for a public
hearing before the city council may be requested for their consideration and final decision. The
petitioner shall be given written notice of the time and place of such hearing. The petitioner shall be
given an opportunity to be heard and show cause as to why the decision of the building standards
commission should not be modified or withdrawn.
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 152/430
(Ordinance O-010-03, sec. 154.21, adopted 6/3/03)
Sec. 3.13.064 Inspections
(a) The building official or code enforcement official is hereby authorized and directed to make such
inspections as are necessary to determine compliance with this article and other applicable ordinances. Such
officials shall have the power to enter at reasonable times upon any public or private property for the purpose of
inspecting and investigating conditions relating to the enforcement of this article and for maintenance of utilities,
provided that either permission of the owner or occupant has been obtained, or if such owner or occupant refuses
or cannot be located after due diligence, that probable cause exists to believe that a violation of this article has
occurred and a search warrant has been obtained from the judge of the municipal court, based upon an affidavit
as to the facts of probable cause.
(b) It shall be the duty of every occupant of a manufactured home or recreational vehicle in a park to give the
owner or his agent or authorized employee access to any part of such park at reasonable times for the purpose of
making such repairs or alterations as are necessary to effect compliance with this article.
(Ordinance O-010-03, sec. 154.21.1, adopted 6/3/03)
Sec. 3.13.065 Responsibilities of park management and park occupants
(a) The responsibilities of the manufactured home park and recreational vehicle park management shall be as
follows:
(1) The park owner or agent shall operate the manufactured home park or recreational park in
compliance with this article and other applicable ordinances and shall provide adequate supervision
to maintain the park, its facilities and equipment in good repair and in a clean and sanitary condition.
(2) The park owner or agent shall notify each and every park occupant of all applicable provisions
of this article and inform them of their duties and responsibilities hereunder.
(3) The park owner or agent shall maintain a register of the park occupancy which shall contain the
following information:
(A) Name and space number of occupant;
(B) Make, model and license number of all recreational vehicles;
(C) Location of each manufactured home and recreational vehicle within the park by space
number.
(b) The responsibilities of manufactured home and recreational vehicle occupants shall be as follows:
(1) The park occupants shall comply with the requirements of this article and shall maintain the
space and its facilities and equipment in good repair and in a clean, sanitary condition.
(2) The park occupant shall be responsible for proper placement of the manufactured home or
recreational vehicle on its space and proper installation of all utility connections in accordance with
all applicable building, plumbing, mechanical and electrical codes.
(3) Skirting, porches, awnings and other additions, when installed, shall be maintained in good
repair. The use of space immediately under the manufactured home or recreational vehicle for storage
shall be permitted only under the following conditions:
(A) The storage area shall have a base of impervious material.
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 153/430
(B) Stored items shall not interfere with the inspections of the manufactured home or
recreational vehicle nor be a fire hazard.
(Ordinance O-010-03, sec. 154.21.2, adopted 6/3/03)
Sec. 3.13.066 Development standards
Any development, redevelopment, alteration or expansion of a manufactured home park or recreational vehicle
park within the city limits shall be done in compliance with the following minimum requirements:
(1) Location. A manufactured home park or recreational vehicle park shall be located only in a
designated zoning area as provided and defined in the zoning ordinance of the city.
(2) Screening. A manufactured home park or recreational vehicle park shall be visually screened
from any immediately adjacent EA, GR, IF-1, IF-2, CB or any residential zoned PD zoned district.
The screening device shall be constructed and maintained not less than six (6) feet in height.
(3) Soil and ground cover. Exposed ground surfaces in all parts of every manufactured home park
or recreational vehicle park shall be paved, covered with stone or other solid material, or protected
with vegetation that is capable of preventing soil erosion and eliminating dust.
(4) Drainage. The ground surface in all parts of the manufactured home park or recreational
vehicle park shall be graded and equipped to drain all surface water in a safe, efficient manner. Each
space shall be graded to ensure the proper drainage of water from the space. The adequacy of
drainage facilities shall be certified by a state-licensed professional engineer.
(5) Additional development standards.

park
(6) Access and traffic circulation and parking.
(A) Internal street, no parking area signs and street name signs shall be privately owned, built
and maintained. Streets shall be designed for safe and convenient access to all spaces and to
facilitate for common use of park residents.
(B) Emergency vehicles shall have access to all areas of the manufactured home park or
recreational vehicle park.
(C) All traffic-control signage along internal streets of the manufactured home park or
recreational vehicle park shall conform to the state manual on uniform traffic-control devices
and be approved by the city traffic engineering prior to installation or placement.
(D) The primary vehicle entrance to a manufactured home park or recreational vehicle park
and the off-street parking area required adjacent to the office building and public facilities shall
be paved.
(E) All other internal streets and off-street parking spaces at the manufactured home park or
recreational vehicle park shall be designed and maintained to support the imposed loads of
emergency vehicles. Manufactured homes, plus towing vehicles, and recreational vehicles, shall
be provided with a surface so as to provide all-weather driving capabilities. Streets and parking
spaces shall be maintained free of cracks, holes and other hazards.
(7) Street dimensions and parking.
(A) An internal street shall be provided to each manufactured home or recreational vehicle
space. Such internal street shall have a minimum width of twenty (20) feet when parking is not
allowed on both sides of the street, twenty-eight (28) feet when parking is allowed on one (1)
side of the street only, and thirty-two (32) feet when parking is allowed on both sides of the
street. This dimension does not include standard stand-up curb. Internal streets shall be
continuous and connect with other internal streets or with public streets, or shall be provided
with a cul-de-sac having a minimum radius capable of handling the largest emergency vehicle
of the city. No internal street ending in a cul-de-sac shall exceed four hundred (400) feet in
length.
(B) Off-street parking spaces shall be located so as to not interfere with access to parking
areas provided for other manufactured homes or recreational vehicle spaces and for public
parking provided in the manufactured home park or recreational vehicle park.
(C) Internal streets shall permit unobstructed access a minimum of twenty (20) feet in width
to within one hundred fifty (150) feet of any portion of each manufactured home, recreational
vehicle, building and storage area.
(D) Within each manufactured home park or recreational vehicle park all streets shall be
named and manufactured home park spaces numbered to conform with block numbers on
adjacent streets. Street name signs and manufactured home numbers shall be of reflective type.
The signs and numbers shall be of standard size and placement to facilitate location by
emergency vehicles.
(E) Internal streets shall intersect adjoining public streets at approximately ninety (90)
degrees and at locations which will eliminate or minimize interference with traffic on those
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 156/430
public streets.
(8) Area lighting. Area lighting shall be approved by the traffic engineer.
(9) Semipublic phone. A minimum of one (1) semipublic telephone shall be provided in an easily
accessible location twenty-four (24) hours a day seven (7) days a week.
(10) Recreation area. All manufactured home parks shall have at least one (1) recreation area
located as to be free of traffic hazards, accessible to all park residents and centrally located.
(A) Extent. Recreation areas and facilities such as playgrounds, swimming pools and
community buildings shall be provided which will meet the anticipated needs of the clientele
the manufactured home park is designed to serve.
(B) Size. Not less than eight (8) percent of the manufactured home park area shall be
dedicated to recreational facilities. This does not include vehicle parking, commercial,
maintenance and utility areas.
(C) Playground location. When playground area is provided it shall be designed to be
protected from traffic, thoroughfares and parking areas. It shall be in a central location to
provide accessibility to all residents of the manufactured home park. Such playground area shall
be maintained in a sanitary and safe condition.
(11) Utility services and distribution. Water, sewer, natural gas and electrical utility services to a
manufactured home park or recreational vehicle park, the means of distribution of those utilities
within the park, the utility connections at each space, and the provision of utilities to and within
buildings and other structures shall comply with applicable state and city standards, regulations and
construction codes.
(12) Buildings and other structures. New or existing buildings and other structures in a
manufactured home park or recreational vehicle park shall comply with construction codes.
(13) Recreational and cooking fires located outside of buildings. No open fires shall be permitted
except in facilities approved by the fire marshal. No open fire shall be left unattended. No fuel shall
be used which emits dense smoke or objectionable odor. Cooking shelters, barbecue pits, woodburning
stoves and incinerators shall be located, constructed, maintained and used in compliance with
local construction codes to minimize fire hazard and smoke nuisance on the property on which used
and on neighboring property.
(14) Storage and handling of liquefied petroleum gases. In parks where LPG is stored or dispensed,
the handling and storage of such gases shall comply with the requirements of the fire code and the
state railroad commission regulations.
(15) Refuse and garbage handling. All refuse and garbage handling shall conform to requirements
as specified elsewhere in this code.
(16) Skirting of manufactured homes. All manufactured homes shall be skirted as required in
section 3.13.031.
(17) Unoccupied, abandoned or unsafe manufactured homes and recreational vehicles.
Unoccupied, abandoned or unsafe manufactured homes or recreational vehicles located in a
manufactured home park or recreational vehicle park may be abated by the city as specified
elsewhere in this code.
(Ordinance O-010-03, sec. 154.22, adopted 6/3/03)
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 157/430
Sec. 3.13.067 Applicability
(a) Except as hereinafter provided in subsection (b) of this section, the provisions of this article shall apply to
all manufactured home parks and recreational vehicle parks established or created subsequent to the effective
date of this section (ordinance adopted July 3, 2003). Any reconstruction, alteration, extension or expansion of
any manufactured home park or recreational vehicle park shall be in full compliance with all provisions of this
article.
(b) Except as set forth in subsection (a) above, the provisions of sections 3.13.063 and 3.13.066 shall not
apply to manufactured home parks and recreational vehicle parks in existence upon the effective date of this
section (ordinance adopted July 3, 2003).
(Ordinance O-010-03, sec. 154.23, adopted 6/3/03)
ARTICLE 3.14 SIGNS*
Sec. 3.14.001 Scope; conflicts with state law
The provisions of this article shall apply to all signs, as that term is defined herein, within the corporate limits of
the city and the established ETJ (extraterritorial jurisdiction). The city elects to exercise its authority to regulate
outdoor advertising signs located in the ETJ of the city as provided by Texas Local Government Code section
216.902 as the same may hereafter be amended. Therefore, new advertising signs shall be prohibited in the ETJ
of the city except as provided herein. This law is subject to Tex. Local Gov. Code, chapter 216, entitled
“Regulation of signs by municipalities.” Any conflict between provisions of this article and chapter 216 shall be
resolved in favor of chapter 216 and its amendments. All signs that are electrically operated or contain one or
more electrical components must obtain an additional permit as required by the city electrical code. (Ordinance
O-001-08 adopted 2/5/08)
Sec. 3.14.002 Definitions
Certain terms are defined for the purpose of this article as follows:
Abandoned sign. A sign which no longer identifies or advertises a bona fide business, lessor, service, owner,
product, or activity, and/or for which no legal owner can be found.
Advertising. To convey information, to seek the attraction of or to direct the attention of the public to any
location, event, person, activity, goods, services or merchandise.
Animated sign. A sign which uses movement or change of lighting to depict action or to create a special effect or
scene (compare “flashing sign”).
Awning. A shelter projecting from and supported by the exterior wall of a building constructed of nonrigid
materials on a supporting framework (compare “marquee”).
Awning sign. A sign painted on, printed on or attached flat against the surface of an awning.
Banner sign. A sign made of fabric or any nonrigid material with no enclosing framework.
Bench sign. Any sign affixed or painted in any manner to a bench.
Billboard. See “off-premises sign.”
Building. Any structure that encloses a space used for sheltering an occupancy. Each portion of a building
separated from other portions by a firewall shall be considered as a separate building.
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 158/430
Building official. The officer or other designated authority or their duly authorized representative, charged with
the administration and enforcement of this article.
Cabinet. A four-sided compartment that houses the other components of a sign.
Changeable copy sign (automatic). A sign on which the copy changes automatically on a lamp bank or through
mechanical means, e.g., electrical or electronic time and temperature units.
Changeable copy sign (manual). A sign on which copy is changed manually in the field, e.g., reader boards with
changeable letters.
Clearance (of a sign). The smallest vertical distance between the grade of the adjacent street or street curb and
the lowest point of a sign, including framework and embellishments, extending over the grade.
Construction sign. A temporary sign identifying an architect, engineer, contractor, subcontractor, and/or material
supplier participating in construction on the property on which the sign is located.
Copy. The wording on a sign surface in either permanent or removable letter form.
Curbline. An imaginary line drawn along and parallel to the outermost part or back of the curb and gutter on
either side of a public street; or, if there is no curb and gutter, along and parallel to the outermost portion of the
paved street; or, if there is no paved street, along and parallel to the outermost edge of the traveled portion of the
street.
Directional information sign. An on-premises sign giving directions, instructions, or facility information and
which may contain the name or logo of an establishment but no advertising copy, e.g., parking and exit or
entrance signs.
(1998 Code, sec. 156.02)
District. Any section of the city for which the regulations governing the use of land and the use, density, bulk,
height and coverage of buildings and other structures are uniform for each class or kind of building therein.
(1998 Code, sec. 156.02; Ordinance adopting Code)
Double-faced sign. A sign with two faces.
Electrical sign. A sign or sign structure in which electrical wiring, connections, or fixtures are used.
Facade. The entire building front including the parapet.
Face of sign. The area of a sign on which the copy is placed.
Festoons. A string of ribbons, tinsel, small flags, or pinwheels.
Flashing sign. A sign which contains an intermittent or sequential flashing light source used primarily to attract
attention. Does not include changeable copy signs, animated signs, or signs which, through reflection or other
means, create an illusion of flashing or intermittent light (compare “animated sign” or “changeable copy sign”).
Freestanding sign. A sign supported upon the ground by poles or braces and not attached to any building.
Frontage. The length of the property line of any one premises along a public right-of-way on which it borders.
Frontage (building). The length of an outside building wall along or on a public right-of-way.
Government sign. Any temporary or permanent sign erected and maintained by the city, county, state, or federal
government for traffic direction or for designation of or direction to any school, hospital, historical site, or public
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 159/430
service, property, or facility.
Height (of sign). The vertical distance measured from the highest point of the sign, excluding decorative
embellishments, to the grade of the adjacent street or the surface grade beneath the sign, whichever is less
(compare “clearance”).
Home occupation. Any occupation or activity conducted within a dwelling unit which is clearly incidental and
subordinate to the use of the premises for the dwelling purposes (see chapter 14).
Illegal sign. A sign which does not meet the requirements of this code and/or applicable state laws.
Illuminated sign. A sign with an artificial light source incorporated internally or externally for the purpose of
illuminating the sign.
Incidental sign. A small sign, emblem, or decal informing the public of goods, facilities, or services available on
the premises, e.g., a credit card sign or a sign indicating hours of business and not exceeding two square feet.
Any sign located within the confines of a project which is not legible from any public right-of-way.
Lot. A parcel of land legally defined on a subdivision map recorded with the appraisal district, or a parcel of land
defined by a legal record or survey map.
Maintenance. For the purposes of this article, the cleaning, painting, repair, or replacement of defective parts of
a sign in a manner that does not alter the basic copy, design, or structure of the sign.
Marquee. A permanent canopy, awning, or roof-like structure of rigid materials supported by and extending
from the facade of a building. A marquee is considered to be part of the building.
Marquee sign. Any sign attached to or supported by a marquee structure.
Nameplate. A nonelectric, on-premises identification sign giving only the name, address, and/or occupation of
an occupant or group of occupants.
(1998 Code, sec. 156.02)
Nonconforming signs. Signs legally existing at the adoption date of Ordinance O-001-08, but which do not
conform to the provisions of this article. (Ordinance O-001-08 adopted 2/5/08)
Occupancy. The portion of a building or premises owned, leased, rented, or otherwise occupied for a given use.
Office, retail, central business district. Names of city zoning districts; refer to zoning map for location of
districts.
Off-premises sign. A sign advertising an establishment, merchandise, service, or entertainment, which is not
sold, produced, manufactured, or furnished at the property on which the sign is located, e.g., billboards or
outdoor advertising.
On-premises sign. A sign which pertains to the use of the premises on which it is located.
Owner. A person recorded as such on official records or the on-premises person in control of the premises. For
the purposes of this article, the owner of property on which a sign is located is presumed to be the owner of the
sign unless facts to the contrary are officially recorded or otherwise brought to the attention of the building
official, e.g., a sign leased from a sign company.
Painted wall sign. Any sign which is applied with paint or similar substance on the face of a wall.
Parapet. The extension of a false front or wall above a roofline.
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 160/430
Pennant. A triangular shaped or other shaped ribbon or device which is greater than one inch in length and used
either singularly or in groups on a line or pole for advertising purposes or for attracting the attention of the
public.
Person. For the purposes of this article, any individual, corporation, association, firm, partnership, or similarly
defined interest.
Political sign. For the purposes of this article, a temporary sign used in connection with a local, state, or national
election or referendum.
Portable sign. Any sign designed or constructed to be easily moved from one location to another and not
permanently affixed to the ground or to a structure or building, including signs mounted upon or designed to be
mounted upon a trailer, bench, wheeled carrier, or other nonmotorized mobile structure. A portable sign which
has its wheels removed shall still be considered a portable sign hereunder. For the purpose of this article, trailer
signs and signs on benches are portable signs.
Projecting sign. A sign, other than a flat wall sign, which is attached to and projects from a building wall or
other structure not specifically designed to support the sign.
(1998 Code, sec. 156.02)
Public right-of-way (public street). That land dedicated for public use commonly as a street, roadway, alley,
bridge, or thoroughfare, and most often extends the entire width between property lines of any roadway, street,
alley, bridge, or other similar thoroughfare, not privately owned or controlled, when any part thereof is open to
the public for vehicular traffic. (Ordinance O-001-08 adopted 2/5/08)
Real estate sign. A temporary sign advertising the real estate upon which the sign is located as being for rent,
lease, or sale.
Roofline. The top edge of a roof or building parapet, whichever is higher, excluding any cupolas, pylons,
chimneys, or minor projections.
Roof sign. Any sign erected over or on the roof of a building (compare “wall sign”).
Rotating sign. A sign in which the sign itself or any portion of the sign moves in a revolving or similar manner.
Such motion does not refer to methods of changing copy.
Searchlight. An apparatus containing a strong light source and reflector for projecting a bright beam of light,
usually truck or trailer mounted.
Shopping center. See “strip center.”
Sign. Includes but is not limited to any device, structure, fixture, or placard using graphics, symbols, and/or
written copy designed specifically for the purpose of advertising or identifying any person, persons, political
party, event, establishment, product, goods, or services.
Sign, area of.
(1) Projecting and freestanding signs. The area of the sign shall be measured as follows if the sign
is composed of one or two individual cabinets:
(A) The area around and enclosing the perimeter of each cabinet or module shall be summed
and then totaled to determine total area. The perimeter measurable area shall not include
embellishments such as framing, decorative roofing, and the like, provided that there is not
written advertising copy on such embellishments.
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 161/430
(B) If the sign is composed of more than two sign cabinets or modules, the area enclosing the
entire perimeter of all cabinets and/or modules within a single, continuous geometric figure
shall be the area of the sign.
(C) Only one face of a double-faced sign will be used to figure the total square footage.
(2) Wall signs. The area shall be within a single, continuous perimeter composed of any straight
line geometric figure which encloses the extreme limits of the advertising message. If the sign is
composed of individual letters or symbols using the wall as the background with no added
decoration, the total sign area shall be calculated by measuring the area within the perimeter of each
symbol or letter. The combined area of the individual figures shall be considered the total sign area.
Snipe sign. A temporary sign or poster affixed to a tree, fence, pole, and the like.
Strip center. A building plot developed or ultimately to be developed with three or more stores, shops, or
commercial enterprises, and which has shared parking facilities or spaces.
Subdivision identification sign. A freestanding or wall sign identifying a recognized subdivision, condominium
complex, or residential development.
Temporary sign. Any sign constructed of cloth, canvas, light fabric, cardboard, wallboard, plastic, metal, or other
light materials, not to exceed six square feet in size and not intended for long-term use. A portable sign shall not
be considered a temporary sign.
Under-canopy sign. A sign suspended underneath a canopy, ceiling, roof, or marquee.
Use. The purpose for which a building, lot, sign, or structure is intended, designed, occupied, or maintained.
Wall sign. A sign attached parallel to and extending not more than 12 inches in front of the wall of a building.
This definition includes painted, individual letter, and cabinet signs, and signs on a mansard.
Window sign. A sign installed inside a window and intended to be viewed from the outside. Such sign shall be
made of wood, paper, paint, or vinyl and not illuminated.
(1998 Code, sec. 156.02)
Sec. 3.14.003 Penalty; appeals
Any violation of city sign regulations will constitute an offense punishable by a fine as provided in section
1.01.009 of this code. Appeals of decisions by the building official concerning signs shall be directed to the
zoning board of adjustment or the planning and zoning commission, depending on the nature of the appeal.
Sec. 3.14.004 Compliance with article
It shall hereafter be unlawful for any person to erect, place, or maintain a sign in the city or its extraterritorial
jurisdiction except in accordance with the provisions of this article.
Sec. 3.14.005 Compliance with zoning ordinance
(a) All signs and sign structures erected, installed, or constructed and the location thereof shall comply with
the provisions of the city zoning code, chapter 14 of this code.
(b) Any sign with an overall height of twenty-five (25) feet or more shall have plans sealed by an architect or
engineer licensed to practice in this state.

https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 162/430
(c) Any roof sign with an overall height of twenty (20) feet or more from the top of the sign to the roof below
shall have plans sealed by an architect or engineer licensed to practice in this state.
(Ordinance O-001-08 adopted 2/5/08)
Sec. 3.14.006 Signs prohibited in all districts
The following signs are prohibited in all districts:
(1) Abandoned signs.
(2) Banners, except as allowed in retail, central business, and commercial zoned districts.
(3) Signs imitating or resembling official traffic signs, signals, or devices.
(4) Snipe signs or signs attached to trees, utility poles, public benches, or streetlights.
(5) Signs placed on vehicles or trailers which are parked or located for the primary purpose of
displaying the sign.
(6) Signs on public right-of-way:
(1998 Code, sec. 156.16; Ordinance adopting Code)
(A) With the passage of this article (on April 7, 2001), it shall be unlawful to place a sign
upon a public street, public sidewalk, public alley, public park, public bridge or part of same,
utility pole, or on any public building belonging to the city unless express consent therefor shall
have been first granted by the city council. (Ordinance O-001-08 adopted 2/5/08)
(B) Any unlawful sign found within a public right-of-way of a public street, sidewalk, or
alley shall be seized and the removal thereof is hereby authorized. The building official,
employees of the police department, the department of public works, and the department of
transportation are hereby authorized to impound any signs found on a public street, public
sidewalk, or public alley and transport or cause the same to be transported to a location
designated by the building official for storage. The building official shall maintain records of
where such signs were located when they were so impounded and shall hold the same in storage
for a period of not more than 30 days. Any sign so held may be redeemed by the owner thereof
upon the payment of a fee to the city through the building official, consisting of a total of $25
for hauling the sign to storage plus $5 per day storage fee for each day the sign is stored. Such
fee shall be in addition to and not in lieu of any fine imposed upon such owner for violation of
this article.
(7) Lighted signs where not properly shielded to prevent glare at any portion of the traveled
roadway and are of such brilliance as to impair the visibility of motor vehicle operators and such
lighting projects onto other private or public property as to create a nuisance.
(8) Pennants, searchlights, and festoons.
(1998 Code, sec. 156.16; Ordinance adopting Code)
Sec. 3.14.007 Insurance requirements
(a) No person shall erect, construct, reconstruct, install, paint, or replace any sign for which a permit is
required within the corporate limits of the city or its extraterritorial jurisdiction until such person has presented
proof of insurance as required by city ordinance.
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 163/430
(b) Proof of general liability insurance in the amount of $300,000.00 must be filed with the office of planning
and zoning and made conditional for the erection of signs in accordance with the ordinances of the city and the
laws of this state. The insurance is to provide for the compensation of the city for any and all damages or
liabilities that may occur to or against the city by reason of the erection, maintenance, demolition, repair,
removal, defects in, or collapse of any sign erected by or under the direction of any such person. The insurance
is to further provide for the compensation of any person who, while upon public property of the city, incurs
damages for which the person erecting such signs is legally liable by reason of the erection, maintenance,
demolition, repair, removal, defects in, or collapse of any such sign. Such insurance shall be valid for one year
from the date of issuance.
(c) Insurance is not required for the following:
(Ordinance O-001-08 adopted 2/5/08)
(1) A property owner or business owner may obtain a permit for a sign which he or she proposes to
construct or install on property under his or her control.
(2) Attaching to a structure letters or numbers the dimensions of which do not exceed 24 inches.
(3) Placement of any painted or poster wall sign.
(1998 Code, sec. 156.17)
Sec. 3.14.008 Permit required; exceptions; electrical permit
(a) Before any sign is erected, constructed, reconstructed, installed, painted or replaced, a permit for the sign
must be obtained. Sign permits are issued by the office of planning and zoning of the city. Permits are not
required for the following:
(1) Any sign being repainted where the painting constitutes the only alteration to the sign.
(2) Any singular wall sign, not exceeding five square feet in area and not projecting more than six
inches from the wall of the building.
(3) Real estate development signs not exceeding 32 square feet per side.
(4) (A) All signs erected by the municipal, state, or federal government for the purpose of
public instruction, street or highway designation, control of traffic and similar uses relating to
the public interest.
(B) All signs for public protection of a warning, directive, or instructional nature, not
exceeding 30 square feet of surface display area, erected by a public utility or transportation
organization which operates under a franchise from the city permitting the use of public
property for the display of such signs.
(5) Political signs not exceeding 32 square feet of surface display area.
(6) The replacement of plastic face signs or panels or other materials containing the same
advertising message where the original or identical frame is used and the frame size is not altered and
substructure is not altered or moved.
(7) The replacement of bulbs that illuminated the sign where the original or identical frame is used
and the frame size is not altered and the substructure is not altered or moved.
(8) A sign located on private property which displays a warning, instructions, or directions not
exceeding 32 square feet of surface display area on each side and on which no other form of business
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 164/430
promotion or advertising appears.
(9) Portable signs of less than 12 square feet.
(10) Portable signs displaying personal messages and on site for no longer than three days.
(11) Signs which are mounted on the face of a building no higher than the roofline or which form
an integral part of a canopy or marquee entrance and state only the street number.
(12) Window signs.
(13) Balloons or gas-filled objects may be used for display or advertising for special events;
maximum height to be 35 feet. One use allowed for three days maximum time per premises per 30-
day period.
(14) Handheld signs or signs, symbols, or displays on persons.
(15) Signs not visible from any public street.
(1998 Code, sec. 156.18)
(b) The changing of an off-premises sign to an on-premises sign by a change in the copy, except for messages
advertising the sign for sale or lease, or the changing of an on-premises sign to an off-premises sign shall require
a permit and shall fully comply with this article. In either event, nonconforming status will be terminated.
(Ordinance O-001-08 adopted 2/5/08)
(c) A sign permit may be obtained from the office of planning and zoning at city hall or by telephone. It shall
be the permittee's duty to ascertain that the proposed sign meets all requirements of this code. A separate
electrical permit shall be obtained for electrical service to a sign as required by this code and shall comply with
the most recent edition of the National Electrical Code as adopted by the city. (1998 Code, sec. 156.18)
(d) The building official shall have the power to revoke permits at any time for failure by the permittee to
comply with any provision of this article. In such cases, all work on such sign shall immediately cease, save and
except that necessary to remove that portion of the sign or sign structure erected at the time of such revocation.
(Ordinance O-001-08 adopted 2/5/08)
Sec. 3.14.009 Permit fees
Before any permit shall be issued under the provisions of this article, the applicant therefor shall pay all associated fees as
listed in article 5.000. (Ordinance O-008-18 adopted 9/18/18)
Sec. 3.14.010 Inspection; maintenance; and nonconforming
(a) Any person who erects or installs a sign shall notify the building official and request a sign location
inspection. When the sign work is completed, the person shall require a final inspection from the building
inspector. Where an electrical sign is erected or constructed, an inspection by the electrical inspector shall be
made.
(b) Any person occupying a location with a sign will be subject to the same duties and responsibilities as the
owner of the location on which the sign is located, with respect to keeping the site clean, sanitary, inoffensive,
and free and clear of all debris, trash, junk, or other noxious substances. All signs, together with all necessary
supports, braces, guy wires, and anchors, must be kept in repair.
(c) Any sign, support, or appurtenances sustaining damage to the extent of 40% of the sign display area,
support, or appurtenances will be immediately removed or repaired.
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 165/430
(1998 Code, sec. 156.20)
(d) A nonconforming sign existing as of the effective date of Ordinance O-001-08 that violates this article or
any other ordinance, and a sign that comes under the jurisdiction of this article due to expansion of the city is a
legal nonconforming sign and may be continued, repaired, and maintained in good condition, but may not be
otherwise altered.
(e) Except as permitted for specific types of signs, voluntary removal of a nonconforming sign for purposes
other than maintenance terminates nonconforming rights for the sign.
(f) Any sign existing as of the effective date of Ordinance O-001-08 that violates a spacing or location
restriction in section 3.14.011, is a legal nonconforming sign and may be continued, repaired, and maintained in
good condition, but may not be otherwise altered. A nonconforming sign will have its nonconforming status
terminated if the sign, or a substantial part of it, is blown down or otherwise destroyed, or dismantled for any
purpose other than routine maintenance or for changing of the copy or advertising message on the sign. For
purposes of this subsection, a sign is considered to have been destroyed if the cost of repairing the sign is more
than sixty (60) percent of the cost of erecting a new sign of the same type, material, and dimensions at the same
location.
Sec. 3.14.011 Location; height limit; construction standards; abandoned signs
(a) No sign shall be erected in any public right-of-way, alley, or easement and signs shall comply with
projection and clearance requirements as set forth in the most recently adopted sign code. No temporary signs,
banners, and the like shall be placed across a public right-of-way without prior consent of the city council. Such
temporary signs, banners, and the like shall have a minimum clearance of sixteen (16) feet, six (6) inches above
the public right-of-way. Projecting signs, marquees, awnings, and the like shall have a minimum clearance above
a public street or public sidewalk of eight feet and project no closer than two feet of the curb; or, if there is no
curb and gutter, along and parallel to the outermost portion of the paved street.
(b) Freestanding on-premises or off-premises signs are hereby restricted to fifty (50) feet height in zoning
districts where such signs are allowed.
(c) New freestanding off-premises signs are to be of metal monopole design and are restricted to a maximum
sign face area of three hundred seventy-eight (378) square feet per side. A maximum of two sign faces, front and
back, are permitted. Multiple sign faces, whether stacked or side-by-side, at the same location and facing the
same direction are prohibited. Existing signs with more than two faces may continue as nonconforming signs,
subject to the provisions of section 3.14.010.
(d) No freestanding off-premises advertising sign, regardless of direction, shall be located within three
hundred (300) feet of any property line of any public park, or playground or within three hundred (300) feet of
any property line of property on which a public school or church is located.
(e) No freestanding off-premises advertising sign shall be located within seven hundred (700) feet as
measured along the right-of-way to any other freestanding off-premises advertising sign, or permitted location,
regardless of which direction the sign is facing, and regardless of which side of the street the sign is located.
(f) No illuminated freestanding off-premises advertising sign shall be located within three hundred (300) feet
of the zoning line of any residential zoned district.
(g) No freestanding off-premises advertising sign shall be located within one hundred fifty (150) feet of the
zoning line of any residential zoned district.
(h) With the passage of Ordinance O-001-08 (on February 5, 2008), it shall be unlawful to place a bench sign
in the corporate city limits or within the extraterritorial jurisdiction of the city.
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 166/430
(Ordinance O-001-08 adopted 2/5/08)
(i) Portable signs shall comply with the requirements of the zoning code for the zoning district in which they
are located. In addition to the zoning requirements, no portable sign over 12 square feet in area shall be located
within 50 feet of another portable sign over 12 square feet in area.
(j) No portable sign, regardless of size, shall be located in such a manner that the sign creates a sight
obstruction on any public street, intersection, or public/private driveway.
(k) All portable signs shall be securely anchored to the ground to resist movement or overturning from wind
or other forces.
(l) The source of electrical power for any portable sign shall be an approved electrical outlet with ground fault
protection located not more than six feet from the sign. Power cords or extension cords shall be of sufficient size
to provide safe electrical power to the sign. No power cords or extension cords shall be laid across or over
pedestrian or vehicular pathways.
(m) Portable signs shall display the sign owner's name and address. The information shall be permanently
affixed or painted on the frame of the portable sign facing the street and be maintained in a legible manner as
long as the sign remains on the site. The characters shall be block style, no smaller than one inch in height, and
be legible without removing any portion of the sign.
(1998 Code, sec. 156.21)
(n) Any portable sign without the proper identification shall be presumed to be abandoned and may be
removed by the building official. Any portable sign so removed, if unclaimed by the identified owner shall be
responsible for the cost of removing the sign, along with any storage fees assessed. Any portable sign so
removed shall be sold at public auction, if unclaimed, and the cost of removal and storage fees shall be charged
against the proceeds of the sale. (1998 Code, sec. 156.21; Ordinance adopting Code)
(o) All electric signs and outline lighting shall comply with the National Electrical Code and ordinances of the
city. If the electrical inspector suspects or has reasonable belief that the electric sign or outline lighting
constitutes a hazard to the safety of life or property, the inspector shall require the sign or outline lighting
installation be revised to meet the minimum standards established by the electrical code. The inspector shall
notify the owner of the sign, or person controlling operation of the sign, of a specific time to revise the electrical
installation of the sign. If the required revisions are not made within the specified time as established by the
electrical inspector, the sign shall be disconnected from the power source. Failure to comply with such a
disconnect order shall constitute a violation of this article.
(p) Any electrical installation of an electric sign and outline lighting shall be performed by a licensed
electrician. All new electric signs or outline lighting shall require a separate electrical permit, inspection, and
approval by the city electrical inspector.
(1998 Code, sec. 156.21)
Sec. 3.14.012 Code adopted
From and after the effective date of this article (ordinance adopted April 7, 2001), the Uniform Sign Code, 1997
edition, published by the International Conference of Building Officials, regulating the erection, construction,
design, quality of materials, location, electrification and maintenance of all signs and sign structures not located
within a building in the city, is hereby adopted by reference as though set out completely in detail. A copy of the
Uniform Sign Code shall be filed with the city secretary, such copy to be open to public inspection during
normal business hours. (1998 Code, sec. 156.22)

ARTICLE 3.15 STREETS AND SIDEWALKS*
Division 1. Generally
Secs. 3.15.001–3.15.030 Reserved
Division 2. Curbs†
Sec. 3.15.031 Handicap ramps required
(a) Section 228 of the Highway Safety Act of 1973, being 23 USC 402(b)(1)(D), was amended to read as
follows:
(D) Provide adequate and reasonable access for the safe and convenient movement of individuals
with disabilities, including those in wheelchairs, across curbs constructed or replaced on or after July
1, 1976, at all pedestrian crosswalks throughout the state.
(1998 Code, sec. 96.15; Ordinance adopting Code)
(b) Pursuant to that act, and to be in accord with both federal and state guidelines for the installation of
handicapped access ramps, the city sets forth the following requirements:
(1) Curbs constructed after June 30, 1976, with accompanying sidewalks shall have curb ramps
(depressions in the sidewalks and curb to accommodate a wheelchair user).
(2) Curbs constructed after June 30, 1976, without accompanying sidewalks will not require curb
ramps, but ramps will be required if sidewalks are added later.
(3) Curbs constructed prior to June 30, 1976, are not required to have ramps even though
sidewalks are constructed after June 30, 1976. However, should a curb constructed before June 30,
1976, require altering after June 30, 1976, to fit new construction, then curb ramps shall be installed.
(4) If a property owner or his representative chooses to extend or install a driveway curb across the
sidewalk, the walk shall be ramped.
(c) A permit shall be obtained for removal of a curb for the installation of handicapped access ramps as
required in section 3.15.032(a). New commercial buildings or developments shall be required to install
handicapped access ramps. Ramps shall be installed according to construction details furnished by the building
inspector's office.
(1998 Code, sec. 96.15)
Sec. 3.15.032 Permits for curb removal
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 168/430
(a) Permit required. It shall be unlawful for any person to remove any curb from a street located in the city
without obtaining a permit from the building inspector.
(b) Application for permit. Any person desiring to remove a portion of curb on a public street shall make
application to the building inspector's office for a permit. The purpose for the curb removal, the location and
length of the proposed curb removal, and such other information as may be determined necessary by the
building inspector for enforcement of this division shall be indicated on the permit. If adequate access to the
property exists or the proposed driveway would increase the hazard, or result in a hazard, to the safe movement
of traffic, the building inspector has the authority to prohibit the removal of a curb in a requested location for a
driveway. If the driveway is part of new construction, the driveway permit may be considered as part of the
building permit.
(1998 Code, sec. 96.16)
(c) Bond required. A permit shall not be issued for the removal of any curbing until the property owner or
contractor making application for a permit has executed a performance or cash bond in favor of the city to insure
compliance with the requirements of this division. The amount of the bond shall be as listed in article 5.000.
After the provisions of this division have been complied with and so authorized by the building inspector, the
performance or cash bond shall be returned to the property owner or contractor. (Ordinance O-008-18 adopted
9/18/18)
Sec. 3.15.033 Removal generally
The removal of any curb pursuant to the provisions of this division shall be done in such a manner as prescribed
by the building inspector. Damage to the curb greater than that necessary to prepare it for the desired opening
shall not be permitted. Such damaged curb shall be replaced to the satisfaction of the building inspector. Failure
to comply with the above shall be deemed a violation of this code. (1998 Code, sec. 96.17)
Sec. 3.15.034 Removal at intersection or turn
It shall be unlawful to remove any portion of a curb at any point on a radius of an intersection or turn, except for
the authorized replacement thereof or the installation of ramps to provide access for physically handicapped
persons, for which a permit has been obtained as required in section 3.15.032(a). (1998 Code, sec. 96.18)
Sec. 3.15.035 Notice prior to slab installation
The property owner or contractor shall notify the building inspector of the proposed pouring of concrete
immediately prior thereto whereby such inspector may determine that the provisions of this division are being
complied with. (1998 Code, sec. 96.19)
Sec. 3.15.036 Slab installation at curb removals
The area between the curbline and property line of the adjacent property shall be concreted the width which such
curb is removed. The minimum distance shall be ten feet. The concrete installed shall be elevated to curb height
at a point between the property line and the curbline with a sloping decrease in the direction of the street from
which the curb was removed and such concrete area shall have a curb on both sides thereof to prevent side
drainage. Sidewalks shall be ramped where the driveway curb is extended across the walk such that it will
provide safe movement of the physically handicapped. Care shall be taken to assure a uniform grade on the ramp
with no short grade changes. The concrete shall be 2500 psi concrete and reinforced with six-inch by six-inch
no. 10 welded wire mesh. Residential driveways shall have a minimum thickness of six inches at the back of the
curb, a minimum thickness of four inches at the property line and shall be placed on well-compacted soil.
Commercial driveways shall have a minimum thickness of six inches. Curb removal for residential driveways
shall be limited to a maximum of 30 feet per opening with a minimum distance along the curb between openings
on each lot of 20 feet. Curb removal for commercial driveways shall be limited to a maximum of 45 feet with a
minimum distance along the curb between openings of 25 feet. (1998 Code, sec. 96.20)
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 169/430
Sec. 3.15.037 Permits and slab installation for curb leave-outs and lay-down type curb openings
In areas where curb and gutter are to be installed by subdividers, developers, contractors, or whomever, the
owner or such person, firm, or corporation desiring curb leave-outs or lay-down type curb openings for
driveways on adjacent property shall be required to install a concrete slab extending from the back of the curb to
the adjacent property line. Before such leave-outs or lay-down type curbs shall be permitted, the owner or such
person, firm or corporation desiring such shall make application for a permit to the building inspector (section
3.15.032(b)) and shall deposit with the city a surety bond or certified check in an amount sufficient to cover the
cost of the installation of the concrete slab, conditioned that applicant shall, within six months from issuance of
permit, or if applicable within six months of completion of the curb adjacent to the property, complete the
installation of the concrete slab to the property line, otherwise to be forfeited as provided herein. The amount of
the surety bond or certified check shall be determined by the building inspector of the city. (1998 Code, sec.
96.21)
Sec. 3.15.038 Time limits for slab installation
Installation of the concrete slab as described in section 3.15.036 or 3.15.037 shall be completed within six
months from the date of the curb permit or the date the curb and gutter installation is complete adjacent to the
property for which the leave-out or lay-down type curb is provided. Failure to complete the installation of the
concrete slab in the specified time shall result in the forfeiture of the surety bond or certified check and the
driveway installation shall be accomplished by the city, using city personnel or the hiring of a contractor. (1998
Code, sec. 96.22)
Sec. 3.15.039 Obstruction or alteration of gutter restricted
(a) Generally. It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct, elevate, diminish or change the elevation of a
gutter line of any street.
(b) Exception. The flow line of a gutter may be changed upon written authorization from the responsible city
official or city manager after submission of evidence that such change would improve or not diminish the flow
characteristics of the gutter.
(1998 Code, sec. 96.23)
Sec. 3.15.040 Angle parking after curb removal restricted
The provisions of this division shall not be construed to authorize angle parking where a curb is removed in
compliance with this division. (1998 Code, sec. 96.24)
Sec. 3.15.041 Conflicts with state transportation commission regulations
In the event provisions of this division are in conflict with the regulations of the state transportation commission,
insofar as they govern and control removal of curbs on state highways, the provisions of the state transportation
commission shall be controlling. (1998 Code, sec. 96.25)
Secs. 3.15.042–3.15.070 Reserved
Division 3. Vegetation Bordering Streets
Sec. 3.15.071 Definitions
For the purpose of this division, the following definition shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or
requires a different meaning:
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 170/430
Street gutter flow line. The street gutter flow line of the curb adjacent to and bordering upon each such restricted
area; in the event there is no such curb, the height restrictions set forth in this division shall be based upon the
actual level of the paved or used portion of the public street adjacent to and bordering upon each such restricted
area.
(1998 Code, sec. 96.35)
Sec. 3.15.072 Restricted areas
(a) The areas in the city restricted by the provisions of this division are as follows:
(1) All of that portion of land lying within a triangular-shaped area on each street corner within the
city described by metes and bounds as follows: Beginning at the precise corner of the intersection
point of the curbs of each of the two streets forming each corner and extending 20 feet along each
such curbline from said curb intersection point, the third side being determined by the drawing of a
straight line from the ends of such 20-foot extensions; whether said land be privately owned or
unpaved or untraveled street right-of-way property.
(2) Where no curbs are in existence at such street intersections, said 20-foot lines shall coincide
with the central flow line of the ditches paralleling such uncurbed streets as shall be determined by
the city engineer.
(b) Provided, however, that the provisions of this division shall apply only to those areas of the city designated
and classified by the city's zoning ordinance requiring construction of lots in zoned sections to be set back from
the property line of each such lot.
(1998 Code, sec. 96.36)
Sec. 3.15.073 Maximum height of shrubs, hedges, etc.
No person shall plant, grow or maintain in any restricted area any plant, hedge, shrub or other growth, except
trees, at a height greater than three feet from the street gutter flow line. (1998 Code, sec. 96.37)
Sec. 3.15.074 Minimum clearance of trees
Any trees planted, grown and maintained in any restricted area shall not have branches or foliage extending from
the trunk thereof at a height lower than the heights provided in section 8.01.002(a)(6). (1998 Code, sec. 96.38)
Sec. 3.15.075 City's right of entry and removal
In addition to any penalty which may be imposed for the violation of this division, the city shall be entitled to
enter upon and remove from the triangular corner areas described in this division any of the growth prohibited
by this division. Such entry and removal shall be without liability to the owners thereof. (1998 Code, sec. 96.39)
Secs. 3.15.076–3.15.100 Reserved
Division 4. Use of Poles, Wires, Pipes and Other Appurtenances*
Sec. 3.15.101 Right of city to regulate property, equipment and fixtures in public ways
The city hereby reserves the right to put into effect at any time other restrictions and regulations as to the
erection and maintenance of poles, wires, pipes, and other appurtenances in the streets, easements, alleys and
other public ways of the city and from time to time to require such poles, pipes, wires and other property,
equipment and fixtures as it may deem proper to be removed and to require wires to be run in conduits on such
terms as the city may deem proper. (1998 Code, sec. 96.50)

Sec. 3.15.102 Inspection; notice to correct condition
The building inspector, electrical inspector, police officers, and such other persons designated by the city shall
have power and it shall be their duty to examine and inspect from time to time all telegraph, telephone, electric
light or other poles, gas pipe lines, pipes and other fixtures in the public places within the city for the purpose of
seeing that all of same are in a safe and suitable condition, and whenever any such item is found to be unsafe or
unsuitable for the purpose for which it is used, the person using, possessing or maintaining same shall be

Nothing contained in the provisions of this division is intended to relieve any person of any condition,

The provisions of this division shall not grant a franchise to any utility or person to use the streets, easements,
