(2) Water pipe;
(3) Carburetion tube or device;
(4) Smoking or carburetion mask;
(5) Chamber pipe;
(6) Carburetor pipe;
(7) Electric pipe;
(8) Air-driven pipe;
(9) Chillum;
(10) Bong; or
(11) An ice pipe or chiller.
(Ordinance O-004-13 adopted 3/19/13)
Sec. 8.10.004 Prohibition on use or possession of other paraphernalia or other substances
It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly or intentionally use or possess any item with the intent to sell or
use such item as illicit synthetic or misbranded substance, or paraphernalia to plant, propagate, cultivate, grow,
harvest, manufacture, compound, convert, produce, process, prepare, test, analyze, pack, repack, store, contain,
or conceal an illicit synthetic or misbranded substance in violation of this article. (Ordinance O-012-13 adopted
12/3/13)
Sec. 8.10.005 Exceptions
(a) The prohibitions set forth in section 8.10.002(a) shall not apply to any person or facility regulated under
the Texas Pharmacy Act.
(b) The prohibitions set forth in section 8.10.002 shall not apply to any substance if the substance's packaging
includes:
(1) The name and physical address of the manufacturer of the product and each ingredient or
component thereof;
(2) The name and physical address of each distributor; and
(3) A complete list of all ingredients and components of the product, including their chemical
composition, sufficient to provide full disclosure.
(c) The prohibitions set forth in section 8.10.002 shall not apply to any substance labeled in accordance with
the regulations of the U.S. Food and Drug Administration or other federal or state law.
(d) It is not a violation of this article if a person purchased, sold, breathed, inhaled, drank, or otherwise
ingested the substance under the lawful supervision of an authorized law enforcement officer to enforce or
ensure compliance with this article.
(e) It is not a violation of this article if a person breathed, inhaled, drank, or otherwise ingested a substance
described in this article pursuant to the lawful direction or prescription of a licensed physician, dentist, etc.
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 261/430
(f) This article does not apply to the inhalation of a lawfully prescribed anesthesia for medical or dental
purposes.
Sec. 8.10.006 Penalties
Any person, partnership, corporation, association or legal entity found to have violated any provision of this
article or to have failed to comply with any provision of this article shall, upon conviction, be fined in
accordance with section 1.01.009 of this code. The imposition of a fine shall be in addition to all other remedies
provided in this article. Each day that a violation exists shall constitute a separate offense.
Sec. 8.10.007 Alternative enforcement
(a) The city council having determined and found that this article is intended for the preservation of public
health and safety, the city attorney or his/her designee is expressly authorized to institute civil proceedings to
obtain temporary and permanent injunctive relief against any violation hereof, to recover any civil penalties
permitted by law, and to recover the city's costs.
(b) In any proceeding hereunder, the city shall also request entry of an order for the seizure of any substances
or products that violate the provisions of this article.
(Ordinance O-004-13 adopted 3/19/13)
ARTICLE 8.11 ELECTRONIC CIGARETTES
Sec. 8.11.001 Purpose
This article is adopted so that the city council may promote, protect, and improve the health, safety, and general
welfare of the citizens of the city under the age of 18 from the hazards of nicotine addiction and the dangers of
ingesting products with no clear regulatory oversight as to their purity, contents, and potential negative health
impacts, through the regulation of the sale and merchandising of electronic cigarettes, liquid nicotine products,
and other flavored liquid products designed to be used in conjunction with electronic cigarettes, the regulation of
which is not preempted by federal or state law.
Sec. 8.11.002 Definitions
Electronic cigarette or e-cigarette. An electronic device usually composed of a mouthpiece, a heating element or
atomizer, a battery, and electronic circuits that all work together to provide a gas derived from liquid nicotine,
and/or other substances, which is inhaled by a user simulating smoking. The term includes such devices,
regardless of the details of the product appearance or marketed name, generally manufactured to resemble
cigarettes, cigars, pipes, or other smoking devices.
Liquid nicotine. Any liquid product composed either in whole or in part of nicotine, propylene glycol and/or
other similar substances, and manufactured for use with an e-cigarette to be converted into a gas for inhaling.
Minor. A person less than 18 years of age.
Person. Any natural person, individual, corporation, limited liability company, unincorporated association,
proprietorship, firm, partnership, joint venture, joint stock association, or other entity or business of any kind.
Photographic identification. A state-issued, district, national or other equivalent government driver's license,
identification card or military card, in all cases bearing a photograph and a date of birth; or a valid passport.
Sec. 8.11.003 Prohibited acts and exceptions
(a) A person who is a minor commits an offense if the person:
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 262/430
(1) Possesses, purchases, consumes, or accepts an electronic cigarette, liquid nicotine, or any
flavored liquid product designed to be used in conjunction with an electronic cigarette; or
(2) Falsely represents himself or herself to be 18 years of age or older by displaying proof of age
that is false, fraudulent, or not actually proof of the individual's own age in order to purchase, receive
or obtain possession of an electronic cigarette, liquid nicotine, or any flavored liquid product
designed to be used in conjunction with an electronic cigarette.
(b) No person may give, distribute, transfer, sell, market, or offer electronic cigarettes, liquid nicotine, or any
flavored liquid product designed to be used in conjunction with an electronic cigarette, to a minor.
(c) No person shall sell, or permit to be sold, through a mechanical dispensing device or vending machine,
electronic cigarettes, liquid nicotine, or any flavored liquid product designed to be used in conjunction with an
electronic cigarette, unless the dispensing device or vending machine is located fully within premises from
which minors are prohibited.
(d) It shall be a defense to prosecution for a violation of this section if the minor possessed the electronic
cigarette, liquid nicotine, or any flavored liquid product designed to be used in conjunction with an electronic
cigarette, in the presence of his or her own adult parent, guardian, or a spouse who is at least 18 years of age.
(e) It shall be a defense to prosecution for a violation of this section if possession or receipt of the electronic
cigarette, liquid nicotine, or any flavored liquid product designed to be used in conjunction with an electronic
cigarette is required in the performance of the minor's duties as an employee. This defense to prosecution only
extends to the possession or receipt of a prohibited item, as described in subsection (a)(1) above, and is not a
defense to prosecution for purchase or consumption of a prohibited item.
(f) It shall be a defense to prosecution for a violation of this section if a minor is participating in an inspection
or test of compliance, acting under the supervision and instruction of a law enforcement agency performing
compliance operations.
Sec. 8.11.004 Enforcement
This article shall be enforced by the city's police department.
Sec. 8.11.005 Penalty
(a) A person who violates a provision of this article is guilty of a separate offense for each day or part of a day
during which the violation is committed, continued, or permitted. Each offense, upon conviction, is punishable
by fine as provided in section 1.01.009.
(b) When required by section 51.08 of the Texas Family Code, as amended, the municipal court shall waive
original jurisdiction over a minor who violates section 8.11.003 and shall refer the minor to juvenile court.
(Ordinance O-004-14 adopted 5/20/14)
CHAPTER 9
PERSONNEL
ARTICLE 9.01 GENERAL PROVISIONS*
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 263/430
Sec. 9.01.001 Response time for employees required to respond to fire calls
(a) A reasonable response time is hereby established by the city for employees who are required to respond to
fire calls. Such individuals are hereby required to establish residence within a 60-minute response time from the
city's central fire station.
(b) (1) Individuals who are hired as new employees by the city, and are required to respond to
fire calls, shall establish a residence within the 60-minute response area no later than 60 days
subsequent to actual employment.
(2) Acquisition of a mailing address inside the 60-minute response area shall not be considered
sufficient to meet the requirements of this section. The individual to which this section applies must
establish, maintain, and actually reside within the 60-minute response area.
(c) Individuals living inside the 60-minute response area at the time of the adoption of this section (September
4, 2012) will be subject to the same requirements as new employees.
(d) This section shall not be applied retroactively. Individuals residing outside the 60-minute response area at
the time of the adoption of this section (September 4, 2012) shall not be required to move inside the 60-minute
response area. Nothing in this section shall be intended to conflict with other state statutory enactments, such as
the Health and Safety Code.
(e) Compliance with the provisions of this section shall be determined by the fire chief on an individual basis.
State law reference–Residency requirements for municipal employees, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code, sec. 150.021.
Cross reference–Fire prevention and protection, ch. 5.
Sec. 9.01.002 Response time for employees required to respond to police calls
(a) A reasonable response time is hereby established by the city for employees who are required to respond to
police calls. Such individuals are hereby required to establish residence within a 60-minute response time from
the city's police station.
(b) (1) Individuals who are hired as new employees by the city, and are required to respond to
police calls, shall establish a residence within the 60-minute response area no later than 60 days
subsequent to actual employment.
(2) Acquisition of a mailing address inside the 60-minute response area shall not be considered
sufficient to meet the requirements of this section. The individual to which this section applies must
establish, maintain, and actually reside within the 60-minute response area.
(c) Individuals living inside the 60-minute response area at the time of the adoption of this section (September
4, 2012) will be subject to the same requirements as new employees.
(d) This section shall not be applied retroactively. Individuals residing outside the 60-minute response area at
the time of the adoption of this section (September 4, 2012) shall not be required to move inside the 60-minute
response area. Nothing in this section shall be intended to conflict with other state statutory enactments, such as
the Health and Safety Code.
(e) Compliance with the provisions of this section shall be determined by the police chief on an individual
basis.
(Ordinance O-008-12 adopted 9/4/12)
State law reference–Residency requirements for municipal employees, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code, sec. 150.021.
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 264/430
Sec. 9.01.003 Health benefits coverage for city retirees
(a) The city hereby elects to provide health benefits coverage to its retirees through TML Intergovernmental
Employee Benefits Pool under the pool's interlocal agreement.
(b) The city hereby adopts the following definition of “retiree” for purposes of this section:
(1) Twenty (20) years of service at any age.
(2) Ten (10) years of service at sixty (60) years of age.
(c) The interlocal agreement in effect between the city and the TML Intergovernmental Employee Benefits
Pool provides that the board of trustees may adopt rules and regulations. The rules and regulations of the TML
Intergovernmental Employee Benefits Pool allow the participating member entity to provide retiree medical
coverage at the same contribution as charged to active employees, to select a contribution level which is an
elevated percentage (which may change from time to time) of the active employee contribution, or to offer over
age 65 retirees a Medicare supplement.
(d) The city elects to offer to retirees and their dependents that are under the age of sixty-five (65):
(1) The same medical plan(s) offered to active employees at the same rate as the active employees
for as long as the TML Intergovernmental Employee Benefits Pool offers this rate structure for
retiree medical coverage.
(2) Retiree continuum of care plan for those retirees and their dependents not entitled to Medicare
and/or Medicare supplement or advantage plans.
(e) The city elects to offer Medicare supplement or Medicare advantage plans with/without prescription drug
coverage as established annually by the TML Intergovernmental Employee Benefits Pool board of trustees for
retirees and their dependents who are sixty-five (65) years of age or older at the Medicare supplement or
Medicare advantage rate.
(f) The city elects to offer the following optional life insurance coverages:
(1) Retiree basic life.
(2) Retiree optional life.
(3) Retiree dependent life.
(g) The city may adopt on an annual basis, any additional or alternative retiree benefit plans to be provided
through TML Intergovernmental Employee Benefits Pool.
(h) The entire cost of these plans shall be paid for entirely by the retiree.
(i) This section will apply to individuals retiring after the effective date of this section, and to employees who
retired under a previous ordinance that elected to continue their healthcare coverage through TML-IEBP. For
individuals retiring after the effective date of this section to qualify, they must enroll for this coverage within
thirty (30) days of their retirement.
(j) This section may be repealed or modified at any time, but will remain in effect for any employee retiring
while it is in effect.
(Ordinance O-005-09, secs. 2, 4 and 5, adopted 9/1/09)

https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 265/430

ARTICLE 9.02 TEXAS MUNICIPAL RETIREMENT SYSTEM*
Sec. 9.02.001 Election to participate; applicable regulations adopted by reference
(a) Election to participate in TMRS. On behalf of the city, the city council hereby exercises its option and
elects to have the city and all of the employees of all departments participate in the Texas Municipal Retirement
System (hereinafter “TMRS”) as provided in Tex. Gov't. Code section 851.001 et seq., as amended; and all of
the benefits and obligations of such system are hereby accepted.
(b) Election to participate in TMRS supplemental benefits fund. The city council elects to have the employees
of all participating departments of the city participate in and be covered by the supplemental benefits fund of the
Texas Municipal Retirement System, as provided by Tex. Gov't. Code section 851.001 et seq.; and all the
benefits and obligations of participation in said fund are hereby accepted by the city as to such employees.
(c) Adoption of regulations by reference. Ordinances effecting the plan for participation in the TMRS,
employee contributions, updated service credits, increases in benefits and retirement annuities and any other
applicable legislation of the city and state are adopted by reference into this code as if fully set forth herein and
shall be kept on file in the office of the city secretary.
(1998 Code, sec. 33.01)
Sec. 9.02.002 Vesting not provided
The city council elects not to provide five-year vesting under the Texas Municipal Retirement System (“TMRS”)
as provided in Tex. Gov't. Code section 854.205, and the city is hereby authorized and directed to file notice of
this election with the board of trustees of TMRS before December 31, 2001. (1998 Code, sec. 33.02)
CHAPTER 10
SUBDIVISIONS
ARTICLE 10.01 GENERAL PROVISIONS*
Sec. 10.01.001 Authority
This chapter is adopted under the authority of the constitution and laws of the state, including particularly
chapter 212, compiled as Tex. Local Gov't Code, and the provisions of Local Gov't Code section 43.021 as
heretofore or hereafter amended.
Sec. 10.01.002 Purpose
The purpose of this chapter is to provide for the orderly, safe and healthful development of the area within the
city and within the area surrounding the city and to promote the health, safety, morals and general welfare of the
community.
Sec. 10.01.003 Jurisdiction
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 266/430
(a) From and after the passage of this chapter, all plats and subdivisions of land within the corporate limits of
the city and all plats and subdivisions of land outside the corporate limits of the city and within one mile thereof,
and all land outside the corporate limits of the city that the council may be petitioned to include within the
corporate limits of the city by an extension of said corporate limits, shall conform to the following rules and
regulations.
(b) It is not intended by this chapter to repeal, abrogate, or in any way impair or interfere with the existing
provisions of other laws or ordinances, except those provisions which are in conflict with this chapter, or with
private restrictions placed upon property, by deed, covenant or other private agreement. Where this chapter
imposes a greater restriction upon land than is imposed or required by such existing provisions of law or
ordinance, the provisions of this chapter shall control.
Sec. 10.01.004 Definitions
For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or
requires a different meaning. Definitions not expressly prescribed herein are to be construed in accordance with
the customary usage in municipal planning and engineering practices.
Alley. A minor public right-of-way, not intended to provide the primary means of access to abutting lots, which
is used primarily for installation of public utilities, solid waste collection, and for vehicular access to the back or
sides of properties otherwise abutting on a street.
Block. An area enclosed by streets and occupied by or intended for buildings. As a term of measurement, block
shall mean the distance along a side of a street lying between and adjoining two (2) intersecting streets.
Building setback line. The line parallel to the street right-of-way line designating the minimum distance from the
street right-of-way line that a structure may be erected.
Commission. The planning and zoning commission of the city.
Comprehensive plan. A periodically updated series of documents that unifies all elements and aspects of city
planning. This plan reflects the best judgment of the staff, planning and zoning commission and city council and
sets a policy for zoning and subdivision decisions. This plan indicates the general locations recommended for
various land uses, transportation routes, public buildings, streets, parks and other public and private
developments and improvements.
Conceptual development plan. An overall conceptual plan showing the intentions of the developer to improve or
subdivide land in accordance with this chapter.
Council. Members of the city council.
Dead-end street. A street, other than a cul-de-sac, with only one outlet.
Developer. Any person, entity or corporation who improves land, to effect a subdivision of land, or submits a
conceptual plan for city consideration.
Easement. A right held by the city or its franchised utility companies to be used for access, drainage or the
placement of utilities such as water, gas, sewer, telephone, cable television and electrical lines or other facilities.
Engineer. A person duly authorized under the provisions of The Texas Engineering Practice Act, [V.T.C.A.,
Occupations Code, chapter 1001], as heretofore or hereafter amended, to practice the profession of engineering.
Extraterritorial jurisdiction. The contiguous unincorporated area not incorporated in any other city, within one
(1) mile of the corporate limits of the City of Borger.
Front/frontage lot. The length of a lot adjacent to a street between two (2) adjacent property lines of lots.
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 267/430
Front/frontage, street. The length of all property on one (1) side of a street lying between two (2) intersecting
streets measured along the right-of-way line, or if the street is a dead-end or cul-de-sac, the length of all property
abutting on one (1) side between an intersecting street and the end of the dead-end street or cul-de-sac street.
Lot. Land occupied or to be occupied by a building and its accessory building.
Main. A water or wastewater (sewer) line designed and installed to collect sewage from or distribute water to
lateral or service lines.
Plat. The map (conceptual plan) which a developer's plan is presented for approval and intends to record in final
form.
Plat, final. A plat which complies with the requirements of V.T.C.A., Local Government Code, chapter 212 (sec.
212.001 et seq.) and this chapter.
Replattinq (resubdivision). The rearranging of any part of a block, street, or alley of a previously platted
subdivision.
Riqht-of-wav, public. Any strip of land including surface, overhead or underground space which is used or
intended to be used wholly or in part as a public street, or alley, or as the location of public walkways and utility
or drainage facilities or installations.
Service tap. A water or wastewater pipe of a design capacity to service a single lot extended from the main to the
property line of the lot served by the service tap.
Shall, should, may. The word “shall” is mandatory. The word “should” is considered to be advisable usage,
recommended but not mandatory. The word “may” is merely permissive.
Sidewalk. The cement concrete, asphaltic concrete or other permanent hard-surfaced material approved by the
director of public works that is located in the street right-of-way, intended for pedestrian use.
Street. The entire width between the boundary lines of every way, other than an alley, publicly maintained when
any part of it is opened to the use of the public for vehicular traffic.
Street, arterial. A principal traffic artery, more or less continuous across the city, which connects remote parts of
the city or areas adjacent thereto and acts as a principal connecting street with state and federal highway, and
includes each street designated as a primary or secondary arterial street.
Street, collector. A street which carries traffic from local streets to arterial streets or highway, including the
principal entrance streets of a residential development and streets for circulation in such a development.
Street, cul-de-sac or court. A dead-end street providing a turnaround for vehicles.
Street, dead-end. A street other than a cul-de-sac, with only one (1) outlet.
Street, local. A street which is primarily to serve traffic within a neighborhood and which is not necessarily
through several residential districts.
Street, marginal access. A local street which is parallel and adjacent to an arterial street or highway and which
provides access to abutting property and protection from through traffic.
Street, width. The shortest horizontal distance between the lines which delineate the right-of-way of a street.
Subdivider. Any person or agent thereof, dividing or proposing to divide land so as to constitute a subdivision as
that term is defined herein, in any event, the term “subdivider” shall be restricted to include only the owner,
equitable owner or authorized agent of such owner or equitable owner, of land sought to be subdivided.
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 268/430
Subdivision. A division of any tract of land situated within the corporate limits, or within one (1) mile of such
limits, in two (2) or more parts.
Surveyor. A licensed state land surveyor or a registered professional land surveyor as authorized by state statutes
to practice the profession of surveying in Texas.
Thoroughfare. Same as street.
Tract. Same as lot.
Transportation plan. The master street development and thoroughfare plan for the city.
Utility. City and/or franchised utility company, above or below ground equipment and lines including, but not
limited to, water, sewer, gas, electricity, telephone and cable television.
Zoning. Regulations governing the use of land and buildings and development standards as set forth in chapter
14, Zoning, Code of Ordinances.
Sec. 10.01.005 Policy
(a) It shall be unlawful for any owner or agent of any owner of land to lay out, subdivide, plat or replat any
land or tract in two or more parts, lots, blocks and streets within the city, or within a maximum distance of one
mile of the corporate limits of the city, without the approval of the planning and zoning commission and the city
council. It shall be unlawful for any such owner or agent to offer for sale or sell property therein or thereby,
which has not been laid out, subdivided, platted or replatted with the approval of the planning and zoning
commission and the city council.
(1) No plat of any subdivision shall be entitled to be recorded in the county clerk's office or have
any validity until it shall have been approved in the manner prescribed herein. In the event any such
unapproved plat is recorded, it shall be considered invalid and the city shall institute proceedings to
have the plat stricken from the records.
(2) No owner or agent of any owner of any land located within a subdivision shall transfer, sell,
agree to sell or negotiate to sell any land by reference to, by exhibition of or by the use of a plan or
plat of a subdivision before such plan or plat has been approved and recorded in the manner
prescribed herein.
(3) At the request of the city council, the city attorney or any other attorney representing the city
may file an action in a court of competent jurisdiction to enjoin the violation or threatened violation
of this chapter by the owner of a tract of land, or recover damages from the owner of a tract of land in
an amount adequate for the city to undertake any construction or other activity necessary to bring
about compliance with the requirements of this chapter regarding the tract. “Owner of a tract of land”
as used in this subsection does not include the owner of an individual lot in a subdivided tract of land.
(b) In order to promote the health, safety, morals or general welfare of the city, and the safe, orderly and
healthful development of the city, the city hereby defines its policy to be that the city will withhold all public
improvements of whatsoever nature, including water service, sewage facilities and maintenance of streets, from
all additions, subdivisions, or parts thereof and from all areas dedicated to the public, the platting of which has
not been approved by the planning and zoning commission and the city council.
(c) No street number and no building permit shall be issued for the erection of any building in the city on any
piece of property other than the original or resubdivided lot in a duly approved and recorded subdivision without
the written approval of the planning and zoning commission and the city council.
(d) (1) The attention of each subdivider is directed to Tex. Local Gov't Code section 242.001(b),
which states in part: “For an area in a municipality's extraterritorial jurisdiction, as defined by Tex.
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 269/430
Local Gov't Code section 212.001, a plat may not be filed with the county clerk without the approval
of both the municipality and the county.”
(2) In the event any provision of this chapter is violated within the extraterritorial jurisdiction of
the city, and outside the city's corporate limits, the city may institute any appropriate action or
proceedings in the district court to enjoin the violation of this chapter.
(e) In lieu of the requirements set forth in (a), (b), (c) and (d) above, the director of planning and zoning,
without consideration by the planning and zoning commission or city council, may approve minor final plats
involving four (4) or fewer lots fronting on an existing street and not requiring the creation of any new street(s)
or alley(s), or the extension of municipal facilities, or for amending a final plat which may be recorded and is
controlling over the preceding plat without vacation of that plat, if the amending plat is solely for one or more of
the following purposes:
(1) To correct an error in a course or distance that was shown on or add a course or distance that
was omitted from the preceding plat, or to correct an error in property description shown on the
preceding plat, or to correct an error in property description shown on the preceding plat.
(2) To indicate monuments set after the death, disability, or retirement from practice of the
engineer or surveyor responsible for setting the monuments.
(3) To show the location or character monument that has been changed in location or character or
that is shown incorrectly as to location or character on the preceding plat.
(4) To correct any other type of scrivener or clerical error or omission in a plat previously
approved by the planning and zoning commission or city council, including lot numbers, acreage,
street names and identification of adjacent recorded plats.
(5) To correct errors in the courses or distances of lot lines between two (2) adjacent lots if both lot
owners join in the application for amending the plat, if neither lot is abolished, and if the amendment
does not attempt to remove recorded covenants or restrictions.
(6) To relocate a lot line to eliminate an inadvertent encroachment of a building or other
improvement on a lot line or easement; or to relocate one (1) or more lot lines between one (1) or
more adjacent lots if the owners of all those lots join in the application amending the plat, if the
amendment does not attempt to remove recorded covenants or restriction, and if the amendment does
not increase the number of lots.
(7) To make necessary changes to a preceding plat to create four (4) or fewer lots in the
subdivision or a part of the subdivision covered by the preceding plat if the changes do not affect the
applicable zoning and other regulation of the City of Borger, if the changes are located in an area that
the city council has approved as a residential area.
(8) To replat one (1) or more lots fronting on an existing street if the owners of all those lots join in
the application for amending the plat, if the amendment does not attempt to remove recorded
covenants or restriction or if the amendment does not create or require the creation of a new street or
make necessary the extension municipal facilities.
(A) The director of planning and zoning shall not approve a variance to these regulations.
(B) Submittal requirements and approval standards shall be the same as for other final plats.
The director of planning and zoning shall submit any minor plat or amending plat which he
disapproves to the planning and zoning commission for consideration within sufficient time to
enable action to be taken within thirty (30) days after the application is filed.

https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 270/430
(C) The director of planning and zoning may, for any reason, elect to present a minor plat or
amending plat to the planning and zoning commission for consideration.
ARTICLE 10.02 PLAT APPROVALS
Sec. 10.02.001 Preapplication conference
Prior to the filing of a plat, the subdivider shall meet with the city secretary and/or director of planning to
acquaint himself with the requirements of the city and the relationship of the proposed subdivision to existing
subdivisions in the general area. At such meeting, the street requirements, utilities and general character of the
development may be discussed.
Sec. 10.02.002 Application required for preliminary and final plat
(a) Any owner or agent of any owner of land desiring to subdivide or plat such land shall submit an
application in writing for approval of a “preliminary and final plat” and proposed street and utility designs to the
city secretary or director of planning. Such application, accompanied by five prints of the proposed plat and the
street and utility designs, shall be filed at least ten days prior to the meeting of the planning and zoning
commission at which approval is asked. The “preliminary and final plat” shall be submitted by the owner,
subdivider or his agent prior to the sale or offering for sale of any lot, tract, or building site.
(b) When it is desired to develop a subdivision in sections or parcels, a preliminary plat of the entire area shall
be submitted to the planning and zoning commission and the city council for approval following the same
procedure as a “preliminary and final plat.” Such plat shall be titled “preliminary plat.” The approval of the
“preliminary plat” by the planning and zoning commission and the city council shall not constitute acceptance or
approval of the subdivision, but is an authorization to proceed with the preparation of the final plat of the
subdivision or portions thereof with the conditions of such approval. The “preliminary plat” shall be filed with
the city secretary after approval, to serve as a guide for the future development of the remaining sections or
parcels.
(c) The planning and zoning commission shall not receive or consider a plat and street and utility designs
unless submitted in accordance with or are accompanied by the following: (see sections 10.02.003 through
10.02.006).
Sec. 10.02.003 Application requirements
(a) For all subdivisions exceeding ten acres in size, a vicinity sketch or key map at a practical scale (400 feet
to the inch preferred) shall be supplied. Such sketch or key map shall show existing subdivisions, streets,
property lines and the recorded names of the owners of the adjoining parcels. It shall also show how the streets
and alleys connect or relate to streets and alleys in neighboring subdivisions and the relationship of the
development to existing or proposed major and secondary thoroughfares.
(b) The “preliminary and final plat” shall be so titled and shall show the names of the subdivider and the name
of the owner if different from the subdivider.
(c) The proposed name of the subdivision (which must not be as similar to that of an existing subdivision as to
cause confusion) and adjacent subdivisions, the names of streets (to conform whenever possible to existing street
names) and numbers of lots and blocks, in accordance with a systematic arrangement.
(d) An accurate boundary survey of the property, with bearings and distances referenced to section lines and
established subdivisions, and showing the lines of adjacent lands and the lines of adjacent streets and alleys, with
their width and names. Streets, alleys and lot lines in adjacent subdivisions shall be shown in dashed lines.
(1) Location of permanent monuments which shall be placed at all corners of boundary lines of a
subdivision and the location of other points which may be necessary for the layout of the subdivision.
Permanent monuments shall be six-inch-diameter concrete 18 inches long with the intersection point
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 271/430
marked with a copper pin 1/4 inch in diameter or a brass cap 1-1/2 inches in diameter. Intermediate
property corners, curve points and angle points shall be marked by iron stakes not less than 12 inches
in length. All monuments and iron stakes shall be set flush with the ground or countersunk, if
necessary, to avoid being disturbed.
(2) Physical features of the property shall be shown including location of watercourses, ravines,
bridges, culverts, present structures, location and size of any existing utilities, and other features
pertinent to subdivision. Where a subdivision is traversed by a watercourse, drainage way, channel or
stream there shall be provided a stormwater easement or drainage right-of-way conforming
substantially to the line for such watercourse and of such further width or construction, or both, as
will be adequate for the purpose.
(3) Any existing flood zones, as shown on the “flood hazard boundary maps” as published by the
U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development [Federal Emergency Management Agency],
shall be clearly outlined on the plat with the base flood elevations shown.
(4) The planning and zoning commission may require additional easements across other parts of
lots if necessary for the installation of utilities or enclosed or open drainage ways. When easements in
areas adjoining the proposed subdivision are necessary to provide adequate drainage thereof or to
serve the subdivision with utilities, the subdivider shall obtain such easements.
(e) The location and width of proposed streets, lots, alleys, building lines, utility easements, widening of
existing thoroughfares, and other features, with accurate dimensions in feet and decimal fractions of feet, with
the length of radii and arcs of all curves, all angles, and with all other engineering information necessary to
reproduce the plat on the ground. Dimensions shall be shown from all angle points.
(1) Contours with a minimum interval of five feet shall be shown as light, dashed lines. A closer
contour interval may be required by the director of planning or city secretary when it is deemed
necessary to indicate topography or drainage. All elevations shown shall be based on USGS datum,
which shall be specified on the plat. A permanent boundary monument shall be used as a benchmark
and the elevation and location of the monument shall be shown on the plat.
(2) The street layout shall be in conformity with a plan for the most advantageous development of
the entire neighborhood area and shall conform to any preliminary plat which may have been
approved by the planning and zoning commission or city council. Proposed streets shall be adjusted
to the contour of the land so as to provide usable lots and streets of reasonable gradient.
(3) Whenever the proposed subdivision contains or is adjacent or parallel to a railroad right-of-way
or a major thoroughfare or freeway of expressway standards, provisions shall be made for a street
approximately parallel to and on each side of such right-of-way at a suitable distance to provide
reasonable use of the intervening land.
(4) All lots or building sites shall conform to the minimum standards for area, width and depth
prescribed by the zoning ordinance for the district or districts in which the subdivision is located.
(5) All lots of subdivisions to be located within the extraterritorial jurisdiction of the city and
which are to be served by a public water supply, but utilizing individual subsurface absorptive
methods for sewage disposal, shall provide for individual lots having surface areas of at least onehalf
acre, or large enough to have a duplicate system, whichever is greater. Smaller lot sizes shall
only be permitted upon submission of written approval for such from the department of state health
services.
(f) The “preliminary and final plat” shall be clearly and legibly drawn in India ink upon permanent tracing
material to a scale of 100 feet to the inch unless approved otherwise and the plat shall also show:
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 272/430
(1) North point, scale, and date of preparation.
(2) Location of subdivision by section, block, survey, county and state.
(3) Metes and bounds description of plat boundaries.
(4) Location of all permanent monuments and control points to which all dimensions, bearings and
similar data shall be referred.
(5) Signature and seal of a registered public surveyor or licensed state land surveyor in responsible
charge of surveying the platted area.
(6) An acknowledgement by the owner of his adoption of the plat and of the dedication of streets,
alleys, easements and other public areas to public use.
(7) Restrictive covenants imposed on the land. (These may be submitted in a separate instrument
but must be filed with the city.)

Sec. 10.02.005 Accompanying documents
(a) The “preliminary and final plat” or “final plat,” as the case may be, shall be accompanied by the following
and each shall bear the signature and seal of a registered professional engineer:
(1) Street design. Plan and profile for each street proposed in the subdivision showing the right-ofway,
paving width, curb and gutter, drainage structures and any utilities which may be located in such
right-of-way. Profile shall show the elevation of the existing ground and the proposed grade elevation
at the centerline of the street and top of the curb elevation if different from the centerline. Plan and
profile of drainage structures and channels may be shown on the same drawings as the street plans
and profiles. Maximum station interval shall be 50 feet.
(2) Utility design. Plan and profile of sewer line may be shown on the street plan and profile when
located in the street right-of-way. The profile shall show the elevation of existing and proposed street
or ground elevation and the top and flow line elevation of each manhole and the sewer line at a
maximum station interval of 50 feet.
(3) Cross sections. Cross sections showing details of street design, manholes and drainage
structures.
(4) Sewage lift station. Complete plans and specifications shall be submitted for approval to the
director of utilities prior to the meeting of the city council at which the plat will be considered.
(5) Estimate. A detailed estimate indicating the cost of materials and their installation for the
streets, utilities, drainage structures and lift stations shall be submitted ten days prior to the meeting
of the city council at which the plat will be considered.
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 274/430
(b) Easement documents, right-of-way deeds or property deeds properly executed for any streets, utilities,
drainage structures, lift stations or others which may be located outside the subdivision shall be presented prior
to the meeting of the city council at which the plat will be considered.
Sec. 10.02.006 Surety bond, certificate of deposit or cashier's check required
Prior to submission of the “preliminary and final plat” or “final plat” to the city council for consideration of
approval, the subdivider or owner shall deliver to the city secretary a surety bond, certificate of deposit or
cashier's check payable to the city. The amount of the surety bond, certificate of deposit or cashier's check shall
be determined by the estimate as required in section 10.02.005(a)(5). The amount of the surety bond, certificate
of deposit or cashier's check may be reduced as the work on the development progresses; for example, when the
street work is complete and accepted by the city in writing, the amount on deposit with the city may be reduced
by the amount in the estimate allowed for the cost of the street work.
Sec. 10.02.007 Presentation of plat to director of planning or city manager
After the subdivider or owner has acquainted himself with the requirements of this chapter, the plat, along with
the street and utility designs, shall be presented to the director of planning or city secretary ten days prior to the
meeting of the planning and zoning commission at which approval is requested.
Sec. 10.02.008 Public hearing by planning and zoning commission
(a) The planning and zoning commission at its regular meeting shall hold a public hearing to consider the plat.
After such hearing the commission may recommend to the city council that the plat be considered for approval
and may in such recommendation set forth any conditions or requirements that the developer or owner must
comply with. If such conditions or requirements exist to such an extent that in the opinion of the planning and
zoning commission an additional hearing is required, the plat shall be returned to the commission at the next
regular meeting or a future meeting. The planning and zoning commission shall approve a plat if it conforms to
the general plan of the city and its current and future streets, alleys, parks, playgrounds and public utility
facilities; the general plan for the extension of the city and its roads, streets and public highways within the city
and in its extraterritorial jurisdiction, taking into account access to and extension of sewer and water mains and
the instrumentalities of public utilities; and all requirements of this subdivision chapter.
(b) The planning and zoning commission shall act on a plat within 30 days after the date the plat is filed. A
plat is considered approved by the planning and zoning commission unless it is disapproved within such 30-day
period.
Sec. 10.02.009 Action by city council
(a) The city council, upon receiving the recommendation of the planning and zoning commission in a regular
meeting, shall set a date to hold a public hearing thereon at which the plat will be considered for approval. In
considering such plat the city council may impose conditions or requirements which are deemed necessary to
ensure compliance with this chapter, other city ordinances and/or for the protection of property owners in
adjacent subdivisions. Such conditions or requirements may be in addition to any which may have been imposed
by the planning and zoning commission.
(b) The city council shall act on the plat within 30 days after the date the plat is approved by the planning and
zoning commission or is considered approved by the inaction of the planning and zoning commission. A plat is
considered approved by the city council unless it is disapproved within such 30-day period.
Sec. 10.02.010 Signature of mayor; filing of copy of plat
Upon approval of the plat by the city council and after the proper escrow deposit or bond has been filed with the
city secretary, the plat shall be signed by the mayor and attested by the city secretary after which a reproducible
copy of the plat shall be filed with the county clerk's office by the city secretary. A reproducible copy with the
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 275/430
filing information shall be retained in the city archives and the original plat shall be returned to the subdivider.
The plat shall be an official plat of record after it has been filed with the city secretary and the county clerk.
Sec. 10.02.011 Subdivider, owner or agent to be present at public hearings
The subdivider, owner, or his agent shall be present at all public hearings at which the plat is to be considered.
Failure to appear may result in such hearing being postponed or the plat being tabled until such time as the
subdivider, owner, or his agent requests a hearing.
Sec. 10.02.012 Variances
(a) The planning and zoning commission may recommend that the city council authorize a variance of these
regulations when, in its opinion, undue hardship may result from strict compliance. In recommending any
variance, the planning and zoning commission shall prescribe only conditions that it deems necessary or
desirable for the public interest. In making its findings, as required herein below, the planning and zoning
commission shall take into account the nature of the proposed use of land and the existing use of the land in the
vicinity, the number of persons to reside or work in the proposed subdivision and the probable effect of the
proposed subdivision upon traffic conditions in the vicinity. No variance shall be recommended unless the
planning and zoning commission finds:
(1) That there are special circumstances or conditions affecting the property such that the strict
application of the provisions of this chapter would deprive the applicant of the reasonable use of his
land.
(2) That the variance is necessary for the preservation and enjoyment of a substantial property right
of the petitioner.
(3) That the granting of a variance will not be detrimental to the public welfare or injurious to other
property in the area where the property is located.
(b) Application for any general variance shall be submitted in writing by the subdivider at the time the plat is
filed for the consideration of the planning and zoning commission. The petition shall state fully the grounds for
the application and all the facts relied upon by the petitioner. The application shall be supplemented with maps,
plans or other additional data which may aid the planning and zoning commission in the analysis of the proposed
project. The plans for such development shall include such covenants, restrictions or other legal provisions
necessary to guarantee the full achievement of the plan.
(c) Any subdivider aggrieved by any finding or action of the planning and zoning commission which is
lawfully subject to review by the city council shall make appeal to the city council within 30 days from the date
of such finding or action, and no appeal shall be permitted after such 30 days.
Sec. 10.02.013 Effect of approval or disapproval of plat
The approval of a plat is not considered an acceptance of any proposed dedication and does not impose on the
city any duty regarding the maintenance or improvement of any dedicated parts until the appropriate municipal
authorities make an actual appropriation of the dedicated parts by entry, use or improvement. The disapproval of
a plat is considered a refusal by the city of the offered dedication indicated on the plat.
Sec. 10.02.014 Vacation of plat
The proprietors of the tract covered by a plat may vacate the plat at any time before any lot in the plat is sold.
The plat is vacated when a signed, acknowledged instrument declaring the plat vacated is approved and recorded
in the manner prescribed for the original plat. If lots in the plat have been sold, the plat, or any part of the plat,
may be vacated on the application of all the owners of lots in the plat with approval obtained in the manner
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 276/430
prescribed for the original plat. On the proper execution and recording of the vacating instrument, the vacated
plat has no effect.
ARTICLE 10.03 GENERAL REQUIREMENTS
Sec. 10.03.001 Street arrangement generally
Unless otherwise approved by the city council, provision must be made for the extension of major streets;
secondary streets shall be provided for circulation of traffic through the subdivision, and adequate minor or local
residential streets provided to accommodate the subdivision.
Sec. 10.03.002 Alignment of streets with existing streets
All major and secondary streets shall be continuous or in alignment with existing streets, unless variations are
deemed advisable by the city council after consideration of recommendations made by the planning and zoning
commission. Curvilinear streets shall be allowed.
Sec. 10.03.003 Street curve requirements
Major streets may have a minimum radius at the centerline of 800 feet; secondary streets may have a minimum
radius at the centerline of 300 feet; minor or local residential streets may have a minimum radius at the
centerline of 150 feet except in special circumstances the planning and zoning commission may approve a minor
or local residential street with a smaller radius.
Sec. 10.03.004 Street intersections
More than two streets intersecting at one point shall be avoided except where it is impractical to secure a proper
street system otherwise. Where several streets converge at one point, setback lines, special rounding or cut-off of
corners and/or a traffic circle may be required to insure safety and facility of traffic movement. No street shall
intersect any other street at an angle of less than 60 degrees. Major street intersections shall have curb radii with
a minimum of 30 feet. Minor or local residential streets shall have a minimum curb radii of 12 feet measured
from the back of the curb.
Sec. 10.03.005 Dead-end streets, cul-de-sacs and courts
Courts or places may be permitted where the form or contour of the land or the shape of the property makes such
street design appropriate. Such cul-de-sacs, courts or places shall provide proper access to all lots and shall
generally not exceed 400 feet in length and a turnaround shall be provided at the closed end which has a
minimum right-of-way radius of 50 feet except that, if an equally safe and convenient form of paved space is
approved by the planning and zoning commission in place of a turning circle, such approved space may be
improved as agreed upon.
Sec. 10.03.006 Relation of streets to adjoining streets and land
The system of streets designated for the subdivision, except in unusual cases, must connect with streets already
dedicated in adjacent subdivisions; and where no adjacent connections are platted, must in general be the
reasonable projection of streets in the nearest subdivided tracts and must be continued to the boundaries of the
tract subdivided, so that other subdivisions may connect therewith. Reserve strips of land controlling access to or
egress from other property or to or from any street or alley or having the effect of restricting or damaging the
adjoining property for subdivision purposes or which will not be taxable or accessible for special improvements
shall not be permitted in any subdivision unless such reserve strips are conveyed to the city on fee simple.
Sec. 10.03.007 Street grades
Major streets may have a maximum grade of 5%, unless the natural topography is such as to require steeper
grades, in which case a 7-1/2% grade may be used for a maximum continuous distance of 200 feet. Secondary
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 277/430
streets may have a maximum grade of 7-1/2%. Minor or local residential streets may have a maximum grade of
10%. All streets must have a minimum grade of at least 0.5%. Centerline grade changes with an algebraic
difference of more than 2% shall be connected with vertical curves of sufficient length to provide a minimum of
600 feet sight distance on major streets; 400 feet sight distance on secondary streets and minor or local
residential streets. No vertical curve shall be less than 200 feet in length. Whenever a cross slope is necessary or
desirable from one curb to the opposite curb, such cross slopes shall not be less than three inches in 30 feet nor
more than 12 inches in 30 feet.
Sec. 10.03.008 Block lengths and widths
In general, intersecting streets determining block lengths shall be provided at such intervals as to serve cross
traffic adequately and to meet existing streets. Where no existing plats control, the blocks shall not be more than
1,600 feet in length nor less than 300 feet in width except in unusual cases.
Sec. 10.03.009 Street widths
(a) Major streets shall have a minimum dedicated width of 100 feet with a minimum pavement width of 66
feet or as prescribed by the planning and zoning commission.
(b) Secondary streets shall have a minimum dedicated width of 65 to 80 feet, with a minimum paving width of
36 to 48 feet.
(c) Minor or local residential streets shall have a minimum dedicated width of 60 feet and all minor or local
residential streets shall have a minimum pavement width of 36 feet measured from back of curb, except in the
case of curvilinear streets, which such width shall be increased to 40 feet measured from back of curb.
Sec. 10.03.010 Sidewalks
In residential subdivisions, sidewalks when provided are to be not less than four feet in width parallel to the curb
and located within the designated street right-of-way. Location of sidewalks shall be uniform throughout the
subdivision and if an extension of an existing subdivision, the sidewalks shall be located the same as in the
existing subdivision. Sidewalks shall be made to slope toward the curb, a minimum slope being 1-1/2 inches.
Maximum slope shall not exceed four inches. Handicapped access ramps shall be provided in the sidewalks at
each block corner. Sidewalks shall be ramped where driveways extend across the sidewalk, if necessary.
Sidewalks are to be constructed of 2500 psi concrete, minimum four inches thick with trowel joints four feet on
center and 1/2-inch expansion joints at all drive edges and intermediate locations not exceeding 40 feet, and
shall have a light sweep finish. Sidewalks abutting business property when provided shall have a minimum
width of six feet.
Sec. 10.03.011 Alleys and alley widths
(a) Alleys shall be provided adjacent to all lots in all districts. Alleys shall be provided 20 feet in width, unless
due to the nature of the development the planning and zoning commission may require additional alley width.
Dead-end alleys shall not be permitted except where they are unavoidable and adequate turnaround facilities
have been provided.
(b) The commission may waive the alley requirement in commercial subdivisions where other definite and
assured provision is made for service access such as off-street loading, unloading, and parking consistent with
and adequate for the uses proposed.
(c) Alleys shall be graded for proper drainage and shall be designed to carry surface waters to the nearest
practical street, storm drain, or natural watercourse approved as a safe place to deposit such waters. Storm
drainage ways or easements that cross alleys shall be concreted the full width of the alley. Compacted base
material four inches thick shall be provided in all alleys. The material shall be of the same type and placement as
that required for streets.
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 278/430
Sec. 10.03.012 Inspections and approval of construction work; compliance with standard specifications
(a) All subdivision construction work located within the corporate limits or within the extraterritorial
jurisdiction of the city, such as street grading, drainage structures, curb and gutter, and installation of sanitary
sewer and water systems, performed by the subdivider or his contractor shall be inspected during construction by
the proper authority of the city and all such work shall be in compliance with standard specifications approved
by the city council.
(b) The proper authority of the city shall submit written approval to the city secretary of the construction of
streets, curbs and gutters, alleys, drainage structures, sanitary sewers, water system and any other item which
may be required prior to release or refunding of any bonds or deposits held by the city and prior to their
acceptance for maintenance by the city.
Sec. 10.03.013 Curb and gutter
Stand-up type concrete curb and gutter, two feet wide and six inches thick, shall be required to be constructed on
all streets and avenues and shall be continuous from block corner to block corner. Radial curb and gutter shall be
constructed at each corner upon each block. Lay-down curbs shall be constructed across all alley intersections
with streets and concrete drainage ways.
Sec. 10.03.014 Street construction standards
(a) All street construction shall be in compliance with the 1982 Standard Specifications for Construction of
Highways, Streets and Bridges as adopted by the state department of transportation.
(b) Street designs shall be approved prior to construction with the minimum being a six-inch-thick sand and
gravel or crushed rock flexible material base compacted to 98% density using the “density control” method with
an overlay of 1-1/2 inch hot mix or an overlay of triple course penetration-type asphalt paving.
(c) Inspection of the installation of the base material and written approval by the proper authority of the city
shall be required prior to overlay.
Sec. 10.03.015 Street posts and markers
All street posts and markers shall be furnished and installed by the city.
Sec. 10.03.016 Excavation and grading
All excavation and grading shall be so designed and performed to carry surface waters to the nearest practical
street, storm drain or natural watercourse and shall be done according to the current standards on file with the
city secretary. All persons performing any excavation or grading operations shall put into effect all safety
precautions which are necessary and shall provide adequate anti-erosion and/or drainage devices, debris basins,
or other safety devices to protect life, limb, health, and welfare of private and public property of others from
damage of any kind.
Sec. 10.03.017 Storm drainage requirements
The size of all drainage structures shall be designed using the “rational method.” Drainage structures shall be
constructed in such locations and of such size to adequately serve the subdivision and the contributing drainage
area. The subdivider shall provide all the necessary easements and rights-of-way inside the subdivision or
outside the subdivision for drainage structures, including storm sewers and open or lined channels. Easements
for drainage structures shall be at least ten feet wider than the structure.
Sec. 10.03.018 Open or lined drainage channels
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 279/430
Drainage channels, when required, shall conform substantially to the line of the existing watercourse and shall
be constructed to extend through the subdivision. All open or lined drainage channels shall have a minimum
bottom width of two feet and a depth based on maximum design flow. Side slopes of channels shall not be
steeper than one foot vertical to two feet horizontal distance. Concrete channels may have vertical sides if
approved by the director of planning or city secretary.
Sec. 10.03.019 Storm sewers
Water in excess of what gutters will carry at maximum design flow shall be diverted into storm sewers or
channels.
Sec. 10.03.020 Water, sewer and other utilities
(a) Generally.
(1) Within the tract covered by a plat, the city shall not serve or connect any public utilities,
including water, sewer, electricity, and gas, that are owned, distributed or controlled by the city, for
the use of the owners or purchasers of any part of the tract unless the plat is approved as provided in
this chapter.
(2) No water connections shall be made and no permits shall be issued for sewer and other utility
connections until the installation of the water and sewer mains with laterals has been completed and
accepted for maintenance by the city on the entire block facing the street on which the property is
located.
(b) Water distribution system.
(1) The water distribution system shall be designed, installed and constructed in accordance with
current AWWA Standards as approved and published by the American Water Works Association and
in compliance with the current rules and regulations for public water systems adopted by the
department of state health services, with reference to materials to be used and construction
procedures to be followed.
(2) As-built drawings shall be provided to the city prior to refunding any deposits and prior to the
acceptance of the system by the city for maintenance.
(3) The water distribution system shall be a closed loop for all subdivisions; dead-end lines shall be
avoided unless installed to serve an area which may be developed in the future. Dead-end lines shall
be provided with a two-inch blowoff valve. Valves shall be so located such that the water line in each
block can be shut off for leak repair or maintenance purposes.
(4) The minimum size water line permitted shall be four inches; the maximum length of four-inch
line shall be 1,000 feet or 30 lot connections, whichever controls.
(5) Water mains serving fire hydrants shall be six inches with a six-inch valve located between the
fire hydrant and the water main.
(6) Water mains and valves shall be of materials as approved by the director of utilities.
(7) Laterals across streets shall be two inches and shall extend from the main to a minimum of two
feet into the area between the curb and the property line and shall be located as close to the center of
the lot it serves as possible. Water laterals shall not be located closer than five feet to a sewer lateral.
The location of all laterals, dimensioned to the nearest lot corner, shall be provided for future location
by the city.
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 280/430
(8) Inspection of the water distribution system shall be made by the proper authority of the city and
shall be requested by the subdivider or his contractor prior to the backfilling of ditches.
(c) Water extension service. In the event water main sizes need to be increased to provide service for the
future development of land, the city will pay the difference in the cost of material of the size line required for
such extension service over the cost of material of the size line which would normally be required to serve the
proposed subdivision. The size of the line needed and the amount to be paid by the city shall be agreed upon
prior to the subdivider purchasing materials. The city will not pay the difference in material cost if the area being
subdivided is part of an area for which a preliminary plat has been filed.
(d) Fire hydrants. Fire hydrants shall be required to be installed in all subdivisions. Fire hydrants shall
conform to the minimum requirements of the state insurance commission and are subject to the approval of the
director of planning and/or city secretary. Fire hydrants in residential areas shall be placed a minimum of 750
feet from any lot in the subdivision as measured along any public right-of-way or easement, which is open and
unobstructed; or located such that a circle with a radius of 500 feet will intersect the circle with radius of 500
feet of the next nearest fire hydrant.
(e) Sewage collection system.
(1) The sewage collection system shall be designed in accordance with the current edition of
Design Criteria for Sewage Systems as adopted by the department of state health services and the
state commission on environmental quality.
(2) As-built drawings shall be provided to the city prior to refunding any deposits and prior to the
acceptance of the system by the city for maintenance.
(3) The materials used in the system shall be as approved by the director of utilities and shall be
identified in the project specifications with appropriate ASTM, ANSI, or AWWA specification
numbers for both quality control and installation. In no case shall bituminous fiberboard or paper
pipe be acceptable for use anywhere in a sewage system.
(4) Manholes shall be located a maximum distance of 400 feet apart with a cleanout provided at
the end of each sewer main. Manholes proposed to be located in the street right-of-way shall be
located on the street centerline or in the area between the curb and the property line.
(5) The minimum size sewer main line shall be six inches and the minimum size lateral shall be
four inches.
(6) All sewers shall be designed and constructed with hydraulic slopes sufficient to give a velocity
when flowing full of not less than two feet per second. The slope of the line or grade shall be as
provided in Design Criteria for Sewer Systems as adopted by the department of state health services
and the state commission on environmental quality. The following slopes are from that publication:
Size of Pipe in Inches LD Fall in Feet per 100 Feet of Sewer
