(7) Laterals shall be extended from the main to the property line and shall be located as close to the
center of the lot it serves as possible. Sewer laterals shall not be located closer than five feet to a
water lateral. The location of the lateral shall be furnished to the city with dimensions to the nearest
lot corner.
(8) Sewage lift station plans and specifications shall be approved by the proper authority of the city
prior to the purchase of any materials therefor.
(9) Inspection of the sewage collection system shall be made by the proper authority of the city and
shall be requested by the subdivider or his contractor prior to the backfilling of ditches.
(f) Sewer extension service. In the event sewer main sizes need to be increased to provide service for the
future development of land, the city will pay the difference in the cost of material of the size line required for
such extension service over the cost of material of the size line which would normally be required to serve the
proposed subdivision. The size of the line needed and the amount to be paid by the city shall be agreed upon
prior to the subdivider purchasing materials. The city will not pay the difference in material cost if the area being
subdivided is part of an area for which a preliminary plat has been filed.
Sec. 10.03.021 Proposed subdivision where city water or sewer not available
(a) Requirements where city water not available. In a subdivision proposed to be located within the
extraterritorial jurisdiction (within one mile of the corporate limits) of the city where city water is not available,
a public water supply shall be accessible, providing an adequate supply of potable water to every lot in the
subdivision. The water distribution system shall comply with this chapter, the same standards, and be subject to
the same inspections as if the subdivision were located within the corporate limits of the city.
(b) Requirements where city sewer not available. In a proposed subdivision to be located within the
extraterritorial jurisdiction of the city where city sewer may not be available, the subdivider shall install
individual sewage disposal systems or a single system for the subdivision. Such sewage systems shall be
designed and installed in compliance with the current edition of Construction Standards for On-Site Sewage
Facilities adopted by the department of state health services. Letters of approval or other acceptable evidence
that the systems have been accepted by the state shall be submitted to the city prior to the release or refund of
any bonds or deposits held by the city.
Sec. 10.03.022 Extraterritorial jurisdiction
(a) Any subdivision proposed to be located within one mile of the corporate limits of the city, within the
extraterritorial jurisdiction of the city, shall comply with this chapter, the standards referred to herein, bonds
required and applicable state laws.
(b) This chapter shall have the same force and effect within the area of extraterritorial jurisdiction as within
the corporate limits of the city, except that no violation of any provision of this chapter outside the corporate
limits of the city but within the city's area of extraterritorial jurisdiction shall constitute a misdemeanor under
this chapter.
(c) The city is entitled to appropriate injunctive relief in district court to enjoin a violation of this chapter
which occurs within the city's extraterritorial jurisdiction.
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 282/430
Sec. 10.03.023 Replatting
Any replatting of any existing subdivision or any part thereof shall comply with the provisions of Tex. Local
Gov't Code sections 212.014, 212.015 and 212.016. In no case shall lot sizes smaller than the minimum set forth
in the zoning ordinance for the zoning district of the area proposed to be replatted be permitted.
Sec. 10.03.024 Advice and cooperation; access to public ways; boundary streets in plats adjoining
unplatted property
(a) Advice and cooperation. Advice and cooperation in the preparation of plats will be freely given by the
planning and zoning commission and the director of planning and/or city secretary.
(b) Land controlling access to public ways. No subdivision or addition showing reserve strips of land
controlling the access to public ways or adjoining properties will be approved.
(c) Boundary streets in plats adjoining unplatted property. Where plats are presented for approval which
adjoins unplatted property, the owner and/or developer of the proposed subdivision shall provide his pro rata part
of the boundary streets.
Sec. 10.03.025 Requirements for final approval and issuance of building permits
(a) The final approval of a final plat of a subdivision shall be invalid unless such approved plat of such
subdivision is recorded in the office of the county clerk within 30 days after the date of its final approval by the
city council.
(b) No building permit shall be issued nor shall any utility connections be permitted by the city to the
subdivider or owner of any lot or any other persons with respect to any property in any subdivision covered by
this chapter until:
(1) The subdivider has complied with all the requirements of this chapter and the final plat
regarding improvements (utilities, street paving, or other items which may have been required); or
(2) An escrow deposit is filed with the city secretary, in the form of a surety bond, certificate of
deposit, cashier's check or other acceptable means, to assure that all the improvements that are
required for the subdivision will be installed and completed. The amount of such deposit shall be
based on the engineer's estimate as required in section 10.02.005(a)(5). Should the subdivider or
owner fail or refuse to install the required improvements within one year of the date of approval of
the subdivision by the city council, the city may make the improvements or have them made by a
contractor using the deposit held by the city to pay for such improvements. An extension of time up
to six months may be permitted upon written application to the city secretary or director of planning.
It shall be necessary for the subdivider to make application to the city council for any additional
extension of time.
ARTICLE 10.04 ADMINISTRATION
Sec. 10.04.001 City council may grant variances
Generally, the city council may authorize a variance from these regulations when, in its opinion, undue hardships
may result from strict compliance. In granting variances, the city council shall prescribe only conditions that it
deems necessary to or desirable for the public interest. In making its findings, as required herein below, the city
council shall take into account the nature of the proposed use of land and the existing use of land in the vicinity,
the number of persons to reside or work in the proposed subdivision and the probable effect of the proposed
subdivision upon traffic conditions in the vicinity. No variance shall be granted unless the council finds that
there are special circumstances or conditions affecting said property such that the strict application of the
provisions of this chapter would deprive the applicant of the reasonable use of the land; that the variance is
necessary for the preservation and enjoyment of a substantial property right of the petitioner; that the granting of
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 283/430
the variance will not be detrimental to the public welfare or injurious to other property in the territory in which
said property is situated.
Sec. 10.04.002 Planned unit development
The standards and requirements of these regulations may be varied or modified by the city council after study
and recommendation by the planning and zoning commission in order to encourage a complete or unique
residential, industrial or commercial development. Full consideration shall be given to adequate public spaces,
traffic circulation, recreation, light, air and other service needs of the development when fully developed. Deed
restrictions, covenants or other legal provisions may be imposed by the developer to assure the general character
proposed.
Sec. 10.04.003 Industrial or commercial subdivisions
An industrial or commercial subdivision shall be processed for approval in the same manner as provided for a
residential subdivision except that no individual lots need be shown on such plat and only streets, blocks,
easements and minimum building lines need be indicated. The minimum right-of-way width of a minor street in
an industrial or commercial subdivision shall be 60 feet and all other streets shall conform to the standards for
major and secondary streets prescribed by the major thoroughfare plan.
Sec. 10.04.004 Authority of city manager or director of planning to establish standards for installation
of public improvements
The city secretary and/or director of planning are hereby authorized to promulgate standards and specifications
as deemed necessary for the regulation of the installation of public improvements in a subdivision. The standards
and specifications shall be submitted to the city council for approval and shall be filed with the city secretary at
least 30 days before they become effective.
(Ordinance O-001-10 adopted 4/20/10)
Sec. 10.04.005 Fees and charges
Fees and charges as listed in article 5.000 shall be paid into the general fund of the city when any map or plat is tendered to
the planning and zoning commission and shall be paid in advance, and no action of the planning and zoning commission
shall be valid until the fee shall have been paid. (Ordinance O-008-18 adopted 9/18/18)
CHAPTER 11
TAXATION
ARTICLE 11.01 GENERAL PROVISIONS*
Sec. 11.01.001 Adoption of state law relative to payment of taxes and penalties
The provisions of state law applicable to municipalities shall apply to and govern the payment of taxes due and
owing to the city and penalties in connection therewith, to the same extent as if such provisions had been, by the
terms thereof, made applicable to city taxes by ordinances of the city. (1998 Code, sec. 35.01)
State law reference–Imposition of penalty for collection of delinquent taxes, V.T.C.A., Tax Code, secs. 33.01, 33.07, 33.08.
Sec. 11.01.002 Licenses and permits not to be issued to persons in debt to city

ARTICLE 11.02 PROPERTY TAXES†
Sec. 11.02.001 Property subject to tax; assessment
All property, real, personal and mixed, shall be subject to taxation, and assessed by the city as provided and in
accordance with the charter and state law. (1998 Code, sec. 35.02)
Sec. 11.02.002 Residence homestead exemption for elderly or disabled
That, beginning January 1, 2009, the total amount of ad valorem taxes imposed by the city on the residence
homestead of a person who is disabled or is sixty-five (65) years of age or older may not be increased while that
homestead remains the residence homestead of that person or that person's qualified spouse, as provided by
section 1-b(h), article VIII, Texas Constitution, and in accordance with provisions of the Texas Tax Code,
section 11.261 as it exists now and as may be amended, except that any statutory amendment allowing an option
for local government must be expressly adopted by separate ordinance in order to become effective in this
municipality. (Ordinance O-003-08 adopted 3/4/08)
State law reference–Residence homestead tax exemptions, V.T.C.A., Tax Code, sec. 11.13.
Sec. 11.02.003 Penalty to defray costs of collection of delinquent property taxes
The city council hereby adopts a 15% penalty to defray the costs of collection of delinquent taxes as authorized
by Tex. Tax Code, sections 33.07 and 33.08, for the current year and each succeeding year thereafter. (1998
Code, sec. 35.07)
State law reference–Imposition of penalty for collection of delinquent taxes, V.T.C.A., Tax Code, secs. 33.01, 33.07, 33.08.
Sec. 11.02.004 Leased vehicles not exempt
The city chooses not to exempt leased vehicles and will assess and levy ad valorem taxes on the vehicles as
authorized by Tex. Tax Code, section 11.252. (1998 Code, sec. 35.08)
State law reference–Authority of municipality to impose tax on leased vehicles otherwise exempted, V.T.C.A., Tax Code, sec. 11.252.
Sec. 11.02.005 Goods in transit
Goods in transit, as defined in Texas Tax Code, section 11.253(a)(2), as amended by House Bill 621, enacted by
the 80th Texas Legislature in Regular Session, shall remain subject to taxation by the city. (Ordinance O-010-07
adopted 11/6/07)
State law reference–Tax exemption for goods in transit, V.T.C.A., Tax Code, sec. 11.253.
ARTICLE 11.03 SALES AND USE TAXES*
Sec. 11.03.001 Sales and use tax on gas and electricity for residential use
The city, by majority vote of the membership of its governing body, votes to continue the taxes authorized by the
Municipal Sales and Use Tax Act (Tex. Tax Code section 321.105) on the receipts from the sale, production,
distribution, lease or rental of, and use, storage or other consumption of gas and electricity for residential use,
effective October 1, 1979, as authorized by section 6 of House Bill No. 1 Acts 1978, 65th Legislature, Second
Called Session. (1998 Code, sec. 35.06)

ARTICLE 11.04 HOTEL/MOTEL OCCUPANCY TAX†
Sec. 11.04.001 Definitions
The following words, terms and phrases, for the purpose of this article, except where the context clearly
indicates another meaning, are respectively defined as follows:
City manager. The city manager or his or her designee.
Consideration. The cost of the room, sleeping space, bed or dormitory space or other facility in such hotel and
shall not include the cost of any food served or personal services rendered to the occupant not related to cleaning
and readying such room for occupancy and shall not include any tax assessed for occupancy therefor by any
other governmental agency.
Hotel. Any building or buildings in which the public may, for a consideration, obtain sleeping accommodations.
The term shall include hotels, motels, tourist homes, houses or courts, lodginghouses, inns, roominghouses,
trailer houses, trailer motels, dormitory space (regardless of whether the bed space is rented to individuals or
groups), apartments, and all other facilities where rooms or sleeping facilities or space are furnished for a
consideration. The term “hotel” shall not be defined so as to include hospitals, sanitariums or nursing homes.
Monthly period. One (1) calendar month.
Occupancy. The use or possession, or the right to the use or possession, of any room, space or sleeping facility
in a hotel for any purpose.
(Ordinance O-012-03, sec. 2, adopted 6/17/03)
Occupant. Anyone who, for a consideration, uses, possesses, or has a right to use or possess any room or rooms,
or sleeping space or facility in a hotel under any lease, concession, permit, right of access, license, contract or
agreement. (Ordinance O-012-03, sec. 2, adopted 6/17/03; Ordinance adopting Code)
Occupant. Anyone, who, for a consideration, uses, anyone, or has a right to use or possess any room or rooms of
sleeping space or facility in hotel under any lease, concession, permit, right of access, license, contract, or
agreement.
Permanent resident. Any occupant who has or shall have the right to occupancy of any room or rooms or
sleeping space or facility in a hotel contracted for in advance of occupancy for at least thirty (30) consecutive
days during the current calendar year.
Person. Any individual, company, corporation, or association owning, operating, managing or controlling any
hotel.
(Ordinance O-012-03, sec. 2, adopted 6/17/03)
Sec. 11.04.002 Levy
There is hereby levied a tax upon the cost of occupancy of any room or space furnished by any hotel or motel
where such cost of occupancy is at the rate of two dollars ($2.00) or more per day, such tax to be equal to seven
percent (7%) of the consideration paid by the occupant of such room, space, or facility of such hotel, exclusive
of other occupancy taxes imposed by other governmental agencies. (Ordinance O-012-03, sec. 1, adopted
6/17/03)
Sec. 11.04.003 Collection
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 286/430
Every person owning, operating, managing or controlling any hotel shall collect the tax imposed in section
11.04.002 for the city. (Ordinance O-012-03, sec. 3, adopted 6/17/03)
Sec. 11.04.004 Reports
On or before the 20th day of the month following each monthly period, every person required in section
11.04.003 to collect the tax imposed herein shall file a report with the city manager showing the consideration
paid for all room or sleeping space occupancies in the preceding month, the amount of tax collected on such
occupancies, and any other information as the city manager may reasonably require. Such person shall also
submit a copy of the Texas Hotel Occupancy Tax Report No. 12-100, which is submitted to the state comptroller
for occupancy tax, to the city manager. Such person shall pay the tax due on such occupancies at the time of
filing such report. (Ordinance O-012-03, sec. 4, adopted 6/17/03)
Sec. 11.04.005 Adoption of procedures; rules and regulations; access to books and records
The city manager shall adopt such procedures, rules and regulations as are reasonably necessary to effectively
collect the tax levied herein, and shall, upon request of any person owning, operating, managing or controlling
any hotel, furnish a copy of such procedures, rules and regulations for the guidance of such person and facilitate
the collection of such tax as such collection is required herein. Such procedures, rules and regulations shall be in
writing and a copy thereof shall be placed on file with the city secretary. The city manager shall be permitted to
have access to books and records during reasonable business hours as shall be necessary to enable the city
manager to determine the correctness of the amount due under the provisions of this article, or to determine
whether or not a report should have been filed and the amount, if necessary, of taxes due. (Ordinance O-012-03,
sec. 5, adopted 6/17/03)
Sec. 11.04.006 Violations; penalties; additional enforcement actions
(a) If any person required by the provisions of this article to collect the tax imposed herein, or make reports as
required herein, and pay to the city manager the tax imposed herein, shall fail to collect such tax, file such
reports, or pay such tax, or if any such person shall file a false report, or any such person shall violate any of the
provisions of this article, such person shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction be punished
by fine as provided in section 1.01.009; and each day after the due date of reports and/or payment of such fine
shall be deemed to be a separate offense and subject to a separate fine. In addition to such fine, such person, firm
or corporation shall pay to the city manager the tax due, together with a penalty of five percent (5%) per month
or any part of a month on any delinquent tax; plus any attorney fees and court courts associated with the
collection of delinquent or fraudulent taxes.
(b) In addition to those penalties and provisions enumerated in subsection (a) of this section, the city may also
take the following actions:
(1) Bring a civil suit against the hotel/motel operator for noncompliance;
(2) Request any district court with proper jurisdiction to enjoin the hotel/motel operation for
noncompliance until the report is filed and/or the tax is paid;
(3) Assess a fifteen percent (15%) penalty of the current arrearage of taxes due;
(4) Request that any appropriate district court close down the hotel/motel if the occupancy taxes
are not remitted. Such request shall require only a ten-day nonjudicial notice to the hotel/motel
operator or that notice date decreed by the district court.
(c) Hotel/motel operators shall provide the city with the proper name, address and telephone number of the
real owners of interest in the facility or complex, including all operations in the city.
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 287/430
(1) If the owners do not physically reside in city or the extraterritorial jurisdiction of the city or are
corporations, limited liability corporations, or partnerships, an agent must be designated for process
of service, either by virtue of an assumed name certificate filed with the county clerk or by written
designation.
(2) Should this information not be provided, any summons issued by the municipal court of the
city may be served upon the local manager of the facility compelling appearance to answer citations
and/or complaints as if the entity or owners had designated the individual as the local agent.
(3) Failure to appear for any such summons and/or subpoena may then be considered by the
municipal court as a further violation of this article, and additional fines and penalties assessed, as
well as arrest warrants issued as appropriate.
(Ordinance O-012-03, sec. 6, adopted 6/17/03)
Sec. 11.04.007 Sale of properties
Should there be a sale of properties by current operators and/or owners, then in that event the following
requirements and actions shall be in force and enforceable:
(1) Retention by buyer of delinquent taxes, plus penalties and interest.
(A) The purchaser shall retain out of the purchase price an amount sufficient to recover any
delinquent hotel/motel occupancy taxes due the city, including any penalties, interest, attorney's
fees, or other costs included in any judicial judgment awarding same to the city;
(Ordinance O-012-03, sec. 7, adopted 6/17/03)
(B) If the purchaser does not remit such amounts or show proof that the hotel/motel is current
in remitting such occupancy taxes, the purchaser becomes liable for any delinquent hotel/motel
occupancy taxes due, including all penalties, interest and assessments, either judicial or
nonjudicial. (Ordinance O-012-03, sec. 7, adopted 6/17/03; Ordinance adopting Code)
(2) Rights of purchaser. In addition to the above enumerated terms, the following shall also apply:
(Ordinance O-012-03, sec. 7, adopted 6/17/03)
(A) The purchaser of a hotel/motel may request that the city provide a receipt showing that
no hotel/motel occupancy taxes or assessments are due; (Ordinance O-012-03, sec. 7, adopted
6/17/03; Ordinance adopting Code)
(B) The city shall be required to file this statement not later than the 60th day after is
received by the city, and upon proof of said pending sale proposed transfer of title;
(C) If the city fails to issue such statement within this time frame, without justification of
delay, the purchaser is relieved of the obligation to withhold the amount due from the purchase
price, but is not relieved of the liability of the debt due.
(Ordinance O-012-03, sec. 7, adopted 6/17/03)
Sec. 11.04.008 Exemptions
(a) State statute exempts the following individuals from the payment of the local hotel/motel occupancy tax if
they are traveling on official business:
(1) Federal employees;
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 288/430
(2) Foreign diplomats with a tax exempt card issued by the U.S. Department of State;
(3) State employees with a hotel tax exemption card (heads of state agencies, state legislators and
legislative staff, members of state boards and commissions, and state judges);
(4) Individuals who have contracted to use a hotel room for more than thirty (30) days.
(b) Additionally, other state employees, such as employees of a state agency, institution, board or commission,
who are traveling on official business, are also exempt from the local hotel/motel occupancy tax. However, such
state employees shall pay the hotel/motel occupancy tax when paying their bill. The state agency is then
responsible for requesting a refund from the appropriate county or municipal government. See exhibit A to
Ordinance O-012-03 for further illustration of the exemptions.
(Ordinance O-012-03, sec. 8, adopted 6/17/03)
CHAPTER 12
TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES
ARTICLE 12.01 GENERAL PROVISIONS
Sec. 12.01.001 Definitions
For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or
requires a different meaning:
Alley. A street that:
(1) Is not used primarily for through traffic; and
(2) Provides access to rear entrances of buildings or lots along a street.
Authorized emergency vehicle.
(1) A fire department or police vehicle;
(2) A public or private ambulance operated by a person who has been issued a license by the
department of state health services;
(3) A municipal department or public service corporation emergency vehicle that has been
designated or authorized by the governing body of a municipality;
(4) A private vehicle of a volunteer firefighter or a certified emergency medical services employee
or volunteer when responding to a fire alarm or medical emergency;
(5) An industrial emergency response vehicle, including an industrial ambulance, when responding
to an emergency, but only if the vehicle is operated in compliance with criteria in effect September 1,
1989, and established by the Texas Industrial Fire Training Board of the State Firemen's and Fire
Marshals' Association of Texas; or
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 289/430
(6) A vehicle of a blood bank or tissue bank, accredited or approved under the laws of this state or
the United States, when making emergency deliveries of blood, drugs, medicines or organs.
Business district. The territory adjacent to and including a highway if buildings used for business or industrial
purposes, including a building used as a hotel, bank, office building, public building, or railroad station:
(1) Are located within a 600-foot segment along the highway; and
(2) Within that segment the buildings occupy at least 300 feet of frontage:
(A) On one side of the highway; or
(B) Collectively on both sides of the highway.
Crosswalk.
(1) The portion of a roadway, including an intersection, designated as a pedestrian crossing by
surface markings, including lines; or
(2) The portion of a roadway at an intersection that is within the connections of the lateral lines of
the sidewalks on opposite sides of the highway measured from the curbs or, in absence of curbs, from
the edges of the traversable roadway.
Digging out. The practice of starting any motor vehicle from a standing position by applying a sudden burst of
power, recognized by spinning rear wheels and noise of tires on the surface of the roadway.
Highway or street. The width between the boundary lines of a publicly maintained way, any part of which is
open to the public for vehicular travel.
Intersection.
(1) The common area at the junction of two highways, other than the junction of an alley and a
highway.
(2) The dimensions of an intersection include only the common area:
(A) Within the connection of the lateral curblines or, in the absence of curblines, the lateral
boundary lines of the roadways of intersecting highways that join at approximate right angles;
or
(B) At the place where vehicles could collide if traveling on roadways of intersecting
highways that join at any angle other than an approximate right angle.
(3) Each junction of each roadway of a highway that includes two roadways at least 30 feet apart
with the roadway of an intersecting highway, including each roadway of an intersecting highway that
includes two roadways at least 30 feet apart, is a separate intersection.
Laned roadway. A roadway that is divided into at least two clearly marked lanes for vehicular travel.
Loading zone. That portion of any roadway set apart, marked and numbered for the sole use of the public as a
place for loading or unloading passengers, merchandise or other cargo.
Motor vehicle. A self-propelled vehicle or a vehicle that is propelled by electric power from overhead trolley
wires.
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 290/430
No-parking zone. A space on the roadway adjacent to the curb, whether marked by official signs or not, in which
no vehicle may be parked.
Official traffic-control device. A sign, signal, marking, or device that is:
(1) Consistent with this chapter;
(2) Placed or erected by a public body or officer having jurisdiction; and
(3) Used to regulate, warn or guide traffic.
Operator. As used in reference to a vehicle, a person who drives or has physical control of a vehicle.
Park or parking. To stand an occupied or unoccupied vehicle, other than temporarily while loading or unloading
merchandise or passengers.
Parking stall or parking space. That portion or section of a roadway adjacent to the curbing or edge, set apart,
marked and bounded by lines painted or marked upon the surface of the roadway and extending into the
roadway for the use of parking vehicles; or that portion of any alley marked by official signs showing such space
to be a parking zone.
Pedestrian. Any person on foot.
Police officer. An officer authorized to direct traffic or arrest persons who violate traffic regulations.
Right-of-way. The right of one vehicle or pedestrian to proceed in a lawful manner in preference to another
vehicle or pedestrian that is approaching from a direction, at a speed, and within a proximity that could cause a
collision unless one grants precedence to the other.
Roadway. The portion of a highway, other than the berm or shoulder, that is improved, designed or ordinarily
used for vehicular travel. If a highway includes at least two separate roadways, the term “roadway” applies to
each roadway separately.
Safety zone. The area in a roadway officially designated for exclusive pedestrian use and that is protected or so
marked or indicated by adequate signs as to be plainly visible at all times while so designated.
Sidewalk. The portion of a street that is:
(1) Between a curb or lateral line of a roadway and the adjacent property line; and
(2) Intended for pedestrian use.
Stand or standing. To halt an occupied or unoccupied vehicle, other than temporarily while receiving or
discharging passengers.
Stop or stopping.
(1) When required, means to completely cease movement; and
(2) When prohibited, means to halt, including momentarily halting, an occupied or unoccupied
vehicle, unless necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or to comply with the directions of a
police officer or traffic-control sign or signal.
Traffic. Pedestrians, ridden or herded animals, and conveyances, including vehicles and streetcars, singly or
together, while using a highway for purposes of travel.
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 291/430
Traffic-control signal. A manual, electric or mechanical device that alternately directs traffic to stop and to
proceed.
Truck. A motor vehicle designed, used or maintained primarily to transport property.
Vehicle. A device that can be used to transport or draw persons or property on a highway. The term does not
include:
(1) A device exclusively used on stationary rails or tracks; or
(2) Manufactured housing as that term is defined by the Texas Manufactured Housing Standards
Act (V.T.C.A., Occupations Code, chapter 1201).
(1998 Code, sec. 70.01; Ordinance adopting Code)
Sec. 12.01.002 Penalty
Whenever in this chapter an act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or a misdemeanor, or
wherever in this chapter the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful,
and no specific penalty is otherwise provided in this code, the violation shall be punished by a fine not
exceeding the amount as provided in section 1.01.009 of this code; provided, however, that no penalty shall be
greater or less than the penalty provided for the same or a similar offense of the laws of the state. Each day a
violation of this chapter or of any ordinance continues shall constitute a separate offense. (1998 Code, sec.
70.99)
Sec. 12.01.003 Purpose
The purpose of the regulations prescribed by this chapter is to insure to the people the maximum use and benefit
of the public streets of the city and yet retain the maximum degree of safety to prevent injury to person and
property. (1998 Code, sec. 70.02)
Sec. 12.01.004 Riding on portion of vehicle not intended for passengers
No person shall ride on any vehicle upon any portion thereof not designated or intended for the use of
passengers. This provision shall not apply to any employee engaged in the necessary discharge of a duty, or to
persons riding within truck bodies in space intended for merchandise. (1998 Code, sec. 70.08)
Sec. 12.01.005 Boarding or alighting from moving vehicle
No person shall board or alight from any vehicle while such vehicle is in motion. (1998 Code, sec. 70.10)
Sec. 12.01.006 Use of toy vehicles on roadway
No person upon roller skates, or riding in or by means of any coaster, skateboard, toy vehicle or similar device,
shall go upon any roadway, except while crossing a street on a crosswalk, and when so crossing, such person
shall be granted all of the rights and shall be subject to all of the duties applicable to pedestrians. (1998 Code,
sec. 70.12)
Sec. 12.01.007 Depositing injurious substances on streets
No person shall throw or deposit upon any street or alley any glass bottle, glass, nails, tacks, wire, cans or any
other substance likely to injure any person, animal or vehicle upon such street or alley. (1998 Code, sec.
70.13(a); Ordinance adopting Code)
ARTICLE 12.02 ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 292/430
Sec. 12.02.001 Authority of police officers and fire officials to direct traffic
(a) Officers of the police department or such officers as are assigned by the chief of police are hereby
authorized to direct all traffic by voice, hand or signal in conformance with this chapter and other traffic laws. In
the event of fire or other emergency or to expedite traffic or to safeguard pedestrians, officers of the police
department may direct traffic as conditions may require notwithstanding the provisions of this chapter and other
traffic laws.
(b) Officers of the fire department, when at the scene of a fire, may direct or assist the police in directing
traffic thereat or in the immediate vicinity.
(1998 Code, sec. 70.65)
Sec. 12.02.002 Traffic engineer
(a) Office created. There is hereby created in and for the city the office of city traffic engineer. The authority,
powers and duties of the traffic engineer are hereby equally vested in the chief of police.
(b) Duties relative to traffic. It shall be the duty of the city traffic engineer to determine the installation and
proper timing and maintenance of traffic-control devices, to conduct engineering analyses of traffic accidents
and to devise remedial measures, to conduct engineering investigations of traffic conditions, to plan the
operation of traffic on the streets and highways of the city for the purpose of making recommendations to the
city council in regard thereto, and to cooperate with other city officials in the development of ways and means to
improve traffic conditions, and to carry out the additional powers and duties imposed by ordinances of the city.
(1998 Code, sec. 70.67)
Sec. 12.02.003 Temporary and experimental regulations
(a) The chief of police, or the city traffic engineer, by and with the approval of the city manager, is hereby
empowered to make regulations necessary to make effective the provisions of this chapter or other traffic
ordinances of this city and to make and enforce temporary or experimental regulations to cover emergencies or
special conditions. No such temporary or experimental regulation shall remain in effect for more than 90 days.
(b) The chief of police or the city traffic engineer may test traffic-control devices under actual conditions of
traffic.
(1998 Code, sec. 70.68)
ARTICLE 12.03 ACCIDENTS*
Sec. 12.03.001 Accident reports required
When the driver or operator of a vehicle is unable physically to make the required accident report, if there were
other occupants of the vehicle at the time of the accident capable of making the report, such occupant or
occupants shall make or cause to be made such report. (1998 Code, sec. 70.29(c); Ordinance adopting Code)
State law reference–Written accident reports, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code, sec. 550.061 et seq.
Sec. 12.03.002 Record of accident reports
The police department shall maintain a suitable system of filing traffic accident reports. Accident reports or
cards referring to them shall be filed alphabetically by location. Such reports shall be available for the use and
information of the city traffic engineer. (1998 Code, sec. 70.30)
Sec. 12.03.003 Moving or removal of vehicles by wrecker trucks
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 293/430
It shall be unlawful for the operator of any vehicle equipped with a crane, hoist, winch, or towing device who
has answered a call to, or is attending the scene of, any collision or accident of one or more vehicles on any
highway or street in the city to remove or attempt to remove any vehicle involved in such collision or accident,
or in any way to interfere with or change the position of any such vehicle, except upon authority or direction and
in the presence of a police officer of the city, unless such change is made or attempted for the purpose of
releasing a person imprisoned within or under such vehicle; provided, however, that it shall be unlawful for the
operator of any vehicle equipped with a crane, hoist, winch, or towing device to remove a vehicle from the scene
of accident or collision without the consent of the owner of the vehicle, unless directed by a police officer to
remove such vehicle as a public safety measure or for the protection of private property. (1998 Code, sec. 70.31)
ARTICLE 12.04 TRAFFIC-CONTROL DEVICES†
Sec. 12.04.001 Adoption of official map
There is hereby adopted by reference a map or plat of all official traffic-control devices authorized by and
erected or installed pursuant to the provisions of this article and the other provisions of this chapter relative to
speed limits and parking restrictions. Such map shall indicate by appropriate symbols the location and type of
each such traffic-control device. Such map shall be on file in the office of the city secretary. (1998 Code, sec.
70.45)
Sec. 12.04.002 Conformity with specifications of state
All traffic-control signs, signals and devices shall conform to the manual and specifications approved by the
state transportation commission. All signs and signals required under this chapter for a particular purpose shall,
so far as practicable, be uniform as to type and location throughout the city. All traffic-control devices so erected
and not inconsistent with the provisions of state law or this chapter shall be official traffic-control devices. (1998
Code, sec. 70.46)
State law reference–Adoption of sign manual and specifications, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code, sec. 544.001.
Sec. 12.04.003 Authority of traffic engineer
(a) General powers and duties.
(1) The city traffic engineer shall place and maintain traffic-control signs, signals and devices
when and as required under this chapter to make effective the provisions of this chapter, and may
place and maintain such additional traffic-control devices as he may deem necessary to regulate
traffic under this chapter or under state law, or to guide or warn traffic. It shall be the duty of the city
traffic engineer to supervise the installation and proper timing and maintenance of traffic-control
devices.
(2) The city traffic engineer shall make a written memorandum in duplicate reflecting the need as
found in investigations for all traffic-control devices, and the location and date of erecting the same.
The original shall be filed with the city secretary and a duplicate retained by the city traffic engineer.
(b) Installation of traffic lights. The city traffic engineer, as authorized by the city council from time to time,
shall designate intersections at which traffic shall be controlled by electric traffic-control signals or lights and
shall cause such signals or lights to be installed and maintained at such intersections.
(c) Designation of crosswalks and safety zones and marking of traffic lanes. The city traffic engineer is hereby
authorized to:
(1) Designate and maintain, by appropriate devices, marks or lines upon the surface of the
roadway, crosswalks at any intersection where, in his opinion, there is particular danger to
pedestrians crossing the roadway and at such other places as he may deem necessary.
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 294/430
(2) Establish safety zones of such kind and character and at such places as he may deem necessary
for the protection of pedestrians.
(3) Mark lanes for traffic on street pavements at such places as he may deem advisable, consistent
with this chapter and other traffic ordinances of this city.
(4) Designate and maintain school zones and crosswalks with appropriate pavement markings,
signs and/or signals in such locations necessary for the safety of children going to and from school.
(1998 Code, sec. 70.47)
Sec. 12.04.004 Ratification of existing devices
All traffic-control signs, signals, devices, and markings placed or erected prior to the adoption of this code and
in use for the purpose of regulating, warning or guiding traffic are hereby affirmed, ratified and declared to be
official traffic-control devices, provided such traffic-control devices are not inconsistent with the provisions of
this chapter or state law. (1998 Code, sec. 70.49)
ARTICLE 12.05 TRAFFIC RULES
Division 1. Generally
Sec. 12.05.001 Limitations on turning around
The driver of any vehicle shall not turn such vehicle so as to proceed in the opposite direction upon any street in
a business district; and shall not upon any other street so turn a vehicle unless such movement can be made in
safety and without interfering with other traffic; and at no intersection controlled by a traffic-control sign or
signal. (1998 Code, sec. 71.08)
State law reference–Safely turning, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code, sec. 545.103.
Sec. 12.05.002 Obstructing traffic
No driver shall enter an intersection or a marked crosswalk unless there is sufficient space on the other side of
the intersection or crosswalk to accommodate the vehicle he is operating without obstructing the passage of
other vehicles or pedestrians, notwithstanding any traffic-control signal indication to proceed. (1998 Code, sec.
71.12(b); Ordinance adopting Code)
Sec. 12.05.003 Funerals, parades, and other processions
(a) Funeral processions. Every funeral procession shall be marked with appropriate pennants or other devices
or methods, such as burning headlights in daytime, sufficient to show the nature of such procession. Police
officers leading funeral processions or assisting in the movement of funeral processions, together with
automobiles in such funeral processions, shall, and the same are hereby authorized, to proceed through red lights
and stop signs, and all persons approaching such traffic-control devices at intersections shall, notwithstanding
any traffic-control device, yield the right-of-way to such police officers and funeral processions.
(b) Driving through processions. No driver of a vehicle shall drive between the vehicles comprising a funeral
or other authorized procession while they are in motion and when such vehicles are conspicuously designated.
This provision shall not apply to authorized emergency vehicles.
(c) Driving in procession. Each driver in a funeral or other procession shall drive as near to the right-hand
edge of the roadway as practical and shall follow the vehicle ahead as close as is practical and safe.
(d) Permit for parades and processions. No parade or procession, excepting the forces of the United States
army, navy, air force or marines, the military forces of the state, and the forces of the police and fire
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 295/430
departments, shall occupy, march or proceed along any street, sidewalk or any other public place or way in the
city, except in accordance with a permit therefor issued by the chief of police and such other regulations as are
set forth herein which may apply.
(1998 Code, sec. 71.15)
Sec. 12.05.004 One-way streets and alleys
(a) Whenever any ordinance of the city council designates any one-way street or alley, the city traffic engineer
shall place and maintain signs giving notice thereof, and no such regulations shall be effective unless such signs
are in place. Signs indicating the direction of lawful traffic movement shall be placed at every intersection where
movement of traffic in the opposite direction is prohibited.
(b) Upon those streets and parts of streets and in those alleys which are designated as one-way streets or
alleys, vehicular traffic shall move only in the indicated direction where signs indicating the direction of traffic
are erected and maintained at every intersection where movement in the opposite direction is prohibited.
(1998 Code, sec. 71.16)
Sec. 12.05.005 Driving on fresh pavement
It shall be unlawful for any person to drive any vehicle upon any portion of any street in the city that has been
freshly paved, unless all barriers or signal lights have been lawfully removed therefrom indicating that the street
is ready for travel. (1998 Code, sec. 71.18)
Sec. 12.05.006 Operating vehicle off of designated roadways or parking lots
It shall be unlawful for any person to drive or operate any vehicle whatsoever through or upon, or to park such
vehicle upon, any park, hospital grounds or other public property within the city except upon official, designated
roadways or parking lots. (1998 Code, sec. 71.19)
Sec. 12.05.007 Digging out prohibited
Any driver of any motor vehicle who shall cause such vehicle to “dig out” or shall cause any such vehicle to
make unnecessary noise by reason of operating such vehicle in such a manner as to cause the wheels thereof to
spin or slide on the roadway of any street when starting such vehicle or while making any turning movement
shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. (1998 Code, sec. 71.20)
Sec. 12.05.008 Control of vehicle; duty to avoid collision
It shall be the duty of every person who shall operate any vehicle within the city to keep the same under control
at all times and to avoid whenever possible colliding with any other vehicle or person. (1998 Code, sec. 71.21)
Sec. 12.05.009 Truck routes
(a) The city traffic engineer, as authorized from time to time by the city council, may designate such truck
routes within the city as may be necessary for the proper flow of traffic through the city.
(b) It shall be unlawful for any truck with a gross vehicle weight rating of over 18,000 pounds (or 18,000
pounds gross cargo weight rating in the case of a truck-trailer or tractor-trailer unit) to use, travel upon or be
driven over any street, avenue or highway within the city not designated as a truck route in subsection (a);
provided, however, that if the point of origin or destination, for commercial purposes only, for any such truck
shall be off such truck route, then such truck may proceed by the shortest possible route to the nearest truck
route.
(1998 Code, sec. 71.27)
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 296/430
Secs. 12.05.010–12.05.050 Reserved
Division 2. Intersections
Sec. 12.05.051 Stop intersections
The city traffic engineer, with the approval of the city council, is hereby authorized to determine and designate
any street intersection as a stop intersection and designate the streets upon which vehicles shall stop before
entering such intersection. Whenever any intersection has been so designated, the city traffic engineer shall
cause the same to be identified by the erection of stop signs indicating which vehicles approaching the
intersection shall stop. (1998 Code, sec. 71.40(a); Ordinance adopting Code)
State law reference–Authority to designate stop intersections, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code, secs. 542.202, 544.003.
Sec. 12.05.052 Yield intersections
The city traffic engineer, as authorized from time to time by the city council, may install and maintain yieldright-
of-way signs at intersections where a special hazard may exist anywhere vehicles shall be required to yield
the right-of-way. (1998 Code, sec. 71.41; Ordinance adopting Code)
State law reference–Authority to designate yield intersections, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code, secs. 542.202, 544.003.
Secs. 12.05.053–12.05.080 Reserved
Division 3. Speed
Sec. 12.05.081 Speed limits on specific streets
The city council may alter the maximum speed limit of 30 miles per hour on any street or portion thereof within
the city in accord with the provisions of Tex. Transp. Code section 545.356. Whenever signs are posted giving
notice of the maximum legal speed limit so established for a particular street or portion thereof, it shall be
unlawful for any person to drive or operate any vehicle at a rate of speed in excess of such limit. (1998 Code,
sec. 71.57; Ordinance adopting Code)
State law references–Authority to establish or alter prima facie speed limits, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code, sec. 542.202(12);
authority of municipality to alter speed limits, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code, sec. 545.356.
Sec. 12.05.082 Speed limit in school zones
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or drive any vehicle at a speed greater than 20 miles per hour
through any school zone as may be marked or designated by signs within the city from 8:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. on
days when school is in session or during the period that yellow signal lights are flashing in conjunction with a
sign indicating a speed limit of 20 miles per hour or whenever children are present in such zones. (1998 Code,
sec. 71.58)
Sec. 12.05.083 Maximum speed in alleys
It shall be unlawful for any person to drive any vehicle at a rate of speed in excess of 20 miles per hour upon any
alley within the city limits. (1998 Code, sec. 71.61)
ARTICLE 12.06 STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING*
Sec. 12.06.001 Designation of areas where parking prohibited or limited; overtime parking
(a) The city traffic engineer shall cause parking stalls to be maintained and marked off in and on such streets
and parts thereof as may be designated by the city council from time to time, and he shall cause spaces in which
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 297/430
parking is prohibited to be maintained and marked off in and on such streets and parts thereof as may be
designated by the city council from time to time. The traffic engineer shall also cause time limit parking areas to
be maintained and marked off in and on such part or parts of streets as may be designated by the city council
from time to time. All such spaces or areas shall be clearly indicated by appropriate signs or by markings on the
pavement or curb.
(1) In areas designated as time limit parking areas, parking may be limited to any period prescribed
by the city council, the same to be designated with clearly distinguished markings or signs at both
ends of the time limit area and at reasonable intervals between the beginning and ending of such time
limit area, indicating the time allowed for parking in such area.
(2) Any prohibition of or time limit on parking established under this section shall apply on such
days and between such hours as prescribed by the city council.
(b) It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, allow, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in his name or
owned or operated by him or in his possession or under his control to be or remain in any space or area in which
parking is prohibited as provided in subsection (a) above, or in a time limit parking area for a longer period of
time than that designated by the markings on the street or by signs clearly visible.
(1998 Code, sec. 72.02)
Sec. 12.06.002 Parking or standing in alleys
(a) No person shall park a vehicle within an alley in such a manner or under such conditions as to block the
free passage of other vehicles in such alleys.
(b) It shall be unlawful for any person to park a vehicle in any alley within blocks 28, 29, 36, 37, 44 and 45,
original townsite, except when such vehicle is actually being used for the purpose of loading or unloading of
merchandise.
(1998 Code, sec. 72.03)
Sec. 12.06.003 Parking near hazardous or congested places
(a) The city traffic engineer, with the approval of the city council, is hereby authorized to determine and
designate by proper signs places in which the stopping, standing or parking of vehicles would create an
especially hazardous condition or would cause unusual delay to traffic.
(b) When official signs are erected at hazardous or congested places as authorized by this section, no person
shall stop, stand or park a vehicle in any such designated place.
(1998 Code, sec. 72.04)
Sec. 12.06.004 Parking for certain purposes
No person shall park a vehicle upon any street for the principal purpose of:
(1) Displaying such vehicle for sale.
(2) Washing, greasing or repairing such vehicle, except repairs necessitated by an emergency.
(3) Sale or disposal of goods, wares or merchandise from such vehicle.
(1998 Code, sec. 72.05)
Sec. 12.06.005 All-night parking
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 298/430
No person shall park a vehicle on any business street or through street for a period of time longer than 30
minutes between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 5:00 a.m. of any day, except physicians on emergency calls, where
signs prohibit such parking. (1998 Code, sec. 72.06)
Sec. 12.06.006 Ten feet of roadway to be available for traffic
No person shall stop, stand or park any vehicle upon a street in such a manner or under such conditions as to
leave available less than ten feet of width of either lane of a roadway for free movement of the vehicular traffic,
except that a driver may stop temporarily during the actual loading or unloading of passengers or when
necessary in obedience to traffic regulations or traffic signs or signals of a police officer. (1998 Code, sec. 72.09)
Sec. 12.06.007 Vehicles in excess of certain length prohibited from parking in central business district
It shall be unlawful for any person to park any vehicle, trailer or combination thereof on the streets, alleys or
other public ways of the city in the central business district, as defined in the zoning ordinance, which shall
exceed 25 feet in length. (1998 Code, sec. 72.10)
Sec. 12.06.008 Unauthorized designation of parking restriction
It shall be unlawful for any person to paint or cause to be painted upon any sidewalk, curb, alley, street or
commons within the city limits, or place or cause to be placed upon any sidewalk, curb, alley, street or commons
within the city, a sign or marker of any kind or character designating a reserve zone, no-parking zone, loading
zone or restricted parking zone of any kind or character unless such person has been authorized to do so by the
city council. (1998 Code, sec. 72.12)
ARTICLE 12.07 PEDESTRIANS*
Sec. 12.07.001 Applicability of traffic regulations
Pedestrians shall be subject to traffic-control signals as provided in this chapter, but at all other places
pedestrians shall be granted those rights and be subject to those restrictions stated in this article. (1998 Code,
sec. 73.01)
Sec. 12.07.002 Crossing roadway at right angles
No pedestrian shall cross a roadway at any place other than by a route at right angles to the curb or by the
shortest route to the opposite curb, except in crosswalks. (1998 Code, sec. 73.06)

CHAPTER 13
UTILITIES
ARTICLE 13.01 GENERAL PROVISIONS*
Sec. 13.01.001 Provisions of chapter incorporated in service contracts
All applicable provisions of this chapter shall be deemed to be incorporated in every contract between the city
and its consumers and customers using any utility service furnished by the city, and they are hereby specifically
charged with the duty and responsibility of knowing the provisions of this chapter and, by applying for or
accepting any such utility service from the city, are deemed to have assented to the provisions of this chapter.
(1998 Code, sec. 51.001)
Sec. 13.01.002 Nonliability of city
The city shall not be liable for any damage to the property of any consumer of any utility service furnished by
the city due to backflow of the sewer system or any other cause outside the direct control of the city. (1998
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 302/430
Code, sec. 51.002)
Sec. 13.01.003 Rights and duties of city council
The city council shall at all times have the right and it shall be its duty to:
(1) Prescribe rules and regulations pertaining to and providing for the manner and method of
operating the city's utility systems;
(2) Provide for their extension and improvement;
(3) Provide for such deposits as in its opinion are reasonable and required;
(4) Enter into valid contracts with property owners within and without the corporate limits of the
city for the extension of water and sewer services, not in conflict with applicable provisions of this
code, state law or city ordinances, rules or regulations; and
(5) Prescribe charges for such services.
(1998 Code, sec. 51.003)
Sec. 13.01.004 Creation of water and sewer utility department
There is hereby created in and for the city the water and sewer utility department of the city, which shall be
known as the water and sewer utility department for the purposes of this chapter, which department shall
embrace the entire waterworks system and the sewer system of the city. (1998 Code, sec. 51.004)
Sec. 13.01.005 Disposal of trash, dirt or other material in drainage ditch
It shall be unlawful for any person to dispose of or dump any trash, dirt or any other material, other than natural
stormwaters, in natural drainage ditches within the city. (1998 Code, sec. 51.005)
Sec. 13.01.006 Impeding watercourse or drainage ditch
It shall be unlawful for any person to stop, divert, change, dam, impound or impede the flow of any watershed
course, drainageway, ditch or other passageway, either natural or created by the city, which serves the purpose of
draining surface water from public rights-of-way in the city; provided, however, nothing in this section shall be
construed as restricting the authority of the city, in the exercise of its legal right, to direct, order or authorize
such changes or disposition of the watercourses as the city council shall deem advisable and to the best interest
of the city. (1998 Code, sec. 51.006)
Sec. 13.01.007 Water or sewer service outside city limits
The city shall be authorized to furnish water or sewer service to consumers outside the city limits at a rate of one
and one-half times (150%) the current rate charged to consumers inside the city limits as set forth in section
13.04.010, water rates, and section 13.05.002, Charges for the use of Municipal Wastewater Facilities and
Monthly Water Consumption. The City Council may also, by resolution or contract, upon such terms, conditions
and rates, provide service for industrial consumers outside the city limits. However, nothing in this section shall
be construed to compel the city to furnish such consumers beyond the corporate limits or to continue such
supply once begun; and the city reserves the right to furnish such consumers it deems advisable and to, at any
time, wholly or partially discontinue the supply upon violation of any of the terms of this Chapter as if the
consumer resided within the city. (Ordinance O-021-05, sec. 51.007, adopted 12/20/05)
ARTICLE 13.02 WATER SERVICE*
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 303/430
Division 1. Generally
Sec. 13.02.001 Prohibited acts
It shall be unlawful for any person, except a member of the fire department or other authorized employee of the
city, to open or use water from a fire hydrant, or to take off the cap of a fire hydrant, or to commit or assist in
committing any of the following acts:
(1) Placing any telegraph, telephone, or electric light pole, or any other obstruction whatsoever,
within three feet of any fire hydrant;
(2) Resorting to any fraudulent device or arrangement for the purpose of procuring water for
himself or others from private connections or premises contrary to the provisions of this code or city
regulation or ordinance;
(3) Turning on or off without authority from the city the water in any street hydrant or other water
fixture, or hitching or tying any animal thereto;
(4) Making or assisting in making or permitting to be made any connections with the mains or
service pipes of the waterworks system of the city or turning on or using the water of the system
without first obtaining a permit;
(5) Covering or concealing from view any water valve box, service or meter box;
(6) Removing any water meter that has been placed by the city, or in any manner changing,
interfering with or tampering with any water meter; provided the provisions of this subsection shall
not apply to the employees of the city when acting in their official capacity;
(7) Turning on the water supply to any building or supply pipe where the supply has been turned
off for the nonpayment of the water charge or for the violation of any provision of this code or city
rule or ordinance governing the water system;
(8) Doing or causing to be done any act that shall hinder or delay the city in its operation of its
water system, or with the intent to defraud the city.
(1998 Code, sec. 51.056)
Sec. 13.02.002 Use of water from fire hydrants
Under no conditions shall fire hydrants be used for furnishing water except for fire department or sewer and
street service; provided, however, that the utilities customer service manager, by and with the consent and
approval of the city manager, may grant a special permit in writing to contractors or others engaged in street
improvement or other construction work, under such regulations as may be prescribed by the city manager, to
use water from not more than one opening on a fire hydrant, the water to be measured and paid for as provided
in this chapter. (1998 Code, sec. 51.056)
Sec. 13.02.003 Repair of service pipes
The city reserves the right to make all repairs and renewals of service pipes from main to meter, but may
authorize licensed plumbers to make such repairs and renewals. (1998 Code, sec. 51.057)
Sec. 13.02.004 Temporary interruption of service
The right is reserved by the city to temporarily discontinue and to reconnect without notice water supply to all
consumers for the purpose of making repairs, connections, extensions and cleaning of mains, machinery,
reservoirs or any part of the city's waterworks system. (1998 Code, sec. 51.058)
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 304/430
Secs. 13.02.005–13.02.030 Reserved
Division 2. Drought Contingency Plan*
Sec. 13.02.031 Declaration of policy, purpose and intent
(a) In order to conserve the available water supply and protect the integrity of water supply facilities, with
particular regard for domestic water use, sanitation, and fire protection and to protect and preserve public health,
safety, and welfare and to minimize the adverse impacts of water supply shortage or other water supply
emergency conditions, the municipal water system hereby adopts the following regulations and restrictions on
the delivery and consumption of water through an ordinance.
(b) Water uses regulated or prohibited under this drought contingency plan (the plan) are considered to be
nonessential and continuation of such uses during times of water shortage or other emergency water supply
conditions are deemed to constitute a waste of water which subjects the offender(s) to penalties as defined in
section 13.02.041, enforcement, of this plan.
(Ordinance O-07-05, sec. 51.059(A), adopted 9/6/05)
Sec. 13.02.032 Public involvement
Opportunity for the public and wholesale water customers to provide input into the preparation of the plan was
provided by the municipal water system by means of a public meeting to accept input into the plan. (Ordinance
O-07-05, sec. 51.059(B), adopted 9/6/05)
Sec. 13.02.033 Wholesale and retail water customer education
The municipal water system will periodically provide wholesale water customers and the public with
information about the plan, including information about the conditions under which each stage of the plan is to
be initiated or terminated and the drought response measures to be implemented in each stage. This information
will be provided by means of the public access channel of the local cable television company for the city. Also,
wholesale customers or the general public may request a copy of the plan at any time during normal business
hours at the office of the utility director at City Hall, 600 N. Main, Borger, Texas 79007. (Ordinance O-07-05,
sec. 51.059(C), adopted 9/6/05)
Sec. 13.02.034 Coordination with regional planning groups
The water service area of the municipal water system is located within the Panhandle Water Planning Area,
Region (A), and the municipal water system has provided a copy of the plan to the Panhandle Water Planning
Area, Region (A), located in the Panhandle Groundwater Conservation District, P.O. Box 637, White Deer,
Texas 79097. (Ordinance O-07-05, sec. 51.059(D), adopted 9/6/05)
Sec. 13.02.035 Authorization
The mayor, or his/her designee, is hereby authorized and directed to implement the applicable provisions of this
plan upon determination that such implementation is necessary to protect public health, safety, and welfare. The
mayor, or his/her designee, shall have the authority to initiate or terminate drought or other water supply
emergency response measures as described in this plan. (Ordinance O-07-05, sec. 51.059(E), adopted 9/6/05)
Sec. 13.02.036 Application
The provisions of this plan shall apply to all persons, customers, and property utilizing water provided by the
municipal water system. The terms “person” and “customer” as used in the plan include individuals,
corporations, partnerships, associations, and all other legal entities. (Ordinance O-07-05, sec. 51.059(F), adopted
9/6/05)

Sec. 13.02.037 Definitions
For the purposes of this plan, the following definitions shall apply:
Aesthetic water use. Water use for ornamental or decorative purposes such as fountains, reflecting pools, and
water gardens.
Commercial and institutional water use. Water which is integral to the operations of commercial and nonprofit
establishments and government entities such as retail establishments, hotels and motels, restaurants, and office
buildings.
Conservation. Those practices, techniques, and technologies that reduce the consumption of water, reduce the
loss or waste of water, improve the efficiency in the use of water or increase the recycling and reuse of water so
that a supply is conserved and made available for future or alternative uses.
Customer. Any person, company, or organization using water supplied by the municipal water system.
Domestic water use. Water use for personal needs or for household or sanitary purposes such as drinking,
bathing, heating, cooking, sanitation, or for cleaning a residence, business, industry, or institution.
Even-number address. Street addresses, box numbers, or rural postal route numbers ending in 0, 2, 4, 6, or 8 and
locations without addresses.
Industrial water use. The use of water in processes designed to convert materials of lower value into forms
having greater usability and value.
Landscape irrigation use. Water used for the irrigation and maintenance of landscaped areas, whether publicly
or privately owned, including residential and commercial lawns, gardens, golf courses, parks, and rights-of-way
and medians.
Nonessential water use. Water uses that are not essential nor required for the protection of public health, safety,
or welfare, including:
(1) Irrigation of landscape areas, including parks, athletic fields, and golf courses, except otherwise
provided under this plan;
(2) Use of water to wash any motor vehicle, motorbike, boat, trailer, airplane, or other vehicle;
(3) Use of water to wash down any sidewalks, walkways, driveways, parking lots, tennis courts, or
other hard-surfaced areas.
(4) Use of water to wash down buildings or structures for purposes other than immediate fire
protection;
(5) Flushing gutters or permitting water to run or accumulate in any gutter or street;
(6) Use of water to fill, refill, or add to any indoor or outdoor swimming pools or Jacuzzi-type
pools;
(7) Use of water in a fountain or pond for aesthetic purposes except where necessary to support
aquatic life;
(8) Failure to repair a controllable leak(s) within a reasonable period after having been given notice
directing the repair of such leak(s); and
7/13/2019 https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 306/430
(9) Use of water from hydrants for construction purposes or any other purposes other than
firefighting.
Odd-numbered address. Street addresses, box numbers, or rural postal route numbers ending in 1, 3, 5, 7, or 9.
(Ordinance O-07-05, sec. 51.059(G), adopted 9/6/05)
Sec. 13.02.038 Criteria for initiation and termination of drought response stages
(a) The mayor or his/her designee shall monitor water supply and/or demand conditions on a regular basis and
shall determine when conditions warrant initiation or termination of each stage of the plan; that is, when the
specified “triggers” are reached. Retail and wholesale customer notification of the initiation or termination of
drought response stages will be made by mail, telephone, local media, and/or local public access television.
(b) The triggering criteria below are based on statistical water use patterns, current and expected weather
conditions, known system capacity limits, and/or current and expected allocation levels from the Canadian River
Municipal Water Authority, our primary supplier of raw water.
(1) Stage 1 triggers–Mild water shortage conditions.
(A) Requirements for initiation. Customers shall be requested to voluntarily conserve water
and adhere to the prescribed restrictions on certain water uses, as defined in section 13.02.037,
definitions, when the municipal water system recognizes that a mild water shortage condition
exists. The following are examples of the types of triggering criteria that may be used in one or
more successive stages of this drought contingency plan:
(Ordinance O-07-05, sec. 51.059(H), adopted 9/6/05)
(i) When water supply allocations from the Canadian River Municipal Water Authority
to the municipal water system are equal to or less than 3600 acre-feet per year, and the
projected use from the municipal water system's owned water wells exceeds 6240 acrefeet
per year. (Ordinance O-002-14 adopted 4/1/14)
(ii) When, pursuant to the requirements specified in the municipal water system's
wholesale water purchase contract with the Canadian River Municipal Water Authority,
notification is received from the authority requesting initiation of stage 1 of the drought
contingency plan. (Ordinance O-07-05, sec. 51.059(H), adopted 9/6/05)
(iii) When, due to declining water levels, mechanical failure, or any other unforeseen
event in the municipal water system's owned wells, an amount of water less than or equal
to 6380 acre-feet of water cannot reasonably be expected to be produced, and there are not
adequate allocations from the Canadian River Municipal Water Authority to bring the
total available water to 9840 acre-feet per calendar year. (Ordinance O-002-14 adopted
4/1/14)
(iv) Any mechanical, accidental, regulatory, or unforeseen event that might negatively
affect the daily safe operating capacity of the municipal water system to continually
provide a safe and reliable supply of drinking water that meets all state and federal
standards. This condition or triggering event must also be expected to persist for several
days or weeks.
(B) Requirements for termination. Stage 1 of the plan may be rescinded when all of the
conditions listed as triggering events have ceased to exist for a period of 30 consecutive days.
The municipal water system will notify its retail and wholesale customers and the media of the
termination of stage 1 in the same manner as the notification of initiation of stage 1 of the plan.

that a moderate water shortage condition exists. The following are examples of the types of
triggering criteria that may be used in one or more successive stages of this drought

projected use from the municipal water system's owned water wells exceeds 6240 acrefeet
per year. (Ordinance O-002-14 adopted 4/1/14)
(ii) When, pursuant to the requirements specified in the municipal water system's
wholesale water purchase contract with the Canadian River Municipal Water Authority,
notification is received from the authority requesting initiation of stage 2 of the drought
contingency plan. (Ordinance O-07-05, sec. 51.059(H), adopted 9/6/05)
(iii) When, due to declining water levels, mechanical failure, or any other unforeseen
event in the municipal water system's owned wells, an amount of water less than or equal
to 5315 acre-feet of water cannot reasonably be expected to be produced, and there are not

(B) Requirements for termination. Stage 2 of the plan may be rescinded when all of the
conditions listed as triggering events have ceased to exist for a period of 15 consecutive days.
Upon termination of stage 2, stage 1 becomes operative.

to the municipal water system are equal to or less than 2524 acre-feet per year, and the
projected use from the municipal water system's owned water wells exceeds 6356 acrefeet
per year. (Ordinance O-002-14 adopted 4/1/14)
